In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: When that Aꝑperril . with his shouris . swote
The drought of Marche hath percid the rote
And bathid . eủery veyne in suche licour
Of whiche vertu engendrid is the floure
And zeferus eke witis swete brethe
Enspirith hath in ey holte and hethe
The tendre Croppis . and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ramme his halfe cours I ronne .
And smale foulis . makyn Meldie
That slepyn al the nyght with opyn eye .
H so pⁱrikith hem nature in hir coragis .
That longyng folkis to goon on pilgrimages .
And palmers for to gon to straunge strondis .
To ferne halwis kouth in sondry . londis .
And specially toto from eủery shiris ende .
Of Engelonde to Cauntirbury they wende
The holy blissid martir for to seke
That hem hath holpyn when they were seke
Be fel that on that sesou on a day .
In southwerke atte the Tabarde as I lay .
Redy to wendyn on my pilgrimage .
To Caunt̉erbury with deuoute Corage
Att nyght was com in to that hostelrie
Wel nyne a tw nyne and twenty in o cōmpany
Of sondry folke . by auenture I falle .
In felachipe and pilgrimes wer they alle .
That touward Caunt̉erbury wolde ride .
The Chaumbures and stabulis were wide .
And wel were we esid . at the bete .
And shortly whan the sonne as to reste .
So had I spokyn with hem ey chone
That I was of hir felaship a none
And made forwarde . herly for to ryse
To take oure wey . ther as youe deuys
But natheles while I haue tyme and space
Me thinkith hit a cording to resoun .
To telle you al the condicioun
Of Eche of hem so as hit semyth me
And whiche they were and what degre
And eke in what aray they in were
And atte a knyght I wille begynne here .
Aknyght ther was . and that a worthi man
That fro the tyme that he firste be ganne
To ridyn oute he louyd Chiualrie
Treuth and honour freedom and curtesie .
Fulle worthi was he in his lordis werre
And ther to had riden no man ferre
As welle in Cristyndome as . in hethynnesse
And eủere honourid for his worthinesse .
At Alisaundre he was whan hit was wonne
Full ofte tyme he had the borde be gonne
A boue al nacions . in pruce
In lettowe had . he reisid and in Ruse
No Cristynman so oftyn of his . degre
In Gernade at the sege eke hadde he bee
Of Algery . had riden in belmarie .
At leis was he . and att satalie
Whenne they were wonne . and in the grete see .
And at many a noble . Armye had he be .
Atte mortaile batailis . had he be fiftene .
And foughtyn for oure feith at transmissene .
In listes thries an ay slayn his foo
This ilke worth knyght had ben also
Sıı̄unme tyme with the lorde . of palatie
A geyne a nothir hethyn in Turkeye
And eủere more he had a soeủereyne pⁱrise
And though that he worthi were he was wise .
And of his porte as meke as a maide .
He neủere . yit dede . velenye . ne saide
In al his lif vnto no man wight
He was a verrey gentil . ꝑparfit gentil knyght
But for to telle you of his araie .
His hors were goode . but he was nott gaie
Of fustian he werid a Gipou
Al smoterid with his habirgeou
For he was . late come from his . vage
And wente to don his pilgrimage
With hym ther wa his sonne a yonge squier
With lx lokkis crulle . and they were leide on presse
Of xxᵗⁱ yere of age was he as I gesse
Of his stature he was of even lengthe
And wondirly delyeủer and grete of strengthe
And he had ben somtyme . in chiualrie
In flaundris . in arteis . in Pkardie
And borne hym welle . in so litil space .
In hope to stonde in his ladies grace .
Enbreidid was his hede as hit were a mede .
And ful of fressh flouris bothe white and rede .
Syngyng he was . and flowtyng al the day .
He was als fressh as the monyth of may .
Short was his gowne . with sleuys longe and wide
Wel koude he sitte on hors . and faire ride .
He koude songes make and wel indite .
Iuste and eke daunce . welle portrei and write
So hote he louyd . that be nyght tale .
He slepe no more than doth a nyghtyngale
Cuteise he was louly and seruysable
And karfe to fore his fadir atte the table
¶ A yeman had . he and seruauntꝭes no moo .
At that that tyme for hym liste to ride soo .
And he was Cladde . in a cote and an hode of grene .
And schef of Pokok o arwes bright and kene .
vndir his belte . he bare ful thriftly .
Wel coude he dresse his takill yomanly .
His sethe Arwis droupid nought with fetheris lowe
In his hande he bare a myghty bowe
A nottid hede . had . he whe and broune visage .
Of wode crafte welle koude . he the . vsage .
vpon his arme . he bare a gaye brasere
And be his side a sworde and a bokeler
And on that othir side a gay dagger .
Harnaised wel . and sharpe as pointe of spe
A xpofor on his brest of Siluyr shene
And horne he bare the bauderic was of grene
A foster was he sothly as I gesse
¶ Ther was also a woman a prioresse
That of smylyng there was ful simple and koy
Hir grettest oth was but by seynte loy
She was clepid madame Eglentyne
Ful wel she songe the seruice diuyne
Entwned in hir note ful semely .
And fresshe she spak ful faire and fetisly .
Aftir the scole of Strdforde . at the wowe
For frensh of Paris . was . to hir vnknowe .
At mete wes I taughte was she with alle .
she lete no morsel . fro hir lippis falle .
Ne wete hir fyngres . in hir sauce depe
Wel coude she karie . a morsel . and wel kepe
That non drope fille on hir breste .
In curtesie was sette mochel hir liste
Hir oeủerlipe wipid she so klene
That in hir coppe no ferthing was sene .
Of grece whanne s dronnkyn had she hir draughte
Ful semely . aftir mete she raught
And sikirly she was . of grete disporte
And ful plesaunte . and amyable of porte
And paynyd hir to countirfete chere .
Of Courte and to ben estately of manere
And to ben holdyn digne of reủerence
But for to speke of hir concience .
She was so charitable and so pitouse
She wolde wepe if she sawe a mowse
Kaught in a trappe if hit were dede or bledde
Of smale houndis . hath she fedde
With rosted flessh or mylke or wastil brede .
But sore wepte she yf any were dede
Or if men smote hem with a yerde smerte
And al was concience and tendirnesse of herte
For semly hir wympill . pinchid was .
Herre nose was streite hir eien grey as glas
Her mouthe full ful smalle and ther to softe and rede
But sikirly . she had a faire for hede
Hitt was al moste a spanne brede I trowe
For hardily she was natt vndirgrowe
Ful fetisly fetise was . hir cloke as I was ware
And smale bedes aboute hir arme she ware bare
A paire of bedis gaudid al with grene
And ther on henge . a broche of golde ful shene
On whiche ther was a krownyd a
Aftyr amor vincit omnia
A nother nonne with hir had she .
That was . hir Chapeleyn and pristis thre
A Monke ther was . a faire for the maistrie
An outerider . that louyd venerie
A manly man to ben an abbott able
Ful many a daynte hors had he in his stable
And whanne he rode myght his bridil here
Glynkyng in a whistelyng wynde as clere
And eke as loude as . doth the chapell belle
Ther as the lorde was keꝑper of the selle
The rule of seinte Maure or of seinte benett
Be cause hit was olde and somdel streite
This ilke monke lete olde thingis pace
And helde aftir the newe worlde the trace .
And hilde aftir the newe worlde the trace .
He yaf nought after the texte of pullid henne
That saith that hounters . be nought holy menne .
Ne that a Monke . whenne that he is recheles .
Is likned till a fissh . that is wat̉erlees
This is to sayn a Monke oute of his Cloistre
But thilke tixte helde . he nought worth an oistre
And I sey his opinyou was gode .
What schulde hehe study and make hym self wode
Vpon a boke in cloistre al way to poure
Othir swynken with ese as houndes and labour
As Austyn haue his swynke to hym reseruyd
Ther for he was . a pⁱrikosour a right
Grehoundes he had as swifte right as foule in flight
Of Pⁱkyng and of huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for no cost wolde he spare
I saw his sleuys purfilde at the honde
With gris and that the fynest of a londe
And for to festene . his hode . vndir his chynne .
He had of golde wrought a full curious pynne
A loue knotte in the grettest ende ther was .
His heed was ballid that schon as any glas
And eke his face . as he had ben an oynt
He was a lorde ful fatte . and in goode poynt
His eyen stepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemyd as a furneis of lede
His botes sowple . his hors in grete astate
Now serteynly he was afaire prelate
He nas nat pale . as a for pynyd goste
A fatte swanne louyd he best of any roste
His palfrey was as broune as as bury
¶ A Frere ther was a wantaune and a mery .
A lymetour o in contre also a ful solempne man
In all the ordris iiij . is non that canne
So mykill of daliaunce and faire language
He had makid ful many a mariage
Of yonge women . at his owne cost
And to his ordre hee was a noble poste
Full wel belouyd and famulier was he
With frankeleyns oeủer all in his cuntre
And eke with worthi women of the toune
For he had pouer of confessioun
As saide hym self more thanne a curat
For of his ordre he was licenciate
Ful swetely her he confessioun
H and plesaunt was his absolucioun
He was an esy man to yif penaunce
Ther as I he wist to haue agode pitaunce .
For vnto a poure orde for to yif
Is signe that a man is wele I schriue
For yif that he yaf he durst make avaunte
He wist that a man was repentaunte .
For many a man so harde is of herte .
He may nought wepe al though hym sore smerte
Ther for in stede of wepyng and praier .
Men muste gif seluer to the poor freres .
His tipette was ay farsyd ful of knyuys .
And pynnys for to yif faire wyvys
And certeynly he had a mery note .
Welle couthe he syng and play on a rote .
Of ȝeddyng he bare vttirly the pⁱrice
His nekke white was . as the floure delis .
Ther to he stronge was . as a Champioun
He knew the Tauernes wel in eủery toun
And eủery osteler . and tappester bebe
Bette thanne a lasour othir a begster
For vnto suche . a worthi man as he
A cordid nought as by his faculte .
To haue with sike lasours aqueintaunce .
Hit is not onest he may nott avaunce .
For to delen with no suche pooreile .
But al with riche and sellers of vitaile
And oeủeral ther as profite schulde arise
Curteise he was and louly of seruise
Ther was no man nowher so vertuous .
He was the best begger . in his hous
And though a wedowe had nat a scho .
so plesaunte was his Principio .
That ther wolde he haue . a ferthing or he went
His purchas was wele bettir than his rente
And Rage he couth as hit were right a whelpe
In loue daies couth he mochil helpe .
With thredebare for ther he was not like a cloisterer .
With threde bare cope as is a pore scoler .
But he was like a maister andand othir a pope
Of double worstede was his semy cope .
That rounde as a belle . oute of the presse .
Somwhat he lispid for his wantaunenesse
To make his Englisch swettir vppon his tonge
And in his harpyng whenne that he had sounge
His eien twynclid in his hede a right
As don the sterris in the frosty nyght
This worthi lymytour was Clepid huberd
¶ A marchaunte was ther with a forkid berd .
In motle and high on a hors he satte
Vpon his hede a flaunderisch beuer hatte
His B botis clapsid faire and fetously
His reasounes he spak ful solempne ly .
sownyng al wey the encres of his wynnyng
He wolde the see wer kepte for any thing
Bi twixt Middilboug Middilburgh and Orwelle
Wel couthe he in eschaunge scheldis selle .
This worthi man wel his witte besette .
Ther wiste no wight that he was in dette
So estately was he of his goeủernaunce .
With his bargaynes and with his cheuysch saunce
For soth he was . a worthi man with all
But soth to say I nott hou men hym calle
¶ A Clerke ther was . of Oxenford also .
That vnto logik had long I goo .
As lene was his hors . as is a Rake .
He was nat right fatte I vndir take .
But lokid holwe . and ther to sobirly .
Ful thredebare was his oeủerest curtepie
For he had getyn hym ther no benyfice
Ne was so worldly for for to haue an office
For hym was leuer haue at his beddis hede .
Twenty bokis clad in blak othir rede .
Of Aristotile . in his philosophie .
Thanne Robis riche othir phithil . or gay sauterie
But al be that he was a Philosophir
HeYitHeYit had he but litle gl golde in his Coffre
But al that he myght of his frendis hente
On bokis and on lernyng he hit spente
And bisily ganne for the soules pray
Of hem that yaf hem wher with to scolay
Of stody toke he most cure and most hede
Not o word spak he more thanne was nede .
And that was said in fourme and reủerence
And schorte and w quykke and ful of high sentence
Sounyng in a moral vertue was his speche .
And gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche
¶ A Sergiaunte of the lawe that was ware and wise
That had ben at the paruys .
He was also full . riche of excellence .
Discret he was . and of grete reủerence .
He semede swiche his wordis . weren so wise .
Iustise he was full often in assise
Bi Patent and by playn Cōmmissioun
For his science and his high renoun
Of fees and robes . had he manyon
So grete a purchasour was nowher non
All was fee . symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not ben enfecte
Nawher so besy aman as he ther nas .
And yit he semyd bisier than he was
In t̉ermes hadde he cas . and domes all
That fram the tyme . of william wer falle .
Ther to he couthe endite . and make a thing
Ther couthe no wight pynche . at his writyng
And eủery statut couth he playn be rote .
He rod but homly . in a medle cote .
Gert with a sainte . of silke with barris smale .
Of his a ray . telle I no lenger tale
¶ A Frankelayn also was in this companie
White was his berd . as is the daisie
Of his complexcioun he was sanguyne
Wel louyd he be the morwe a sop in wyn
To lyuyn in delite . was eủere his wone
For he was Epucurus owne sonne
That hilde opinioun that playn delite
Was verray felicite and parfit
An housholdir and that a grete was hee
Saynt Iulian he was in his contre
His bred his ale was al waies aftir on
A bettre enuyned man was neủere non
Withoutyn bakemete neủere his hous
Of fissh and flessh and that so plentiuous
Hit snewid in his hous of mete and drinke
Of all dayntees that men couthe thinke
Aftir the sondry sesouns of the yere
So chaungid he his mete and his sopere
Ful many a fat partrich had he in mue
And many a brem and many luce in stue
Wo was his cook bote yif his sauce were .
Poynaunt and scharpe . and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his hal al way .
Stode redy cuuerid al the longe day .
Att sessiouns ther was he lorde and Sire
Ful ofte tyme he was . knyght of the schire
An anlaas and a gipser al of selke
Heng at his gurdill . white as morwe mylke
A schereue had he ben and eke countour
Was nowher swich a worthi vauasour
An Haberdassher and a Carpenter ther was .
A webbe a diere and a Tapister .
And they were clothid all in o lyuere .
Of a solempne and a grete frat̉ernite .
Ful fresshe and newe hur gere ay pikid was .
Hur knyuys ner chapid nought with brasse
But all with siluer . wrought ful clene and well
Hur gurdelis and hur nouches . eủery del
Wel semyd eche of hem a faire burgeis .
To sittyn in a ȝeldehalle . on a deys .
eủeriche for the wisdom that he canne
Wer schaply for ben an aldirman
For Catel had they I now and rente
And hir wivis woldyn wel assente .
And els certayn they were to blame
Hit is ful fayre . to be clepid madame
And gon to vigilis al be fore
And haue a Mantell rialliche I bore
A Cooke they had wyth . hem for the nones .
To boile the Chekens with the maribones .
And poudir Marchaunt tarte of galyngale
Wel couth he knowe a draught of londou ale
He couth roste and seth and broile and frie
Makyn Mortrews and welle bake a pie
But grete harme was hit thought me
That on his schyn a marymole had he
For blanke mang that made he with the beste
¶ A Schipman was ther wonyng fer by west
For aught I wote he was of Dertmouthe
He rode vpon a rounsy as he couth
In a goune of falchyg that to the kne .
H A Dagger . hangyng on a las had he .
A boute his nekke vndir his arme doune
The hote somyr hath made his hew al broune
And certeynly he was a gode felawe .
Ful many a draught of wyn had drawe
Fro burdeus ward while that that chapmān slepe
Of nise conscience . toke he no cepe
Yif that he faught and had the hier hande
By wat̉er he sente hem home . to eủery lande
But of his crafte . to rekyn well his tidis .
TheHisTheHis stremes and his daungers hym bi sidis
His herberw and his mone and his ledemanage
Ther was no suche fram hēnne to Cartage
Hardy he was and wis to vndirtake
With many a tempest had ben his berde schake
He knew welle . al the hauenes . as thei were
Fro gotlond to the Cape the finis tere
And eủery creke in Britaigne and in spayne
His barge . clepid was . the maudleyn
¶ With vs ther was a Doctour of fisik
In al this . worlde ne was ther noon hym like
To speke of fisik and of Surgerie
For he was groundid in Astronomye
He cepte his pacience ofof a full grete delle .
In his houris by his magik naturel .
Wel couth he fortunen the assendent .
Of his ymages for his pacient
He knew the cause of eủerych maladie
Were hit of hot . othir colde othir moiste or drie
And were engendrid and what humour
He was a verrey parꝑparfite practesour
The cause he knew and of his harme the rote
A non he yaf the sikemann his bote
Ful redy had he his Apotecaries .
To send hym drenchis . and his letuaries
For eche of hem made othir for to wynne .
Hir frendship nas . naught newe to be gynne .
Wel knew he . the olde esculapius .
And deiscroides and eke rufus .
Olde ypocras . haly and galien
Serapiou Rasis . and auyzen
Auerrois . Damascien and constantyn
Bernard and gatesdene and gilbertyn
Of his Diete mesurable was hee .
For hit was of no suꝑperfluite
But of gret norishing and digestible .
His stidie was . but litil on the bible .
In Sangyn Sangwyn and in pers . he cl clad was all
Lynyd with taffata and with sendall .
And yit he was . but esy of dispense
He kepte that he wanne in pestilence
For golde in fisik is cordiall .
Ther for he louyd gold in speciall .
¶ A goode wif was . ther of bi side bathe
But sche was sumdell . def and that was skathe .
Of clothmakyng sche had suche an haunt
sche passid hem of ypres and of gaunt
In all the Parissh wiff wif ne was ther non
That offring bifore . hir scholde gon
And yif ther dide . certayn so wroth was sche .
Ther sche was oute of al charite
Hur curchiues ful fyne were . of grounde
I durst swere . they weydyn al oute x pounde
That on a sonday . weryn vpon hir hede
Hir hosyn were of fyne scarlet rede
Ful straite I teide . and schoes ful straite and newe
Bold was hir face and faire and rede of hewe
sche was a worthi woman al hir lif
Housbondis at the Chirche dore sche had fife
Withoutyn othir cumpanie in hir youthe
But ther of nedith nought to speke as nowe
And thris had sche . ben at Ierusalem
Sche had passid many a straunge streme
At Rome sche had ben and at boleyn
In Galeis and at seint Iame and at Coleyn
Sche couth mochil of wandring by the way
Gap tothid was sche soleyn sothlysothly for to say .
Vpon an ambeler esely sche satt
I wymb wymplyd well . and on hir hede an hatte .
As brode . as is a bokeler othir a targe .
A fote Mantell . aboute hir hepis large
And on hur fete . a paire of spurris scharpe
In felawschip wel couth sche laugh and carpe
Of remedies of loue . sche knewe . ꝑpar chaunce
For sche couth of that arte the olde daunce .
¶ A gode man was ther of religiou
And was a poure persoun of a toune
But riche he was of holy thought and werke
He was also l a lernyd man a Clerke
That Cristꝭes gospell trewly wolde preche
His parischons deuoutely wold he teche .
Benygne he was and wondir diligente .
And in adeủersite . ful paciente .
And swiche he was I preuyd oftyn sithis .
Ful loth wer hym to cursyn for his tithis .
But rathir wolde he yif oute of doute
Vnto his poor parischons a boute
Of his offring and eke of his substaunce
He couth in litil thing haue suffisaunce
Wide was his parish and housis fer a sondir
But he ne lafte natt for rayne ne thondir
In sikenes nothir in myschif to visite
The ferrest in his parissh moche and lite
Vpon his fete . and in his hand a staff
This noble insaumple . vnto his schepe he yaf
That fir he wrought and aft̉erward that he taught
And oute of the gospell he tho wordis caught
And eke this figure . he addid eke ther to
That yif gold rust what schal Iryn do
For yif a prest be foule on whom we trust
No wondir nysse a leude man to rust
And schame hit is yif that a prest take ce kepe
A schiten schepherd and a clene schepe
Welle ought a pste . ensaumple for to yiue
Bi his clennesse . hou that his schep schulde leue
He sett nought his benefice to hire
And let his schepe . encombrid in the myre .
And ranne to londou vnto seint poules .
To sekyn hym a chaunterie for soules .
Othir with a brothirhed to ben with holde .
But dwelle at home and kepe wel his folde
So that the wolf ne made hit nought miscarie
He was a schepher and a nought a mercenarie
And though he holy were and vertuous
He nas nought to synfullmen dispitous
Ne of his speche . daungerous ne digne
But in his techinge discret and benygne
To drawyn folke to heuen by fairenesse .
Bi goode insaumple . this was his bisinesse .
But it were any ꝑpersoune obstinate .
What so he wer of high and low estat
Hym wolde hynhyn he snybben scharply for the nones .
A bett̉er I trow that nawher noon es .
He waitid aft̉er no pompe and reủerence .
Ne makyd hym a spisid conscience .
But Cristis lore and his posteles twelue
He taught but first he folwid hit hym self .
¶ With hym ther was . a plowman was his brothir
That had I lad of dounge full many a fothir
And trew swynker and a gode was he .
Lyuyng in pees . and ꝑparfite charite .
God louyd he best with al his hole herte .
At al tymes . though he gamyd or smerte .
And than his neighboure right as hym selfe .
He wolde thresch and ther dike and delue
For cristis sake with eủery pore wight
With outyn hire yif hit lay in his myght
His tithis paied he ful faire and welle
Bothe of his propre swynk and his catell .
In a tabarde he rode upon a mere
¶ Ther was also a Reue and a Millere
A Somenour and a ꝑpardoner also
A Maunciple and my self ner ther namo .
The Miller was a stoute Carle for the nones .
Ful big he was of braune and eke of bones .
That prouyd wel for oeủeral where he cam
Att wrastelyng he wolde haue al wey the ramme
He was schort schuldrid brode a thikke knarre
Ther ne was no dore that he ne wolde haue of harre
Othir breke hit at arennyng with his hede
His berd as any sow asothirasothir fox was rede
And ther to brode as though hit were a spade
vpon his coppe right of his nose he had
A werte and ther stode a tufte of heris .
Rede as the bristillis as a sowis eris .
His nostrellis blak blak were and wide
A swerde and a bokeler he bare by his side
His mouth as grete was as a grete furneys
He was a yangeler and a goliardeys
And that was most of synne and har lottries .
Wel couth he stele . corne . and tolle thries .
And yit he had . a thombe of gold ꝑparde
A white cote . and a blew hode werid he .
A bag pipe . wel couth he blowe and soune .
And ther with all . he brought us oute of toune .
¶ A gentill Maunciple . was ther of a Temple .
Of whiche a catours myght take example .
For to ben wise in bigbigbig biyng of vitaile .
For whethir that he paide othir toke bitaile .
Al gate he waitid so on his ag acate .
That he was ay be forne . and in gode state .
Now is hit nott that of god a full faire grace
s that suche a leude manes witte schall pace
The wisdam of an hepe of lernyd men
Of Maistris . had he . mo than thris ten
That weryn of law exꝑperte . and curious
Of whiche ther were . ai doseyn in that hous
Worthi to ben steuwardꝭes of rente and lande
Of any lordis . that is in Engelonde .
To make hym lyue . by his propre gode .
In honoure . sentenles . but he wer wode .
Or lyue a scarsly as hym list desire
And able for to helpen anan al an hole schire
In any cas . that myght fall othir hap
And ther this . maunciple sette hur althir haphap cap
¶ The reue was a sclendir colrik man
His berd was schaue as nygh as eủer he can
His here was by his ere . ful rounde I schorne
His top was dockid like a prest biforne .
Ful long were his leggis and full lene .
I lik a staf . ther was no calf I sene
Wel couth he kepe . a gerner and a bynne .
Ther was non auditour couthe on hym wyn
Wel wist he by . the drought and by the rayn
The ȝeldyng of his . sed and of his grayn
His lord schip his nete . his deirie .
His swyn his hors his store and his pultrie
Was holy in this reuys goeủernyng
And by his couenaunt yaf the rekenyng
Synne that his lorde was twenty yere of age .
Ther couth no man bring hym in arereage .
Ther nas baili ne herde othir odir hyne
That he ne knew his sleight and his cunnyng
They were of hym a drad as of the deth
His wonyng was ful . faire vpon an heth
With grene trees schaduyd was his place .
He couth bett̉er thanne his lord purchace .
For richeliche a storis he was priuilie
His lorde wel couth he please subtilly .
To yiue and lene hym of his awne gode .
And haue a thanke and yit a cote and a hode
In youth he lernyd and had a gode maister .
He was a wel . gode wright a Carpynt̉er
This Reue sat vpon a wel gode stotte .
That was ofof a pomyl grey and a hight scot .
A long surcote of pers . upon his hond hade
And by his side he bare a rusty blade .
Of Northfolke was this Reue of whiche I tell .
By side a toune . men clepid Beldiswell .
TherTher Tuckid he was . as is a free a boute
And eủere he rode the hyndreste of oure route
¶ A somnour tl was ther with us in that place .
That had a fire rede r cherebyns face .
For sawseflewme he was with eyen narwe
As hote he was and lecherous as any sparwe
With skalid browis blak and pilid berd .
Of his viseage childryn were a ferd
Ther nas quyksiluyr litarge othir brymston
Boras . ceruse ne oyle of tartre non
Ne oyntement that wold clense and bite
That hym myght helpyn of the whelkꝭes white .
Nothir of the knobbis sittyng on his chekis
Wel louyd he garlike oyneons and eke lekis
And for to drink strong wyne rede as blode
Thanne wolde he speke and crie as he were wode
And whanne that he weldronkyn had the wynne
Thanne wold he speke . no worde but latyn
A fewe t̉ermys had he . to or thre
That he had lernyd oute of som deg decre
No wondir . is he herde hit al the day
And eke ye knowyn wel how that a yaie
canne clepyn wat as wel as can the pope
But who so couth in othir thing hym grope
Thanne had he spente al his philosophie
Ay questio quid Iuris wold he crie
He was a gentill . har lot and a kynd
A bettir felawe schuld men naught fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A goode felaw to haue his concubyne .
A twelfe monthe . and excuse hym att fulle .

l.hi: and yif he fond anwhere a gode felaw

div.l: Ful priuily a fynch well . couth he pull .
And yif he fond anwher . a good felawe
He wold teche hym to haue . non awe .
In swiche cas . of the Archedeknes curs
But yf a mannes sovle were in his purs
For in his purs he schulde I punysshid be
Pur is the Archideknes . helle saide hee .
But welle I wote . he lide right in dede .
Of cursinge ought eche gilty man drede
For Curs will . sle . right as soilyng sauyth
And also ware hym of a significauit
¶ In daunger had he at his . owne . gise .
The yonge gurles . of the diocise
And knew hur counsaill . and was al hir rede
A gerlaund hadde he sett upon his hede .
As grete as it were for an ale stake .
A bokeler . had he . mad hym of a kake .
¶ With hym ther rod a gentil pardoner .
Of Rouncivale . his frend and his compere
That stright was comen fro the Courte of Rome .
Ful loude he song cu hedir loue to me
This somenoure bar to hym a stiff burdoun
Was neủere trumpe . of half so grete . soun
This pardoner . had here as . yelwe . as wex .
Bute smoth hit heng as doth a strike of flex .
Be . ounces . henge his . lokkis that he had .
And ther with his scholdris . al oeủer spred
But thynne hit lay by culpons on and on
But hode for Iolite . ne werid he non
For hit was trusshid upon his walet
Hym thought he rode . al of the newe iette .
Descheuele . saue his cap he rode al bare .
Swiche glaring . eien had he as an hare .
A vernycle had he sewid on his cape
His walett lay be forne . hym in his lappe .
Bretful of pardoun comen from Rome al hote .
A voise had . as smal as hath a gote .
No berde had he ne neủere . scholde . haue
As smothe hit was as it were late I schaue .
I trowe he were . a geldyng othir els a mare .
But of his Crafte fro Berwik in to ware
Ne was ther swiche a nothir pardoner .
For in his male . he had a pilwe ber
Whiche he saide . he hadhe had . was oure lady veil .
He saide . he had . a gobet of the sail .
That seint petur had whenne that he wente
vpon the see . til Iesu Crist hym hente
He had a Crosse of latyn ful of stones .
And in a glas . he had piggis bones .
But with thise . relikes . whenne that he fonde
A poeủere ꝑpersoun dwellyng upon londe .
vpon a day he h gate hym more mone moneye
Than that the ꝑpersoun gat in monthis twey .
And thus with faynyd flateryng and iapes .
He made the ꝑpersoun and the people his apis .
But truly to tellyn at the laste
He was in Chirche . a grete ecclesiaste
Wel couthe he rede a . lessoun othir a storie
But al ther beste he song an offretorie
For wel he wiste whenne . that sounge was sounge
He moste pche and wel . affile ther to his tounge
To wynne siluer as he ful wel koude
Ther for he songe the murierly and loude
Nowe haue I tolde you sothly in clause
The estate . the array . the nounbre . and eke the cause
Whi that assemblid was . this . companye
In Southwerke . at this gentil hostlerie
That hight the Tabard faste by the belle .
But now is tyme to you for to telle
How that we baryn vs that ilke nyght
Whenne that we were . in that hostelrie a light
And aftir wille I telle of oure viage
And al the remenaunte of oure pilgrimage
But first I pray you of youre curtesie .

l.hi: though that I playnly in this matere

div.l: That ye ne arrecte it nought my vilanye
Though that I playnly in this matere
To telle you hur wordis . and hur chere
Ne though I speke hir wordes . proꝑperly
For this ye knowen also wel as I .
Ho so schal . telle . a tale aft̉er aman
He mote reherse . as neigh as he canne
eủerich worde . yif hit be in his charge
Al speke he neuer . so rudeliche ne large .
Othir els . he moote telle . his tale vntruew
Othir fainyd thing and fynde wordes newe
He may nott spare . al though . he were his brothir
He mote as welle . seye of o worde as an nothir
Crist spak hym self ful brode in holy writte
And wel ye wot no vilenye is it
Eke plato . saith ho so canne hym rede .
The wordis . mote be Cosyn to the dede .
Also I praye you to for yeuyn yeue hit me
Al haue I nought sett folke in hir degre
Here in this tale as that they scholde stonde
My witt is schorte ye may wel vndirstonde
¶ grete chere made . oure hoste us eủerichon
And to the soper . sette he ous a noon
He seruyd . vs . with with vitaile . at the beste .
Strong was the wyn and wel to drinke us leste

l.seg: A semly man he was . with eyen stepe
A fairer burgeis is ther non in chepe .
Bolde of his speche . and wise and wel I taughte .
and of manhede . hym lakkyd right nought

div.l: A semly man oure hoste was with all
For to ben a marchall . in a lordes halle .
A large man he was . with eyen stepe
A fairer Burgeis . is ther non in chepe .
Bolde in his speche . and wise and wel I taught
And of manhede hym lackid right nought
eke ther to he was . a murie man
And aftir soper . pleyen he be gan
And spak of murthe . amonge othir thyngis
Whanne that he had mad oure rekenynges
And saide thus . now lordynges trewly .
ye be to me welwel right welcome hertly .
For be my trouthe . yif that I schal not lie
I ne sawe this yere so murie a companye .
At ones in this herberwe as is nowe
Fayn wold I do you murthe wiste I howe
And of a murth I am right nowe by thought
To don you eese . and hit schal coste nought
¶ ye gon to Caunterburie . god you spede .
The blissid martir quite you your mede
And welle I wote . as ye gon by the way .
ye schapyn you to talyn and eke to play .
For truly confort ne myrth is noon
For to ridyn by the wey . dombe as the ston
And ther for . will I make you disporte
As I saide erst and don you som comforte
And yif ye likyn al by on assente
For to stondyn to my iugement
And for to werkyn as I schal you say .
To morwyn whenne ye ridyn be the way
Now be my fadir soule that is dede .
But ye be murie y wil yif you myn hede
Holde vp your hand with oute more speche
Oure consail was . nat . longe for to seche
vs thought it was . nought worthi to make it uys .
And grauntid hym withoute more auys .
And bad hym say . his . verdit as hym lyste
Lordynges quoth he nowe herkyneuth for the beste
But take hit nought I pray you in disdeyne
This is the poynt to speke schorte and playn
That eche of you to schorte with your weye
In this viage . schal tellen tales twey .
To Caunturbury ward y mene hit so
And homward schal tellyn othir too .
Of Auenturus that whilom haue I falle .
this is to seynthis is to seyn And whiche of you that berith hym best of all .
This to seyn that tellith in this cas
Tales of best sentence . and most solas .
Schal haue a soꝑpar at oure aldre coste .
Here in this place . sittyng by this post
Whanne that that we comme ageyn from Caunturbury .
And for to make you the more mury
I wille my selfe gladly with you ride
And who so will . my iugement with say
schal pay al . that we spend by the way .
And yif ye vouche sauf that this be so .
Tellith me anon withoute wordis moo .
And I will . erly schape me therfor .
This thing was grauntid and oure othis swore
With ful glad hert and praidyn hym al so
That he wolde vouche sauf for to do soo .
And that he wolde . be oure goeủernoure
And of of oure talis . Iuge and reportour
And sette the soꝑpar at a certeyn pris .
And we will . rulid ben at his deuys .
In highe and lowe and thus by on assente
We ben acordid to the Iugement
¶ and ther upon the wyn was fett anon
We dronkyn and to reste . wente we echon
Withoutyn any lenger tariyng
A morwe whanne the day gan spring
vp ros oure hoste and was oure aldre cokke
And gaderid ous to gederis in a floke
And forthe we ridyn a litil more than pas .
vnto the wateryng . of seint Thomas .
And ther oure oste by gan his hors a reste
And saide lordes herkneth yif you leste
I wot your forwarde . and ye it recorde
yif euen song and morw song acorde
Lat se nowe ho schal telle oure first tale
Whilom as olde stories tellen vs
Ther was a duke that hight Teseus
Of Attenes he was lord and goeủernour
And in his tyme suche a conquerour
That gretter was ther noon vndir the Sonne
Full many a Riche Cuntre hadde he wonne
What with his wisdom and his Chiualrie
He Conquerid all the Regne of Femenye
That whilom was callid Scithia
And weddid the Quene ypolita
And brought hur home with hym in to his cuntre
With mochill glorie and grete solempnite
And eke hur yonge suster Emelie
And thus with victorie and with melodie
Lat I this noble Duke to Athenes ride
And all his Oste in Armus hym by side
¶ And certis yif it ner to longe to here
I wolde haue tolde you Fully the maner9
Howe wonnyn was the Reigne of femenye
By Theseus and by his Chiualrie
And of the grete Bataile for the nones
By twixen Athenes and Amazones
And how assegid was Ypolita
The faire hardy quene of Scithia
And of the feste that was at hur weddyng
And of the tempeste at hir hom comyng
But alle that thing I mot as now for bere
And weike ben the oxen in my plow
¶ The remenaunt of the tale is longe I now
I wille nott lettyn eke noon of this Route
Late eủerry felawe telle his tale a boute
And late se nowe who schall the soper wynne
And ther I lafte I wille ayen be gynne
¶ This duke of whom I make menciou
When he was comen almoste vnto the towne
In all his wele and in his most pride
He was ware as he caste his eie a side ¶ Knyght
Wher that ther knelid in the highe wey
A companie of ladies tweie and tweie
Eche aftir othir clad in clothis blake
Butt suche a crie and suche a woo they make
That in this worlde nys creature lyuyng
That herd swiche a nothir weymentyng
And of this crie thei wolde neuer stenten
Tille they the Reynes of his bridill henten
¶ What folke bēn ye that att myn hom comyng
ꝐPertourbyn so my feste with criyng
Quoth Theseus haue ye so grete enuye
Of myn honoure that thus compleyne and crie
Othir hoo hath you mysbodyn othir offendid
And why that ye beenwhy that ye been tellith me yif hit may be amendid
And whi that ye ben clothid thus in blak
The eldeste lady of hem alle spake
Whanne sche had swonyd with a dedely chere
That hit was reuth for to sen and here
¶ Sche saide victorivictori lorde to wham fortune hath yeuen
Victorie and as a conquerour to lyuen
Nat greuyth ous youre glorie and your honour
But we be seke mercy and socoure
Haue mcy on oure wo and oure distresse
Some drope of pite thorwe thi gentilnesse
Vpon vs wrechid wymmen lat thou falle
For certis lord ther is non of vs all
That sche ne hath ben a duchesse othir a quene
Now be we caitiues as it is well I sene
Thankid be fortune and hir fals whele
That noon estatete assureth to ben well
¶ Now certis lorde to a bidyn your psence
Here in the temple of the godesse clememence
We haue ben waitynge all fourtene nyght
Now helpe us lord sith it is in thi myght ¶ Knyght
¶ I wrecche whiche that wepe and wayle thus
Was whilom wif to kyng Cappaneus
That starf at thebes cursid be that day
And all we that ben in this aray
And maken all this lamentacou
We losten all oure housbondes at that toun
While that the sege ther aboutes lay
And yitt now the olde Creou wailaway
That lord is nowe of Thebes that Citee
Full fillid of of Ire and of iniquite
He for dispite and for his tiranye
To done the b dede bodies vilanye
Of all oure lordes whiche that ben slawe
Hathe all the bodies on an hep I drawe
And will natt suffren hem by noon assent
Neithir to ben I burijd nothir I brent
But makith houndithhoundishoundith houndis ete hem in dispite
And with that worde with oute more respite
Thei fillyn gruf and cridyn pitously
F haue on vs wrechid wōmmen som mercy
And late oure sorwe synkyn in thi herte
¶ This gentill Duke doun fram his courcer sterte
With herte pitous whenne he herde hem speke
Hym thought that his herte wolde breke
When he saw hem so pitous and so mate
That whilom weren of so grete estate
And in his Armys he hem all vp soso hente
And hem confortith in full goode intente
And swore his othe as he was trewe knyght
He wolde don so ferforth his myght
Vpon the tyraunt Creon hym to wreke
That all the people of grece scholde speke ¶ Knyght
Howe Creou was of Theseus I seruyd
As he that hadde his dethe full well deseruyd
And right a noon withoute more abode
His baner . he displaijd and forth rode
To Thebes ward and all his oste be side
No ner Athenes wolde he gon ne ride
Ne take his eese fully half a day
Butt onwarde on his way that nyght he lay
And sente a non Ypolita the queene
And Emelie hir yonge sustir schene
Vnto the toun of Athenes to dwelle
And forth he rit ther is namore to telle
The Rede statue of mars with spere and targe
So schinyth in his white baner large
That all the feldis glidereden vp and doun
And by his baner borne is his penoun
Of golde full riche in whiche ther was I bete
The M Minotaur whiche that he slowe in Crete
Thus Rite this Duke thus Rite this conquerour
And in his oste of chiualrie the floure
Till that he cam to Thebes and a light
Faire in a felde ther that he thought to fight
Butte schortly to spekyn of this thing
With Creou whiche that was of Thebes kynge
He faught and slowe hym manly as a knyght
In playne bataile and put the folke to flight
And at assaut he wan the Cite aftir
And rent a doun bothe wall and sparr and Raftir
¶ And to the ladies he restorid agayn
The bones of hur frendis that weryn slayn
To don obsequies as was tho the gise
But it wer all to longe forto deuise
The grete Clamour and waymentynge ¶ Knyght
That the ladies made at the brennyng
Of the bodies and the grete honoure
That Theseus the noble conquerour
Dothe to the ladies when they fro hym wente
But schortly for to telle is myn entente
Whan that this worthi Duke this teseus
Had Creou slayn and wonnen thebes thus
Stille in that felde he toke all nyght his reste
And did with all the Cuntre as hym liste
To Ransake the tacetastace tas of the bodies dede
Hem for to strepe of harneys and of wede
The pilours diden bisenes and cure
Aftir the bataile and disconfiture
And so by fell that in the taas of the bodies dedethey foundeof the bodies dedethey founde
Thurgh hirte with many a greuous wounde
Tho yonge knyghtis ligginge by and by
Both in oon armes . wrought full richely
Of whiche tho Arcita hight that oon
And that othir knyght hight Palamou
Natt fully quike ne fulli dede thei were
But by hur Cote armures and by hur gere
The heraudis knewe hem best in speciall
As they w that weren of the blood roiall
Of Thebes and of sustren tho I borne
Out of the taas the pilours han hem torn
And han hem carijd softe vnto the tente
Of theseus and he full sone hem sente
To Atthenes for to dwelle in pⁱrisou
ꝐPererpetuelly he nolde no Raunsoun
And when this worthi Duke hath thus I don
He toke his oste and hom he ridith anon
With laurer croned as a conquerour
And ther he lyuith in ioie and in grete honoure ¶
Terme of his lif what nedith wordis moo
And in a toure in anguysch and in wo
Dwellyn this Palamou and eke arcite

With hundis swiche as that hym list comaunde ¶
And whanne this Duke was comen in to the launde
Vndir the sonne he lokith and a noon
He was war of Arcite and Palamou
That foughtyn breme as it we boles thoo .
The bright swerdis wentyn to and fro .
So hidously that with the lest stroke
Hit semyd as it wolde fellen an oke
But what thei were nothing he ne wote
The Duke his courser with his spores smote
And at a strote he was he was by twixen too .
And pullid oute a sch swerde and cried hoo .
No more vpe payne of lesyng of your lifhedlif hed
Be myghty mars he schall anon be dede
That smytith any stroke that I may seen
Butt telle me now what myst̉er men ye ben
That ben so hardy . for to fightyn here
Withoutyn Iugge othir officer
As though it were in R listis Rially
This Palamou answerid hastily
And side leue sire what nedith wordis mo
We haue the deth deseruid bothe too
Too wofull wrecches and kaitiues
That ben encombrid of oure owne lyues
And as thou art now a rightfull lorde and iuge
Ne yif vs neithir mercy ne refuge
But sle me first for saint charite
But sle my felawe eke as well as me
Othir sle hym first for though thou know hym lite
This is thi mortall foo that hete Arcite
That fro this lond is banysshid oeủer his hede
For which hath deseruyd to be deed
For this is he that that com vnto thi gate ¶ Knyght
And saide that he hight Philostrate
Thus hath he iapid the ful many yere
And thou haste makid hym thi chif squier
And this is that al so louyth Emelie
For sith the day is com that I mostschalmost schal die
I make playnly my confessiou
That I am thilke wofull Palamou
That hath thi pⁱrisoun brokyn wikkidly
I am thi mortall fo and hit am I
That louyth so hote Emelie the bright
That I wille die psente in hir sight
Wherfor I aske deth and my iuyse
But sle my felawe in the same wise
For both haue we deseruyd to be slayn
This worthi duke answerid anon ageyn
And saide this is a schort conclusiou
ThYourTh Your owne mouth by your confessiou
Hath dampnid meyoume you and I will hit record
Hit nedith nott to peyne you with the corde
Ye schall be dede be myghti Mars the rede
The quene anon for verrey wōmmanhede
Gan for to wepe and so did Emelie
And all the ladies in the cōmpanye
Grete pite was hit as hit thought hem all
That eủere suche a chaunce schulde by falle
For gentill men thei were of grete estate
And nothing but for loue was this debate
And sawe hur blody woundis wide and sore
And all they cridyn both lesse and more ¶ Knyght
Haue mercy lorde vpon vs women all
And on hur bare knees doune gonne they fall
And wold haue kist his fet ther as he stode
Til at the laste a slakid was his mode
For pite renneth sone in gentill herte
And though he first for Ire quoke and sterte
He hath considerid schortly in a clause
The trespas of hem bothe and eke the cause
And al though his ire hure gilte acusid
Yit in his reesoun hem he both excusid
As thus he thought well that eủery man
Will help hym selfe in leflouelef loue if that he can
And eke delieủere hym self out of pⁱrisoun
And eke his hert had compassiou
Of wōmmen for they wepen eủere on and on
And in his gentill herte he thought a non
And softe vnto hym self he saide fy
Vpon a lorde that will haue no mercy
But be alyou both in worde and dede
To hem that ben in repentaunce and drede
As well as in a proude dispitous man
That will mayntene that he first be ganne
That lorde hath litill of discressiou
That in suche cas can no diuisiou
Butt weieth pⁱride and humblenesse aftur on
And schortly whan thishisthis ire is thus a gon
He gan to lokyn vp with eien light
And spake thise same wordes al on height
¶ The god of loue a benedicite
How myghti and howe grete a lorde is hee ¶ Knyght
Ayeyns his myght ther gaynee none obstakelis
He may be clepid a god for his miraclis
For he canne makyn at his owne gise
Of eủerich herte as that hym list deuyse
Lo here this Arcite and this Palamou
That quittely weren oute of my pⁱrisoun
And myght haue I leuyd in thebes realli
And wetyn wel I am hir mortal ennemy
And that hur deth lith in myght also
And yit hath loue maugre hir eien too
Brought hem now hedir bothe for to die
Now loketh is nat that a hie folie
¶ Who may be a fole but yif he loue
Bi holde for godis sake that sit a boue
Se howe thei bledyn and they nott well arraijd
Thus hath hir lorde the god of loue I paide
Hir wages and hir fees for hir seruise
And yit they wenyn for to ben ful wise
That seruyn loue for aught that may be falle
But this is yit the best game of all
That sche for whom thei haue this ioliste
Can hem ther offorof for as muche thanke as me
Sche wott no more of all this hote fatefarefate fare
Bi god thanne wott a kuckow or an hare
But al mote ben assaijd hote and colde
A man mote be a fole othir yong othir olde
I wot hit by my self ful yore agon
For in my tyme a seruaunt was I oon
And therfor sithyn I know of loues paine
And wot how gretesoregrete sore hit kan aman destraine ¶
As he that hath ben kaught ofte in his las
I you for yif al holy this trespace
Att request of the quene that knelith he
And eke of Emelie my sustre dre dere
And ye schal bothe anon vnto me swere
That neủere mo ye schall my countre dere
Ne make warre vpon me nyght nothir day
But ben my frendes in all ye may
I you for yiue this trespas eủery dele
And they hym swore his axing faire and wele
And hym of lordeschip and of mercy preide
And he hem grauntid gᵃce and thus he saide
¶ To speke of Real lynage and richesse
Though that sche were a quen othir pⁱrinsspⁱrinscessepⁱrinsspⁱrinscesse
Eche of you both is worthi douteles
To weddyn whenne tyme is bot natheles
I speke as for my sustir Emelie
For whom ye haue this and ialosie
Ye wott your self sche may nat weddyn thoo
At ones though ye fightyn eủer mo
That oon of you al by hym loth othir lif
He mote goo pipyn in a yuy lef
This is to sayn sche may nat nowe haue both
Alle bebe ye so ialous ne so wroth
And for thi I putput you putt in this degre
That sche of you schal haue his destenye
As hym is schape and herkyneth in what wise
Lo here your ende of that I schall deuise
¶ My wille is this for that conclusioun
Withoutyn any othir replicacoun
And if you likith take it for the best ¶ Knyght
That eủeriche of you schal gon wer hym list
Frely withoutyn Raunsou othir daunger .
And this day lᵗⁱ welwekiswel wekis fer ne ner .
eủerich of you schall bringe an C knyghtis
Armyd for listis vp at all rightꝭes
Al redy to darrayne hir bataile
And this bihote y you with oute faile
Vpon my trouth and as I am a knyght
That whethir of you both that hath myght
This is to sayn that wher he or thou
May with his hundred as I spak of now
Sle his contrarie othir oute of listis driue
That I schall yif hym Emelie to wiue
To whom that fortune yiueth so faire a gᵃce
The listis schal I maken right here in this place
And god so wissly on my soule rewe
As I schall euen iuge be and trewe
Ye schullen non othir ende with me makyn
And if th l you thinkith this is wel I saide
Saieth your auys and holdith you paide
This is your ende and your conclusiou
He lokith lighte now but Palamou
Who springith vp for ioie but Arcite
Ho couthe telle othir ho couth hit endite
The ioie that is makid in the place
When theseus hath don so faire a grace
But downe on knees when eủer I man wight
And thonkyn hym with all hur herte ⁊and myght
And namely the thebanes faste ofte sith ¶
And thus with good hope and with herte blyth
Thei takith their leue and homward gonne they ride
To thebes the Cite with his wallis wide

div.l: I trow men wolde deme it negligence
Yif I foryete to tellen the dispence
Of Duke theseus that goth so bisily
To makyn vp the listis Rialli
That swich a noble theatre as it was
I dar well sayn in all this world ther nas
The circuyte the aa myle was a boute
Wallid of stou and dichid al withoute
Rounde was the schap in man of compas
Full of degrees the height of sixti pas
That whenne a man was sett on o degre
He lettith nott his felaw nothing to see
Esteward ther stode a gate of marbill white
Westeward right suche anothir in the oposit
And schortly to concludyn swiche a faire place
Was noon in erth as in so litill space
For in the lond ther was no crafty man
That geomotrie or ars metrike can
Ne no portreyour ne keruer of ymages
That theseus ne yaf mete and dring and wages
This theatre to makyn and deuise
And for to don his rite and sacrifise
He Esteward hath vp on the gate a boue
In worschip of venus godesse of loue
Don make an auter and an oratorie
And on the gate westeward in memorie
Of Mars he makid hath ther swiche a nothir
That cost largely of gold a fothir
And northeward in a toret of the walle
Of Alablastre white and rede corall
An oratorie riche for to see ¶ Kyght
In worship of Diane of diane of chastite
Hath theseus don wrought in noble wise
But yit nowe had I for yeten to deuise
The noble keruynge and the portratures
The schap the countenaunce and the fyguris
That weren in thise oratories thre
Fir in the temple of venus maist thou see
Wrought in the walle ful pitous to be hold
The broken slepis and the sikis cold
The salte teres and the waymantyng
The firy strokis of the inge
That loues seruauntes in this lif enduren
The othis al so that hir couenauns assuren
Plesaunce and hope desir folhardinesse
Beaute and youthe bawderie richesse
Charmes and fors lesyngis flaterie
Despence bisinesse and ialousie
That werid of yelwe gooldes a gerland
And a kuokow sitting a bouen on his hand
Festis intrument̉er carolles daunces
Lust and array and al the circumstaunces
Of loue whiche I rekene and rekene schall
Bi ordre weren payntyd ther on the wall
And mo than I can now make of mencioun
For sothe allsothly alsothe all sothly al the mount of citheroun
Ther that venus hath hur pⁱrincipall dwellyng
Was schewid on the wall in portreying
With all the gardyn and the lustinesse
Ne Narcisus the faire of yore agon
Ne yit the foly . of kyng Salamon
Ne yit the grete strength of Ercules
The chauntmentꝭes of Medea and circes
Ne of turnus with the hardy fers corage
The Riche Cresus kaitif in Seruage ¶ Knyght
Thus may ye welle that wisdam nerichesse
Beaute ne sleighte strength hardinesse
Ne may with venus holde chamꝑpartie
For as hur lust the world thanne may sche gie
Lo alle thise folke so caughte wer in hir lace
Till they for wo . ful ofte saide allas
Suffisith her . ensamples . on othir thoo .
And thought I couth reken a thousand mo
The statue of Venus glorious for to see
Was madenakidmade nakid fletynge in the large see
And fro the nauel downe al couerid was
With wawes grene and bright as any glas
A Citole in hir right hand ther had sche
And on hir hed was ful semly for to se
A Rose gerlaund fressh and wel smellyng
By forne hir stode hur soune cupido
Vpon his schuldris wyggis had he tho
For blinde he was hit is ofte sene
A bowe he bare and arwes bright and kene
S Whi schulde I natt as wel telle you alle
The portrature that was vpon the wall
With in the temple of myghty mars the rede
Al paintid was the walle ine length and brede
Like to estres of of the grisly place
That hight the grete temple of mars in tras
In thilke frostyfrosty colde frosty regioun
Ther as mars hathe his soeủeraigne mancioun
First in the wall was payntid a foreste
In whiche ther dwedel dwellith neithir man ne best
With knotty knarry bareyne tres olde ¶ Knyght
Of stublis scharpe and hidous to be holde
In whiche ther ranne a Rombel in a slowe
As thowh a storme schulde bresten eủery bowghe
And dounward fran an hill vndir a bente
Ther stode the temple of Mars armipotente
Wrought all of burnyd stele of whiche the entre
Was longe and streight and gastle for to see
And ther oute com arage and suche a nyea ba vizea nye a b vize
That it made all the gate for to a rise
The northirne light in at the dores schon
For wyndow on the wall ne was ther noon
Thourgh whiche men myght any discerne
The dore was all of Athamaunt eterne
I clenchid ouerthwert and endelong
With yren togh and for to make it stronge
eủery piler the temple to sustene
Was tonne grete of yren bright and schene
Ther saw I first the dirke ymagynyng
Of felony and al the compasing
Of cruell Ire rede as any glede
The pikpurs and eke the pale drede
The smyler with the knyth vndir the cloke
The sleper brennyng with the blake smoke
The tresoun ofof also of morthering in the bed
The opyn werre with woundis all bi bled
Contek with blodi knyf and scharpe manace
All full of chirkyng was that sori place
The sleightir of hym self and yit saw ither
His herte blode hathe bathid al his here
The naile I driuyn in the schode a nyght ¶ Knyght
The colde dethe with mouth gaping vpright
A myddis the Themple satt meschaunce
With grete disconfort and sory countenaunce
¶ I saw wodnesse laugynge in his Rage
Armed compleynt out hees and fers oute rage
The karoyn in the busshe withe throte I corue
A thousande slayne and nat of qualme I storue
The tiraunt with the pray by forse I rafte
The tonne destroied ther was no thing lafte
But saw I brente the schippes hoppesteres
The hunte I stranglid with the wilde beris
The sowe fretyn the childe right in the cradill
The Coke I scaldid for all his longe ladill
¶ Nat was forgetyn by the infortune of marte
The Carter ouer Ridyn with his owne Carte
Vndir the whele full lowe he lay a doune
Ther wer also of martꝭes deuisioun
The Barbour and the Bocher and eke the smyth
That for gith scharpe swerdis o on his stith
And al a boute depeyntid in a tour
Saw I conqueste sittyng in grete honoure
Withe the scharpe swerdesswerdeswerdes oeủere his hede
Hangyng by a subtill twynyd threde
Depaytid was the slaughtur of Iulius
Of grete nere and of Antonyus
All be that thilke tyme they wer vnborne
Yit was hur deth depayntid ther biforne
By mansynge of Mars right by figure
So was it schewid in that portreyture
As is depaintid in the sercles a boue ¶ Knyght
Ho schall be slayn or els ded for loue
Suffiseth on ensaumple in stories olde
I may nott rekene hem al they I wold
The statu of Mars vpon a Carte stode
Armyd and lokyd grym as he wer wode
And oeủer his heed ther schynen tho figuris
Of st̉erres that ben clepid in scⁱpturis
That on Puella . that othir Iubeus
This god of armes was arraied thus
A wolf ther stode by for hym at his fete
With eien rede and of a man he ete
With subtil pensell was departid his storie
In redoutynge of Mars and of his glorie
¶ Now to the Temple of Diane the Chaste
As schortly as I can I wolle me haste
To telle you here al the discripciou
Departid ben the walles vp and doun
Of hontyn and of schame faste chastite
Ther saw I how woful salistepe
Whenne that Diane agreuyd was with hire
Was turnyd fro awoman vntill a bere
And aftur was he made the lode sterre
W Thus was it partid I kan sey you no ferre
Hir sonne is eke a st̉erre as men may see
Ther saw I Dane I turnyd till a tree
I mene nott the godesse Diane
But penne us Doughter which that hight Dade
Ther saw I Attheon an hert ymakid
For vengeaunce that he saw Diane nakid
I saw thou that his houndis haue hym kaught
And freten hym for that they knew hym naught ¶ Knyght
But payntid was ther a litil forther more
How Atthalante huntid the wilde bore
And Meleagre and many othir mo
For whiche Diane wroughte hym care and wo
Ther sawe I many a nothir wondir storie
The whiche me liste nat drawe to memorie
¶ This goddesse on an herte ful heigh sett
With smale houndes al aboute hire fote
And vndir nethe hir fete sche had a mone
Wexing hit was and schulde sone
In gaude grene hir statue clothid was
With bowe in honde and arowes in a cas
Hur eien caste sche ful lowe a doun
Ther Poluto hath his dirke regioun
¶ A woman trauayllyng was hir by forne
But for hir Childe so longe was vnborne
Full pitously lucy ne gan sche to calle
And saide help for thou maist best of all
Well couthe he paynte lifly that he wrought
With many a floryn he the hewis boughte
Now ben thise listes mad and theseus
That at his grete coste arraied he thus
The temples and the theatre eủery dell
Whenne hit don was hym likid wondir well
Butt stynte I wille nowe of theseus a lite
And speke of Palamou and of Arcite
¶ The day aprochith of hur retournyng
That eủeriche schulde an C knyghtꝭes bringe
The Bataile to darrayne as I you tolde
And til Atthenes hir couenaunt for to hold
Hath eủerich of hem brought an C knyghtꝭes
Wel armyd for the werre at alle rightꝭes¶ Knyght
And sikirly ther trowid many a man
That neuer sithen the worlde beganne
As for to speke of knyghthode of hur honde
As fer as god hathe makid see and lond
Nas of so fewe so noble a companye
For eủery wight that louyth chiualrie
And wolde his thankis haue a passaunt name
Hath praied that he myght ben of that game
And welle was hem that ther to chosen was
For yif ther felle to morwe swiche a cas
Ye knowyn well that eủery lusty knyght
That louyth ꝑparamours and hath his myght
Were it in Engelond othir els where
Thei wolde hir thankis willyn to be ther
To fight for a lady benedicite
Hit were a lusty sighte for sothe for to see
¶ And right so ferden they with Palamou
With hym ther wentyn knyghtꝭes many oon
Some wille be armyd in haubergeoun
And in a breste plate and a light gypoun
And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
Som wille ben armyd on his leggis well
And haue an ax in hand and som a mace of stele
Ther nys no newe gise that it nas olde
Armyd wer they as I haue you tolde
eủeriche aftir his opynyoun
Ther maist thou seen comyg with Palamou
Ligurge hym self the grete kyng of trace
Blak was his berde and manly was his face
The cercles of his eyen that weren in his hede
Thei glowdyn by twixte yelwe and rede ¶ Knyght
And like a griffen lokid he a boute
With Crempe heris on his nose and on brewes stoute
His lymes grete his brawnes stoutehardestoute harde and stronge
His scholdres brode his armes rounde and longe
And as the gise was in his cuntre
With foure white Boles ther in the trais
In stede of cote Armure ouer his harneis
He had a beris skynne colblak for olde
With nailis yelwe and bright as any golde
His long here was kembid by hynd his bakke
As any Rauynes fethir hit schon for blak
A writh of gold arin grete of huge weight
Vpon his hede sette ful of stones bright
Of fyne Rubies and Diamauns
A boute his Chare ther wente white Alauns
Xxᵗⁱ and mo as grete as any stere
To hunten at the lyoun and at the deere
And folwyd hym with mosell faste ibounde
Colerd of golde and terettꝭes filid rounde
An hundrid lordis hadde he in his re rowte
Armyd full well with hertis sterne and stoute
¶ With Arcita in stories as men fynde
The grete Emetreus the kynge of ynde
Vpon a stede bay trappid in stele
Couerid in clothe of golde diaprid welle
Com Ridyng like the god of armyd Mars
His Cote armure was of cloth of tars
Couchid with perles white and round and grete
His sadill was of brend gold newe I bete
A mantelet vpon his schulderis hangyng
Brett full of Rubies rede as fire sparkelyng
His crispe here like rīnges I ronne
And that was yelwe and gliderid as the sonne
His nose was highe his eien bright Citryne
His lippis Rounde his colour was sanguyne ¶
A fewe frakenes in his face isprainde
Bi twixe yelwe and somdel blak ymaynde
And as l a lyon he his his lokis caste
Of fyue and twenty yer his age I gessekastegesse kaste
His berde was well by gonne for to springe
His vois was a trumpe right thundringe
Vpon his hede he werid of lawrer grene
A gerlond fressh and lusty for to sene
Vpon his hond he bare for his deduyt
An Egle tame as any lilie white
An C lordes had he with hym there
All armyd saf her hades in all hir gere
b For trustith welle that dukis erles and kynges
a Ful richely in alle maner thinges
Were gaderid in this noble companye
For loue and encres of chiualrie
Aboute this kyng ther ranne on eủery ꝑparte
Ful many a tame lyou and libard
¶ And t in this wise thes lordes all and some
Ben on the sonday . to the Cite come
A Boutyn pⁱrime and in the toune alight
This Theseus this Duke this worthi knyght
Whenne he had brought hem in to his Cite
And Innyd hem eủeriche at his degre
He festeth hem and doth so grete labour
To esen hem and don hem alle honour
That yit men wenyth that no mannes witte
Of noon Estat ne couthe amendyn it
The mynstralcie the seruise and the feste
The grete yiftꝭes to the most and leste
The riche aray of theseus Palais
Ne he satt firste ne last vpon the deis
What ladies fairest ben othir best daunsyng
Ne hoo moste felyngly spekith of loue
What hawkes setten on the perche aboue ¶
What houndis liggen on the flore a downe
Of all this now make I no mencioun
But all the effecte that thinkith me the best
¶ Now comyth the pointe and herkenyth you leste
The sonday nyght er day beganne to springe
Whenne Palamou the larke herde synge
All though hit ner nat day . by oures too
Yit song the larke and Palamou right thoo
With holy herte and with an high corage
He rose to wende v on his pilgımage
Vnto the blissidfull sitherea benygne
I mene venus honourable and digne
And in that oure he walkid forth a pas
But to the listes ther hir temple was
And downe he knelith and with vmble chere
And hert sore he saide as ye schall here
¶ Fairest of faire o lady myn venus
Doughtir to Ioue and spose to vlcanus
Thou glader of mounte of Citheroun
For thilke loue thou haddist for to do a doun
Haue pite of my bittir teres smerte
And take myn vmble praier at thyn herte
¶ Allas I ne haue no langage for to telle
The effecte ne the turmentꝭes of myn helle
My herte may nott myn harmys be wreye
Butt mercy lady bright that knowest welle
Mi thought and seeste welle what harmes that I fele
Considere all this and rewe vpon my sore
As wisly II as I schall for eủere more
Emforth my myght thi trewe seruaunt be
And holdyn werre all wey with Chastite
That make I myn a vowe so ye me helpe
Ne kepe I nat of armes nowe for to ȝelpe
Ne I axe natt o to morwe to haue victorie
Othir pris of armys blowyn vp and doune
But I wolde haue fully possessiou
Of Emelie and die in thi seruise ¶ Knyght
Fynde thou the maner how and in what wise
I reche nat bote hit may bettir be
To haue victorie of hem othir they of me
So that I haue my lady in myn armes
For though that sobe that mars be god of armes
Youre vertue is so grete in heuen abouyn aboue
That yif you liste I schall well haue my loue
¶ Thi temple wole I worschip eủere moo
And on thyn Aucter whethir I ride or goo
I wille don sacrifise and firis bete
