Arcite is colde ther mars his soule gie
Nowe wille I spekyn forth of Emelie
Schrighte Emelie and howlith Palamou
And theseus his sustir toke a non
Swownyng and bar hir frothe Cors awey
What helpith hit to tariyn forth the day .
To tellyn how sche wepe both eue and morwe
For in swiche cas wymmen hauyn swiche sorwe
Whanne that hir housbounde is from hem a goo .
That for the more part the sorwyn soo
Othir els fallyn in swiche maladie
That at the laste certaynly they die
Infinite be the sorwes and teres
Of olde folke and folke of tendre yeris
¶ In al the toune for the deth of this theban
For hym ther wepith both childe and man
So grete a weping was ther non sertayn
Whanne hector . was I brought al fressh I slayne
To troie allas the pite that was there ¶ Knyght
Cracching of chekis rentyng of here
Whi woldist thou be dede this women crie
And haddist golde I nowe and Emelie
¶ No man ne myght gladyn theseus
Sauyng his olde fadir Egeus
That knew this worldes tᵃnsmutacoun
As he had seen hit changid vp and doune
Ioie aftir wo and wo aftir gladnesse
And schewid hym ensamples and likenesse
Right as ther died neủere man quoth he
That he ne lyuyd in erthe in som degre
Right so ther lyuyd neủere man he saide
In all this worlde that som tyme he ne deide
This world nys but a thurghfare ful of wo
And we ben pilgrimes passinge to and fro
Deth is an ende of eủereủeryeủer eủery worldly sore
And oeủere all this yit seide he mochil more
To this effecte ful wisly to enhorte
The peple that þey schulde hem reconforte
¶ Duke theseus with al his bisi cure
Caste now anon wher that the sepulture
Of good arcite may best I makid bee
And eke most honorable in his degre
And at the laste he toke conclusioun
That ther as first Arcite and Palamou
Had for loue the bataile hem betwene
That in the selue groue swete and grene
Ther as he had his amerouse desires
His complaint and for loue his hote firis
He wolde make a fire in whiche the office
Funrall he myght al complice
And lete cōmmaunde anon to hakke and hewe
The okis olde and ley hem a rewe ¶ Knyght
In culpons well araied ther for to brenne
His officers with swifte fete a non gon renne
And ride anon at his cōmmaundement
And aftir this theseus hath I sente
Aftir a bere and hit oeủere spredde
With clothis of golde the richeste that he hadde
And of the same sute he cladde arcite
Up on his handes gloues hadde he white
¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
Ther his sperehis spere seten folke of whiche on bar his schilde
A nothir his spere vpon his hondes held
The thredde bar with hym his bowe turkais
Of brende golde was the cas and eke the harneis
And ridyn forth a pas with sorwfull chere
Toward the groue as ye schull aftur here
¶ The nobleste of the grekis that ther were
Vpon hir schulderes carien the bere
With slakke pas and eien rede and wete
Thourghoute the Cite by the maistir strete
That sprad was al with blak and wondir hie
Right of the same is al the strete I wrie
Vpon the right hande wente olde Egeus
And in that othir side Duke Theseus
With vessels in hir hand of golde full fyne
Al ful of hony mylke blod and wyne
Eke Palamou with ful grete companie
And aftir that com woful Emelie
With fire in hande as was that tyme the gise
To don the office of funerall seruise
Hoge labour and full grete apparailyng ¶ Knyght
Was at the seruise and the fir makyng
That with the grene top the heuyn raught
And twenty fathym of brede the armys straught
¶ This is to sayn the bowes were so brode
Of stre first was ther laide full many a lode
But how the fire was makid vpon an height
Ne eke the names of the trees highte
As oke firi burch aspe alder . holme popeler .
Wilow elue plane assh box chestayn and laurer .
Mapill . thorne beche hasill . yw whityntre
How they were felde schal nat be tolle for me
Ne how thow godes rennen vp and doune
Desherited of hir habitacoun
In whiche thei wonyd in rest and pes
Nymphes phawnes and amadriades
Ne how the bestis and the briddis all .
Fleddyn for fere whenne that the wode was falle
Ne how the grounde a gast was of the light
That was nat wonyd to se no sonne bright
Ne how the fire was couchid firste with stree
And than with smale stikkis clouen ataat thre

hi.hi: And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie

div.l: And than with grene wode and spicerie
And with cloth of golde and with perie
And gerlandes hongyng with full many floure
The myrre the encens that gaf so grete odoure
Ne how arcite lay a mong all this
Ne which richesse a boute his body . is
Ne how that Emely . as was the gise
Put in the fire of funerall . seruise
Ne how sche swonyd whenne sche made the fire
Ne what sche spakke ne what was hir desire
Ne what Iuelles men in the fire tho caste
Whanne that the fire was grete and brente faste
Ne how som cast hir schilde and som hir spere ¶ Knyght
And of hir vestimentis whiche that they were
And cuppes ofof full of wynne and mylke and blode
In to the fire that brent as it were wode
Ne how the grekes with an huge route
Thries riden al the fire a boute
Vpon the lefte hand with a lowde schoutynge
And thries with hir speris claterynge
And thries how the ladies gonne to crie
Ne how that riche wake was I holde
All thilke nyght ne how the grekis pleie
The wake pleyes ne kepe I nat for to seye
Ho wrastelith best nakid with oyle an onoynt
Ne hoo that bar hym best in no disioynt
I will nat tellen eke how that they gon
Hom till Atthenes whenne the pley is don
But schortly to the poynt thanne wolle I wende
And maken of my longe tale an ende
¶ Bi proces and by lengthe of certeyn yeres
All styntid is the mornyng and the teris
Of grekis by on generall assent
Thanne semyd me ther was a parlement
At atthenys vpon certeyn poyntes and cas
A mong the whiche poyntꝭes I spokyn was
To haue with certayn cuntres aliaunce
And haue fully of thebans obeisaunce
For whiche this noble theseus anon
Lete sendyn aftir gentill palamou
Vnwist of hym what was the cause and whi
But in his blake clothis sorwfully .
He cam at his comaundement an hie
Tho sent theseus for emelie
¶ Whenne they were sett and v huyst was al the place
And theseus a bidyn had a space
Er eny worde com from his wise brest
His eien sette he ther was his lest ¶ Knyght
And with a sad visage he sikede stille
And aftirward right s thus he saide his wille
¶ The first moouere of the cause a boue
Whanne he first made the faire cheyne of loue
Gret was the effecte and high was his entente
Welle wiste he whi and what that he ment
For with that faire chaine of loue he bond
The fir the eir the watir and the londe
In certayne boundes that they may I nott flee
That same pⁱrince and that moeuer quod he
Hath stablisshid in this wrechid world adoun
Certayne daies and duracōun
To all that is engendrid in this place
Oeủere the whiche day . they may nat passe
Al mowe they yit tho daies well abregge
Ther nedith non auctorite to legge
For hit is preuyd by exꝑperience
But that me liste declaren my sentense
Thanne may men by this ordre wel discerne
That thilke moeuer . stable is and is et̉erne
AlAl Well may men know butte yif hit be a fole
That eủery parte deryuyth from his hool
For nature hathe nat at his bygynnyng
Of no partie of cantell of a thing
But of athing that ꝑparfit is and stable
Descendyng so til hit be corrumpable
And ther for of his wise puruiaunce
That specie of thinges and progressiouns
Schullen enduren by successiouns
And natt et̉erne with outen any lie
This maistow vndirstande and se at iee
Lo the oke that hath so longe a nurisshing
Fro tyme first it byginyth to springe
And hath so longe a lif ase we may see ¶ Knyght
Yit at the laste wastid is the tree
Considerith eke how that the harde stone
Vndir oure fote on whiche we trede and gon
Yit wastith it as hit lieth by the wey
The brode ryuer . some tyme wexith drie
The grete townes se we wane and wende
Thanne may I wel seyne that all thing hathe ende
Of man and woman sen we well as also
That nedis in oon of thise termes thoo
This is to saien youthe othir els in age
He mote be dede the kyng as schall apage
Some in bedde som in the depe see
Some in the large feld as men may see
Ther helpith nought al goth that ilke way
Thanne may I sayn that il thing mote deie
What makith this but Iubit̉er the kynge
That is principie and cause of all thing
Connectyng al vnto his ꝓpropre wille
From which it is dirivid soth for to telle
And here agaynes no creature of lyue
Of no degre auailith for to striue
¶ Thanne is hit wisdom as hit thinkith me
To makyn vertue of necessite
And take it well that we may not eschew
And nameli that to vs alle is due
And who so grouchith aught he doth folie
And Rebell is to hym that all may gie
And certaynly a man hath most honoure
To dien in his excellence and floure
Whenne he is sikir of his gode name
Thanne hath he don his frende ne hym no schame
And gladder aughte his frende ben of his deth
Whanne with honoure is I yolden vp the breth
Thanne whanne his name appallid is for age
For halfe for geten is his varsalage ¶ Knyght
Thanne is he best as for a worthi fame
To dien whenne that hisishis best of his name
¶ The contrari of all this is wilfulnesse
Whi grucchyn we whi haue we heuynesse
That goode Arcite of chiualrie floure
That partid is with dewete and grete honour
Oute of this foule pⁱrisoun of this lif
Whi grucchith here his cosyn and his wif
Of his wel fare that louyd hym so welle
Came he hem thanke nay god wote neủere a del
That both his sowle and eke hem selue offende
And yit thei mowe hure lustes not amende
What may I conclude of this longe serie
But aftir wo I rede vs to be merie
And thankyn Iubiter of all his grace
And or that we depart fro this place
I rede that we make of sorwes too
O ꝑparfite Ioie lastyng eủere mo
And loketh nowe where most is sorwe is here ynne
Ther wollen we first amendyn and by gynne
¶ Sustir quoth he this is my full assente
With all that here is of my parlement
That gentill Palamou thyn owne knyght
That seruith you with will with hert and myght
And eủere hath don synne that ye first hym knewe
That ye schall of youre grace vpon hym rewe
And take hym here for housbounde o and for lorde
Len me your hond for this oure acorde
Lat se of routherouthe your now womanly pite
He is a kynges brothirs sonne ꝑparde
And though he were a poure bacheler
Syn he hath seruyd you so many a yere
And had for you so grete aduersite
Hit most be considerid leueth me
For gentill mercy oughte to passyn right
Thanne saide he thus to Palamou ful right ¶ Knyght
I trowe ther nede litill sermonyng
To makyn you assentyn to this thing
Com nere and take your lady by the honde
Bi twixte hem tootoo was mad a noon this bonde
That hight matrimoigne othir mariage
Bi al the counsaill and baronage
And thus with blisse and ioie and melodie
Hathe Palamou weddid the lady Emelie
And god that all this wide world hath wrought
Sende hym his loue that hit so dere hath bought
For now is palamou in al his wele
Lyuyng in blisse in richesse and in hele
And Emelie hym louyth so tendirly
And he hir seruith ay so gentilly
That neủere was ther no word hem by twene
Of aa Ialosie othir any othir tene
Thus endith Palamou and Emelie
And god saue all this merie companie Amen
Whenne that the knyght hath thus thehystheys tale I tolde
In al the route nas ther yong ne olde
That he ne saide hit was a noble storie
And worthi for to drawyn to memorie
And namely the gentiles eủerychon
Oure Ooste loughe and swor so mote I gon
This goth a right vnbokelid is the male
Lat se now ho schall telle a nothir tale
For trewly the game is well by gonne
Now tellith ye sir Mounke yif ye conne
Som what to quite with this knyghtꝭes tale
The myller that for dronkyn was al pale
So that vnneth vpon his hors he hat⁊andhat sat
He nold avalyn neythir hod ne hat
Ne a bide no man for his curtesie
But in Pilatus vois . he gann to crie ¶ Knygh
And swore by Armes and bi blod and bones
I kanne a noble tale for the nones
Wh with whiche I wille nowe quite the knyghtꝭes tale
Oure oste sawe well that he was dronke of ale
And saide abide robyn my leue brothir
Some bettir man schall telle vs firste anothir
A bid and late ous wirche thriftily
By godis soule quoth he that wil nat I
For I wil speke othir els go my wey .
Oure oste answerid telle on a deuylwey .
Thou arte afole thi witt is oủer come
Now herkenyth quoththe Miller alle and some
But first I make a protestacoun
That I am drounke I knowe it by my soune
And therfor yif othir myspeke or sey
Wit hit the ale of southwerke I prey
For I wole telle the legende and a lif
Bothe of a carpynter and of his wif
How that the Clerke sette the wrightꝭes tappe .
The Reue answered and said stynt thi clappe .
Lete be thi leude dronken harlatrie
Hit is a synne and eke agrete folye
To apayren any man othir hym defame
And eke to bringe wivis in swiche blame
Thou maist I nowe of othir thinges sayne
This dronkyn Miller spak ful sone agayne
And And saide leue brothir sir Osewolde
Ho hath no wif he is no kekekold
But I say nat ther for that thou art on
Ther bith ful gode wiuys many oon
And eủere a thousand gode a yenes on badde
That knowestow well thi selue but yif tho madde
Whi art thou angry with my tale nowe
I haue a wiffe parde as welle as thou
Yit I wolde I for the oxen in my plough
Taken vpon me more thanne I nowe ¶ Knygh
As demyn of my self that I were on
I wille beleue well that I am noon
An hosebounde schal nat ben inquisitif
Of godis pⁱriuite nothir of his wif
So he may fynden godis foisen there
Of the remenaunt nedith naught enquere
What schulde I more say but this Miller
Ne nolde his wordis for no man for bere
But tolde his cherlisshe tale in his manere
Ne of his thankis . that I schal reherse hit here
And therfor eủery gentill wight I prey .
For goddis loue demeth nat that I sey
Of euyll entente bute I mot reherse
Hir tales all be thei bett̉er or werse
Or els falsen som of my metere
And ther for ho so list hit nat here
Turne ouyr the lef and ches a nothir tale
For he schal fynde I nowe grete and smale
Of storiall thing that touchith gentilesse
And eke moralite and holinesse
Blameth nott me yif that ye chese amysse
The Miller is a Cherle ye knowith wel this .
So was the Reue and othir many moo
And harlotrie they tolde bothe too
Auisith you I put me out of blame
And eke men schal nat make ernest of game
¶ The Millers tale
Whilom ther was dwellyng at oxenforde
A riche gnof that gettestis hilde at borde
And of his crafte he was a Carpynter
With hym ther was dwellyng a poure scoler
And lernyd arte but al his fantasie
Was turnyd for to lerne astrologie
And couthe a certeyn of conclusions ¶Mille
To demyn by interrogacons
Yif that men askid hym in certeyn houris
Whanne that men schulde haue droughte or els schouris
Othir if men askid hym whalt schall bifalle
Of eủery thing I may nott rekene alle
This Clerke was clepid hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he couth and of solas
And ther to he was sligh and ful priue
And like a maydyn thought me to see
A Chaumbre hadde he in that hostelrie
Allone withoutyn any companye
Ful fetisliche I dight with herbis swote
And he hym self as swete as is the rote
Of licoris othir any ceduale
His almageste and bokes grete and smale
His Astrelaby longyng for his arte
His augrym stones layen faire a part
On schelues couchid at his beddis hede
His presse I couerid with a falthing reede
And al aboue ther lay a gay sauterie
On whiche he made on nyghtꝭes melodie
So swetely that all the chambre ronge
And Angelus ad virginem he ofte songe
And aftir that he songe the kynges note
Ful oftyn blissid was his mery throte
And thus this swete clerke his tyme spendte
Aftir his frendis fyndyng and his rente
This Carpynt̉er hadde weddid newe a wif
Whiche that he louyd more than his lif
Of xviij yer sche was of age .
Ialous he was and hilde hir narwe in cage
For sche was wilde and yonge and he was olde
And therfor en his eȝe he was a colde
He knew natt Catou for his witte was rude
That bad man schulde his symylitude ¶Mille
A manne schulde weddyn aftir his estat
For youth and elde is oftyn at debate
But sith that he was fallen in the snare
He moste endure as othir folke his care
Faire was the yonge wif and ther with all
As any wesyll hir body gente and small
A seynte sche werid I barrid all of silke
A barmclothe as white as morne mylke
Vpon hir lendis ful of many agore
White was hir smoke and broidid al by fore
And eke by hynde on hir coler aboute
Of cole bla k silke with in and eke withoute
The tapis of hir white voliper
Were of the same sute of hir coler
Hir filett brode of silke and sett ful hie
And sikerly sche had a licorus yeie
Ful smale I pullid wer hir browes too
And they were bre bente and blake as any slo
Sche was full more blisfull on to see
Thanne is the newe Pere ionette tree
And softer thanne the wolle is of wethir
And by hur gurdill hynge a purse of lethir
Tasselid with grene and perlid with latoun
In all this worlde to seken vp and doune
Ther nys noman so wise that couth thenche
So gay a popelot othir swiche a wenche
Ful bright was the schynyng of hir hewe
Than in the toure the noble I forgid newe
But of hir sounge hit was as loude and ȝ ȝerne
As any swalwe sittyng on a berne
Ther to sche couthe skipe and make a game
As any kid othir calf folwyng his dame
Hir mouth was swete as bragot othir methe
Othir hord of applis leide in her othir heth ¶Miller
Wynsing sche was as is a ioly colte
Longe as a maste and vpright as a bolte
A broche sche bare vpon hir loue coler
As brode as is the bas of a bokeler
Hir schon were lasid on hir legges hie
Sche was a pⁱrimerole a piggis nye
For any lord to leggen in his bedde
Othir yit for any gode yeman to wedde
Now sir and afte sir so by fille the cas
That on a day this hende nycholas .
Fill with this yong wif to rage and pley .
While that hir hosebounde was at oseney .
As clerkis ben ful sotill and ful queynte
And sodenly he take hir by the queynte
And pⁱriuely he caught hir by the queynte
And seide I wisse I wis but yf I haue my wille
For dere loue of the lemman I spille
And wolde haue kiste hir ofte for the nones
And saide lemman loue me now all atones
Othir I will dien al so god me saue
And sche spronge as a colte dothe in the thraue
And with hir hede sche wriyd fast a wey
Sche saide I wille nat kisse the by my fey
Whi late be quoth ich late be Nycholas
Othir I wille crie oute harrow and allas
Do wey your handis for your curtesie
This Nicholas a non gan mercy forto crie
And spak so faire and proferid hir so faste
That sche hir loue hym grauntid at laste
And swere hir othe by seint Thomas of kent
That sche wolle ben at his komaundement
Whanne that sche may hir leysre wel aspie
Myn hosebounde is so full of ialousie
That but ye waite welle and be pⁱriue
I wotte ful well I nam but ded quoth sche
Ye motte be ful derne as in this cas
Nay therof care ye nat quoth nycholas ¶Mille
A Clerke had litherly by sette his tymetyme while
But yif he couthe a Carpynter begile
And thus they ben acordid and I sworne
To waite a tyme as I haue seide be forne
Whanne Nicholas had don this eủerydell
And thakkid hir aboute the lendis welle
He kyssith hir swete and takith his sawtrie
And pleieth fast and makith melodie
Thanne fille hit thus that to the parisch chirche
Cristes owne werkꝭes for to werche
This gode wif wente on an haliday
Hire forhede schon as bright as any day
So was it wasshen when sche lete hir werke
Now was ther of that Chirche a parissh clerke
The whiche that was clepid absolou
Crull was his here and as the gold hit schon
And stroutede as a fanne large and brode
Ful stright and euen lay his ioly schode
His rode was rede . his eyen gray as glasseglasse goos
With Poules wyndow coruyn on his schois
In hoses rede rede he wente fetisly
I clad he was ful smal and proprely
Al in a Cirtill of a light waget
Full faire and thikke bēn the poyntes sett
And ther vpon he had a gay surplis
As white as is the blosme upon the ris
A myrie childe he was so god me saue
Well couthe he latyn blode and clippe and schaue
And make Chartre of londe and acquitaunce
In xxᵗⁱ man couthe trip and daunce
Aftir the scole of oxenforde tho
And with his leggis castyn to and fro
And pleien songes on a smal ribible
Ther to he songe som tyme a loude quinyble ¶Mille
And as welle couthe he pleyen on his giterne
In all the toune ther nas brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne visitide with his solas
Ther any gailard tapuster was
But soth to sayn he was somdel scoymus
Of fartyng and of spech daungerus
This absolou that iolif was and gay
Goth with a senser on the haliday
Sensing the wyuys of the parisshe faste
And many alouely loke on hem he caste
And namely on this carpynters wif
To loke on hir hym thought a mery lif
Sche was so propre and swete and likerus
Wer he catte he wold hir hente anon
This parissh clerke this iolif absolou
Hath in his herte swiche a loue longyng
That of no wif ne toke he no offring
For curtesie he saide he wolde non
The mone whan hit was nyght ful bright schone
And absolou his giterne hadde I take
For Paramours he thought for to wake
And forthe he gothe iolif and amerous
Till he com to the Carpynters hous
A litill aftir cokkes had I crowe
And dressid hym vp by a shot wyndowe
That was vpon the Carpinters walle
He syngith in his vois gentil and small
Now dere lady yif thi will be
I pray you that ye wille thynken or on me
Full welle acordaunt to his giternynge
This Carpynter a woke and herd hym syng
And spak vnto his wif and saide anon
What Alisoun herestou nat absolou
That chaunteth thus vndir oure boures walle
And sche answerid hir hosebounde ther with alle

l.hi: This passith forth what wolle ye bett than well

div.l: Yis god wote ion I here it eủerydell
This passith forthe what wole bet thanne welle
Fro day to day this iolif absolou
So wowith hir that hym is wo by gon
He wakith al the nyght and al the day
He kembith his lokkis brode and made hym gay
He wowith hir by menes and by brokage
And swore he wolde ben hir owne page
He syngith brokkyng as a nyghtyngale
He sente hir pyment moch and spiced ale
And wafrus pipyng hote oute of the glede
And for sche was of toune he proferid mede
For som folke wolen ben wonnen with richesse
And som for strokis and som for gentilnesse
Som tyme to schewe his lightnesse and maistrie
He pleieth heroudes vpon a scaffold hie
But what availith hym in this cas
Sche louyth so this hende Nicholas
That absolou may blowe the bukkes horne

div.l: And thann schull we be lordis all oure lyf

But of o thing I warne the ful right

For that by twixte you schall be no synne

Pypyn he couthe and fisshe and nettis bete
And turne Cuppis and well wrestill and schete
Ay by his belte he bare longe panade
And of a swerde ful trenchaunt was the blade
A ioly popper bare he in his pouche
The nas man for perill that durst hym touche
A shefilde twitle bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face and kamois was his nose
As pillid as and ape was his skulle
He was market betere at the full
Ther durst no wight hand upon hym legge
That he ne swore a none he schulde a begge
A thef he was for sothe of corne and mele
And that a shigh and vsaunt for to stele
His name was hote deynose Symekyn
A wif he had comen of noble kynne
The persoun of the toune hir fadir was
With hir he yaf full many panne of bras
For that Symkyn scholde in his blode a lie
Sche was I fostred in a nonnerie
For Symkyn wolde no wif as he seide
But sche wer wel I norisshid and a maide
To saue his state of yemanrie
And he was proude and perte as any pie
A ful faire sight was hit vpon hem thoo
On halidaies to fore hir wolde he goo
With his typett bounden a boute his de de hede
And sche cam aftir in gite of rede
And Symkyn had hosyn of the sam
Ther durste no wight clepe hir bote dame
Was non so hardy that wente by the way
That with hir ones durst rage or play
But yif he wold be slayn of Symkyn
With panade othir with knyf othir boidekyn
For gelous folke ben ꝑperilous eueremo
Al agatꝭes thei wold hir wyues wenden soo
And eke for sche was somwhat smoterlich
Sche was digne as watir in a diche
As ful full of hokir and bisemare
Hur͗e thought that a lady schulde hir spare
What for hir kynrede and nortelry
That sche had lerned in the nonnery
A doughtir had they by twixen hem thoo
Of xxᵗⁱ yer olde withoutyn any moo
Sauyng a childe that was of half yere olde olde age
In cradill hit lay hit was a propre page
This wenche thikke and well I growyn was
With camus nose and eien gray as glas
With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hie
But right faire was hir here I wille nott lie
The ꝑpersoun of this toun for sche was so faire
In purpos was to makyn hir his eir͗e
Bothe of katell and of his mesuage
And straunge he made hit of hir mariage

div.l: In to som worthi blod of Auncetrie
For holy chirches goode mot be dispendid
On holy chirches blode that is discendid
Ther for he wolde his holy blode honoure
Though that he holy chirche schulde deuoure
¶ Grete sokne hath this Miller withoutyn doute
With s s whete and malte in al the land a boute
And nameliche ther was agrete college
Men clepith the soler halle of canttebrigge
Ther was hir whete and eke hir malte I grounde
And on a day hit happid in a stounde
Sike lay the Maunciple on a maladie
Men wyntyn that he schulde diee
For whiche the myller stal mele and corne
Am Am An hundrid tyme more thanne by forne
For ther by forne he stale curtaisl
But now he was a thef outeragesly
For whiche the wardeyn chid and made fare
But ther of sette the Myller nought a tare
He Crakyd bost and swore hit nas nat soo
Thanne were there yone yone ȝunge pore clerkes too
That dwellyn dwellyn dweldyn in this hal whiche that I seie
Testif they were and lusty for to pleye
And only for hir myrth and reuerie
Vpon the wardeyn bisily they crie
To yiue hem leue bote a litil stounde
To gon to mylle and sen hir corne I grounde
And hardily thei durst leye hur nekke
The meller schulde nat stele hem a pekke
Of corne by sleyght ne be sighte hem reue
And att the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn hight that on and Aleyn hight that othir
Of on toune they were borne that hight strothir
For in the North I canne nat telle where
This Aleyn makith redy all his gere
And on an hors his sak he cast anon
Forthe goth Aleyn the Clerke and also Iohn
With gode swerde and bokeler girte by his side
Iohn knewe the wey hym nedid no gide
And at the mylle the sak a doun he leith
Aleyn spak first al haile Symounde he saith
How faris thi faire dought̉er and also thi wif
Aleyn wel com quoth Symkyn by my lif
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
Symound quoth Iohn by god nede hath no pere
He muste serue hym selfe that hath no swayn
Or els he is fole as Clerkis sayn
Sir oure maunsiple I hope he will be dede
So warkis ay the wangis in his hede
And ther for am I come and eke aleyn
To grynde oure corne and carie hit hom ageyn
I pray you sped ous hethen what ye may
Hit schall be done quoth Symkyn a non by my fay
What wolde ye done while hit is an honde
Bi god by the hopir right wole I stande
Quoth Iohn and se the corn how hit gos in
Yit saw I neuere by my fadir kynne
How that the hopir waggith to and fro
Aleyn answered and saide wilt thou so
Thanne wille I ben by nethe by my croun
And se how that the mele falles a doun
In to the trough that schal be my disporte
For Iohn in faith I may be of youre sorte
I am as yuyll myller as ar ye
This Miller smylid of hir nycete
And though all this nys don but for wile
Thei wene that no man may hem by gile
But by my thrifte yit schal I blere hir yeie
For all the sleight of hir philosophie
The mo queynte crekis that they make
The more wole I stele whanne I take
In stede of floure yit wol I yeue hem bren
The grettest clerkis buth nat wiseste men
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of al hir Arte counte I nought a tare
¶ Out at the dore he gothe ful preuely
Whenne that he sawe his tyme softely
He lokith vp and doune til he hath founde
The clerkis hors ther as it stode I bounde
By hynde the mylle vndir a leuesell
And to the hors he hym goth faire and welle
He strepith of the bridill right a non
And whanne the hors was laws he gynnyth to gon
Toward the fenne there wilde maris renne
And forth with we he thorw thikke and thourgh thynne
This Mileward cometh a gayn no worde he saide
Butt doth his note and with the Clerkis pleide
Til that hir corne was faire and wel I grounde
And whenne hure mele is sakkid and I bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fidith his hors a way
And ganne to crie harow and weleaway
Oure hors Aley Aley is lost Aleyn for goddis bones
Step on thi fete com oute man al attones
Allas our wardeyn hath his palfrey lorne
This Aleyn al for gate bothe mele and corne
Al was oute of his mynde his housbondrie
What whilke way is he gon gan he to crie
The wif com lepyng inward with a renne
Sche saide allas your hors goth to the fenne
With wilde Maris as fast as he may goo
Vnthanke com on his hand that bound hym so
And he that bett̉er schuld haue knytte the Reyne
Allas quoth Iohn Aleyn for Cristis peyne
Ley doune thi swerde and I will myn also
I is ful wight god wot as is a Roo
Bi godis hert he schall nat scape vs bath
Why ne had thou put the capill in the lathe
Yl haile Aleyn by god thou is a fonne
Thise sely Clerkis han full fast I ronne
Toward the fenne both Aleyn and eke Iohn
And when the Miller sigh that they were gon
He half a buschel of hir floure hathe take
And bad his wif go knede hit in a cake
He saide I trow the Clerkis were a ferd
Yit can a Miller make a clerkis berd
For al his arte now lat hym gon his way
Loo where he goth no lat the childryn play
They gete hym nott so lightly by my croune
Thise sely clerkꝭes rennyn vp and downe
With kepe stande gossa ware derere
So wif So wif Ga wightly thou and I schall kepe hym here
But schortly till that it was verrey nyght
They koude nat trewly with all hir myght
Hir Capill cache he ranne all wey so faste
Til in a diche they caught hym at laste
Wery and wete as bee is in the reyne
Comyth sely Iohn and with hym comyth Aleyn
Allas quoth Iohn the day that I was borne
Nowe are we drivyn tyl hethyn and to scorne
Oure corne is stole men wol vs foles calle
Bothe the wardeyn and oure felaus alle
And namly the Myller wellawey
Thus playnyth Iohn as he goth be the way
To warde the Mille and Baiard in his hande
The Miller sittyng by the fire he fande
For hit was nyght and ferther myght they nought
But for the loue of god they hym by sought
Of harboure and of ease for hir peny
The Miller seide a gayne if ther be any
Swiche as it is ye schul haue youre parte
My hous is straight but ye haue lernyd arte
Ye canne by Argumentꝭes makyn a plac
A myle brode of xxᵗⁱ fote of space
Lat see nowe yif this place may suffise
Othir make hit rowm with speche as is your gise
¶ Now Symond saide this iohn by saint cuthberd
As is thou merie and that is faire answerid
I haie hauehaiehaue herde sey men schal take of too thinges
Swilke as he fyndes othir take swilke as he brynges
But specially I pray the oste dere
Get vs som mete and drinke and make vs chere
And we wollyn pay trewly at the full
With empty hande men may non hauke tolle
Lo here oure siluer redy for to spende
This Miller in to the toune his doughtir sende
For ale and brede and rostid hem a goos
And bonde hir hors hit scholde no more go loos
And in his owne chambre hem made a bedde
With schetꝭes and with Chalones faire I spredde
Nought fro his owene bed x fote othir twelue
His doughtir had a bedd al by hir selue
Right in the same chaumbre by and by
Hit myght be no bette for cause whi
Ther was no rowmer herboure in the place
Thei soupen and thei speken hem to solas
And drinkyn euer strong ala at the beste
A boute myd nyght wente thei to reste
Well hath this myller vernysshid his hede
Ful pale he was for drounken and nought rede
He yukshet and he spekith thurgh his nose
As he were on the quakke othir on the pose
To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wif
As any iay sche light was and iolif
So was hir ioly whistle well I wett
The cradill at hur beddis fette is sett
To Rokken and to yiue the childe to sowke
And whenne that drunken al was in the crowke
To bedde wente the doughtir right anon
To bedde goth Aleyn and also Iohn
Ther ne was namore hem nede no dwale
This Miller hath so wisly bibbid ale
That as an hound snortith in his slepe
Ne of his taile be hynde he toke no kepe
His wif bare hym a bordoun ful strong
Men myght here hire routyng tho furlong
The wenche routith eke par companye
Aleyn the clerke that herd this melodie
He pokid Iohn and saide slepestetoweslepestetoweslepestetow
Herdist thou eủere swiche a song er nowe
Lo swiche a couplyng is by twixte hem all
A wilde fire I pray on hir bodies falle
Ho herde euer swilke a ferly thinge
He they schall haue the floure of euyl endyng
This long nyght ne tidith me no reste
But yit no forse al schall be for the best
For Iohn saide he as eủere mote I thriue
Yif that I may yon wenche wille I swiue
Som esement has lawe I schapyn vs
For iohn ther is a lawe that sayth thus
That yif a man in o point fore be agreuyd
That in a nothir he schal be releuyd
Oure corne is I stole sothely hit is no may may nay
And we han an ille fitte all this day
And synne I schall haue non othir amendement
A gayn my losse I wol haue esement
Bi godis sowle hit schal non othir bee
This ihon Iohnihon Iohn answerid aleyn avise the
The Miller is for sothe a perilous man he saide
And yif that he out of his slepe
Til he so nygh was er sche myght a spie
That hit hadde ben to late for to crie
And schortly for to seie they were a ton
Now playn playplayn play Aleyn for I wolle speke of iohn
¶ This Iohn lieth stille a forlong wey or too
And to hym self he makith rewthe and woo
Allas quoth hee this is a wikkid iape
Now may I sayn that I is but and anandan ape
Yit hath my felaw somwhat for his harme
He hath the Myllers doughtir in his arme
He Aunteride hym and hath his nedis spedd
And I le le lie as a draf sak here in my bedde
And whenne this iape is tolde an nothir day
I schall be holde a daffe and a kokenay
I wolle a rise and auntre hit by my faith
Vnhardy is vnseli thus men saith
And vp he ros and softly he wente
And bar And bar But to the Cradill and in his hond hit hente
And bar hit softe vnto his beddis fete
Sone aftir this wif hir routyng let
And com a gayn And com a gayn And gan a wake and went hir oute to pisse
And com agayn and gan the Cradill mysse
And gropid here and ther but sche fond noon
Allas quoth sche I had al most mysgon
I had al most gon to the Clerkis bed
Ey benedicite thanne hadde I foule spedd
And forthe sche goth til sche the Cradil fond
Sche gropith all wey forthere with hir hond
And fond the bed and thought nought but god
Bi cause that the Cradill bi hit stode
And ne wist wher sche was for hit was dirke
But faire and wele sche crep in b b to the clerke
And lith full stille and wolde haue caught a slepe
With in a while Iohn the Clerke vp lepe
And on this gode wif he leyth on so sore
So merie a fitte ne had sche nought ful yore
He prikith harde and depe as he wer mad
This ioly lif han thise ij Clerkis ledde
Till that the thridde koc by gan to synge
Aleyn wex wery in the dawnyng
For he had swonkyn al the longe nyght
And saide fare well malyne swete wight
The day is comen I may no lenger bide
But eủere mo wher so I go othir ride
I am thyn awne clerke so haue I sele
Now dere lemman quoth sche fare right well
But or thou goo o thing I wille the telle
Whenne thou goste homward by the mylle
Right at the entre of the dore by hynde
Thou schalt a kake of half a buschel fynde
That was I makid of thyn owne mele
Which that I help my self for to stele
And gode lemman god the saue and kepe
And with that worde al moste sche ganne to wepe
Aleyn vp rist and thought or hit dawe
I wille go crepen in by my felawe
And fonde the Cradill with his hand anon
Bi god thought hee al wrong I haue mysgon
Myn hede is toty of my swynke to nyght
That makith me that I go nat a right
I wott well by the Cradill I haue mys go
Here lithe the myller and his wif also
And forth he goth on twenty deuelwa
Vnto the bed ther as the myller lay
He wend haue cropyn in by his felaw Iohn
And by the Miller in he crepte anon
And caught hym by the nekke and softe he spake
He saide thou Iohn thou swynys hede a wake
For cristes sowle and her a noble game
For by that lord that callid is seinte iame
As h h I haue thries in this schorte nyght
Swyuyd the Milleres doughtir bolt vp right
While thou ase a coward hast ben agast
Ye false harlot quoth the Miller hast
Thou schalte be dede bi goddis dignite
How dorste thou be so bolde to disꝑparage
My doughtir that is come of sowch lynage
And by the throte bolle he caught alayn
And he hente hym dispitously agayn
And on the nose he smot hym with his fist
Doun Ranne the blody strem vpon his breste
And in the flore with nose and mouth to broke
They walwe as don the piggis in a poke
And vp they gon and doun agayn a non
Til that the Miller spurnyd at a ston
And doun he fille bakward on his wif
That wist nothing of this nyce strife
For sche was falle a slepe a litill wight
With Iohn the clerke that wakyd had al nyght
And with the fall oute of hir slepe sche breide
Helpe holy crosse of bromholm sche seide
In manus tuas to the lord I calle
A wake Symonde the fende is on me fall
Myn herte is brokyn help I nam but ded
Ther lith on my wombe and on myn hed
Help Symkyn now / the false clerkis fight
This Iohn starte up as faste as eủere he myght
And graspith by the wallis to and froo
To fynde a staf and sche stirte vp also
And knew the estres bet than did Iohn
And by the walle a staffe sche fond a non
And sawe a litill schymeryng of a light
For at an hole in schone the mone bright
And bi that light sche saw hem bothe too
But sikirly sche ne wist who was hoo
But as sche sawe a whit thing in hir iȝ
And whanne sche ganne this white thing aspie
Sche wente the Clerke had werid a voluper
And with the staff sche drow ay nere and nere
And wente had hitte this Aleyn at the fulle
And smote the Miller on the pelid skulle
That downe he goth and cride harowe I die
And And This Clerkis bete hym welle and lete hym lie
And greythengrethengreythen hem and toke hir hors a noon
And eke hir mele and on hir wey they gon
And atte the Mille dore they toke hir kake
Of half a buschell floure ful well I bake
Thus is the proude Miller welle I bete
And hath lost the grindyng of the whete
And paide for the soper eủerydelle
Of Aleyn and of Iohn that bete hym well
His wiff was dight and his doughtir als
Loo souche it is a Miller to be fals
And therfor this proủerbe is seide ful soth
Hym thare well wene that evill dothe
A gilour schal hym silf begilid be
God that sittith high in mageste
Saue all this cumpanye grete and smale
Thus haue I quite the Miller his tale
The Coke of London while the Reue spake
For ioy hym thought he clawid hym on his bakke
Ha ha qduod he for Cristis passion
The Miller hath a scharpe conclusion
Vpon his argument of herbigage
Welle saide Salamon in his language
Bringe nought eủery man to thyne hous
For herbering be nyght is ꝑperilous
Welle ought a man avisid for to be
Whom that he brought in to his pⁱriuit
I pray to god so yeue me sorwe and care
If eủere sethe I hight ogge of ware
Herd I myller better sett on werke
He had a Iape of malice in the dirke
And ther fore if ya vouche saue to here
But god forbede that we stynte here
A tale of me that am a pore man
I wille you telle as well as eủery kan
A litill iape that fel in yoᵘur Cite
Houre hoste answerid I graunte that the
Now tell on Roger loke that hit be gode
¶ For many a pasty hast thou letyn blode
And many a Iacke of Douer hast thou solde
That hath ben twis hote and twis and colde
Of many a Pilgrime hast thou cristis curs
For of thi parcely yit fare I the wors a later hand has added "th" intralinearly to "For."
That they haue etyn with the stubbid gose
Fo in thi schop is many a flie lose
Nowe telle on Roger be thi name
But yit I pray the be nott wrothe for game
A man may sey ful sothe in game and pley
Thou seis ful sothe Roger be my fey
But sothe pley quade pley as the flemyng seith
And therfor harry balife be thi feithe
Be thou nought wrothe er we deꝑpartyn here
Thowe that my tale be of an ostelere
But natheles I wille nott telle it yit
But er we departe thou schall be quit
And ther with all he lough and made chere
And seide his prologe in this manere
A prentise whilom duellid in hour cite
And of crafte of vitaileris was he
Gailarde he was as goldfynche in the schawe
Broune as bery a proꝑper schort felaw
With lokkis blake kempte full fetisly
Daunce he cowde so welle and Iolily
That he was clepid Perkyn Reuelour͗e
He was ful of loue and ꝑparamour͗e
As is the hive full of hony swete
Welle was the wenche that with hym myght mete
Atte eủery brideale wolde he singe and hoppe
He louyd bettir Tauerne thanne the schoppe
For whan there eny ridyngꝭe was in chepe
Oute of the schoppe thedir wolde lepe
Tyll that he alle the sight had sein
And daunce welle he wolde and nought com ageyn
And gaderid a meyne of his sorte
To hop̄pe and singe and make suiche desporte
And there thei set set steuene for to mete
And pleyen atte the Dise in suiche a strete
For in that toune was ther no prentise
That fairer cowde cast a paire of Dice
Than Parkyn cowde and ther to he was fre
Of his Dispence in place of p̉reuite
That founde his maister welle in his chaffare
For oftyn tyme he fonde his box al bare
For sikirly a prentise reueloure
That hauntith Dice riotte or ꝑparamour͗e
His maistir schal hit in his schop̄pe a bie
Alle haue he no parte of the mynstralsie
For thefte and Riotte thei ben conuertible
Alle kan he pley in geterne or rubible
Reuell and treuthe as in a lowe degre
Thei ben full wroth all Day as men may see
This ioilif prentise with his maistir bode
Tille he were oute of his prentise hode
Alle were he snybbid bothe erly and lat
And sum tyme lad with Reuell to Newgate
And at the laste laste his maister hym be thought "laste" added in left margin.
Vpon a day whanne his paper sought
Of a prouerbe that seithe this same worde
Welle bettir is a roten appill oute of horde
Thanne hit rote all the remenaunt
So farith hit bi a riotous seruaunt
Hit is lasse harme tolete hym parte ⁊and trye his gre⁊and trye his gre
Thanne he schende alle the seruᵃauntis in a place
Ther for his maister yaue hym acquitaunce
And bad hym go with sorwe and myschaunce
And thus this iolif prentice had his leue
Nowe late hym riote alle the nyght or leue
And for ther is no thef withoute a louke
That he helpith hym to wast and to souke
Of that he bribe kan or borwebrwe borwe may
A non he sente his bed and his aray
Vnto his compere of his own sorte
That louyd dise and reuel and disporte
And had a wif that held for cuntenaunce
A schop and swiue for hir coisutenaunce sustinaunce coisutenaunce sustinaunce

div.l: Lith and lestenyth and herkenyth a right
And ye schullen here of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn of Bovndes was his name
He koude of norture and moche of game
Thre sonnes the knyght hadde and with his body he he wan
The Eldest was a moche schrewe and sone be gann
This bretheryn louyd well hir Fadir and of hy were agaste
The eldeste disseruyd his Fadres curs and had hit at the laste
The goode knyght his Fadir leued so yore
That dethe was come hym to and handlid hym ful sore
The gode knyght karid sore seke ther he lay
How his Children schulde leuen aftir his day
He had ben wide where but none housbonde he was
Alle the londe that he hadde it was verrey purchas
Fayne he wolde it were dressid a monge hem alle
That iche of hem had his parte as hit myght falle
Tho sente he to his cuntre aftir wise knyghtꝭes
To helpyn Delyn his londe and dressyn hym to rightꝭes
He sente hem be worde be lres they schulden highe bliue
Yif thei wolde speke with hym while he was a lyue
Tho the knyghtꝭes herden seke that he lay
Had they no reste neithir nyght ne day
Till they com to hym ther he lay stille
On his Deth bedde to abide goddis wille
Thanne saide the gode knyght seke ther he lay
Lordis I you warne for sothe with oute any saynayany say nay
I may no lenger leuen here in this stounde
For thourgh godis wille dethe drawith men g to grounde
Ther nas noon of hem alle that herde hym a right
That they ne had reuthe of that ilke knyght
And saide for godis loue ne dismay you nought
God may do bote of bale that is now I wrought
Thanne spak the gode knyght sike ther he lay
Bote of Bale god may send I wotte hit is no nay
But I beseke you knyghtꝭes for the loue of me
Goth and dressith my londis aaa monge my sonnes thre
And for the loue of god delith hem nought a mysse
And for gete nought Gamelyn my yongeste sonne that is ¶

but atte the laste with mochill kare and wo
we felle acordid be twene oure selfe too
he yaf me all the bridill in my honde
and of his tounge and his hande also
and made hym brenne his boke and right tho
and whann I had I goten vnto me
be maistrie all the soủeraignete
atte which boke he lowe all wey full faste
and eke ther was somtyme a clerke in Ronne
a Clerke Cardenall that hight seint Ierome
that mad aboke a geyn Iouynian
In whiche boke eke ther was terkulan
Cricippus Trocula and Helewis .
that was abbes nought ferre fro ꝐParis
and eke the ꝑparablis of Salamon
Ovides art and bokis manyon
and al thise were boundyn in oon volyme
and eủery nyght and day was his custome
whanne he had leisir and vacacou
from othir worldly occupacioun
to redyn on this boke of wikkid wivis
he knewe of hem mo legendis and lyues
thanne ben of goode wivis in the bible
for tristith welle hit is inpossible
that eny Clerke wille speke goode of wifis
But yif hit be of holy seintꝭes lyues
ne of noone othir womman neủere the mo
who payntid the lyon telle me whoo
Be god yif wommen had writyn storijs
as Ch Clerkis kanne with inne hir horatorijs
thei wolde haue writen of men more wikkidnesse .
thanne alle the marke of adam may redresse
the childryn of mercurie and venus .
byn in hir wirking contrarius
and venus louyth Riot and dispence
and for hir diủerse disposicioun
Eche fallith in othir exaltacioun
as thus god wote mercurie is desolate
In pisces . wher venus . is exaltate
and venus fallith the Mercurie is reisid
ther for no woman of no man is . preisid
the Clerke whanne he is olde and may nought do
of venus werkis . worth his olde scho
thanne sittith he doune and writith in his dotage
that women kone nought kepe hir mariage
But nowe to purpos whi I tolde the
that I was betyn for a loke ꝑparde
vpon a nyght Iankyn that was oure sir
Redde on a boke as he satte bi the fire
of Eua first that for hir wikkidnesse
was al man kynde brought to wrechidnesse
tho redde he mo how Sampson leste his heris
Sleping his lemman kitte with hir sheris .
thorow whiche tresoun loste he bothe his eien .
tho Redde he me yif that I schall nott lien
of Erkules and of his Diamyre
that causid hym to sette hymselfe afire
no thing for gate he the penaunce and wo
that socrates . hadd with his wivis too
howe that ancipa . caste pisse on his hede
this sely man satte stille as he were dede
he wipid his hede . no more durste he saine
aftir thundir dynte comyth reyne
of Phasyua . that was the quene of greke
for shrewidnesse hym thought tale swete
fy speke no more hit is a gisly thinge
of hir horrible luste and hir likyng
of Clitermistra for hir lecherie
that falsly made hir housbond for to die
he redith with welle gode deuociou
he tolde me for what occasion
amphiorax at thebes loste his life
Mi housbande had a legende of his lif wif
Eriphalem that for an nowche of golde hath puyly
hath pⁱriuily vnto the grekis tolde
wher that hir housbond hid hym in a place
for whiche he hadde atte Thebes sory gce
of lyuia tolde he me and of lucie
thei bothe made hir housbondis for to die
thanne he saide myn owne treu wif
do as thou liste terme of thi lif
kepe thyn hous and kepe in eke myn astate
aftir that day had we neủere debate
god helpe me so as I was to hym as so kynde
as any wif from denmarke vnto ynde
and also treue and so was he to me
I pray to god that sittith in mageste .
so blisse his soule for his mercy dere
nowe wille I say my tale yif ye wille here
The Frere lough whan he had herd al this .
nowe dame qd he so haue I ioie or blisse
this is a longe ꝑparable of a tale
and whanne the somnoure herde the frere gale
loo qd the somnoure godis armes too .
a frere wille ent̉remete hym eủere moo
lo goode men a flie and eke a frere
wille fall falle in eủery mannys dish and matere
what spekist thou of pambulaciou
what amble or trotte or pees or go sitte a doune
thou lettiste oure disporte in this manere
ye walke thou somnoure qd the frere
now by my faith I schall . or that I goo .
telle of a somnoure suche atale or too .
that alle folke schulle laughen in this place
now els frere I be shrewe thi face
qd this somnoure and I be shrewe me
but I telle the talis too or thre
of Freres or I com to Sytynbourne
that I schalle make thyn herte to morne
for I welle I wotte thi pacience is agon
f Oure hoste criyd pes and that anon
and saide late the woman telle hir tale
ye faren as folke that dronkyn ben of ale
nowe dame telle forth your tale and that is best
and that is beste al redy sir qd she right as you leste
yf I haue licence of this worthi frer
yis dame qd he telle forthe thi tale I wille here .
IN the olde daies of the kyng Arthure
Of whiche that bretonnes speke grete honour
Alle was this lande fulfillid of fairie
The Elfe quene with hir Ioly companye
Dauncid withoute in many grene mede
This was the olde opynyou as rede
I speke of many an yere a goo
But nowe canne no man se noo Elues moo
For nowe the grete charite and praiers
Of lymytours and othir pore freres
As thikke as any motis in the sonne beme
That sergyn eủery land and eủery streme
As thikke as any motꝭes in the sonne beme
Blissing halles Chaumbris bouris
Cottes burghis Castels and hie toures
Thropis vernes shepens dayries
This makith ther ben no fairies
For ther as wonte was an Elfe
Ther walkith nowe the lymytour hym selfe
In ondir meles and in mornyngis
And saith his matyns and his holy thingis
As he goth in his lymytacoue
Woman may goo nowe saffely vp and doune
Vndir eủery bussh and eủery tree
Ther is non Inkub⁊andz; but hee
And he wille do hem but dishonour
And so fille hit that this kynge Arthure
Had in his hous a lusty bacherer
That on day cam ridyng fro reuere ¶ Bath
And happid a lone as she was born
He sawe a maidyn walkyng hym beforne
Of whiche maide maugre hir hede
Be verray fors he rafte hir maidenhode
For whiche oppressiou was suche clamour
And suche pursute to kynge arthure
That dampnyd was this knyght to be dede
Be cours of lawe he schulde haue loste his hede
ꝑparauenture sweche was the statute thoo
But the quene and othir ladies moo
So longe preied thei the kynge of grace
Till he his lif hym grauntid in the place
And yaf hym grace to the quene al at hir wille
To chese whethir she wolde hym saue or spille
The quene thankid the kynge with all hir myght
And aftir this thus spake she to the knyght
Whanne that she say hir tyme on a daye
Thou stondiste yit qd she in suche araye
That of thi life yit sese hasthou no suerte
I graunte the lif if thou can telle me
What thing is that that women most desiryn
Be ware and kepe thi nekke bone from yren
And yif thou kanste noughte telle hit me anoon
Yit wille I gif the leue for to gon
A twelfe month and a day to seke and lere
An answere suffissaunt in this matere
And surte wille I haue or that thou passe
Thi body for to yeldyn in this place
Wo was this knyght and sorfully sightesikithsighte sikith
But whatt he may nott doo as hym likith
And atte the laste he chesym for to wende ¶ Bathe
And cam a geyn yit att the yeris ende
With swiche answere as god wolde for hym puruey
He sekith eủery hous and eủery place
Wher as he hopith for to fynde gᵃce
To lerne what thinge women louyn moste
But he ne coude a riven in no coste
Wher as he myght fynde in this matere
To creatures acording in fere
Some seiden that women loue moste richesse
Some saide honoure some saide Iolinesse
Some Riche aray some saide luste l a bedde
And oftyntyme to be wedewe and wedde
Some sayde that we be moste I esid
Whanne that we be I fleterid and plesid
He goth full nygh the soth I wille nought lie
A man shall wynne vs beste with fleterie
And with attendaunce and with besinesse
Be we I lymyd bothe more and lasse
And some sayn that we louen beste
For to be free and do that as vs liste
And that no man pʳue vs of oure visvicevis vice
But say that we be wise and nothing nyce
For treuly ther is non of vs alle
Yif any wight wille clawe us on the galle
That we nylle loke for he saith us sothe
A say hit he shall fynde hit that hit doth
For be we neủere so vicious with inne
We wille be holdyn wise and clene of synne
And some me sayn that grete delite haue we
For to be holde stable and eke sekree
And in o purpos stedfastly to dwelle
And nought be wrey thinge that men vs telle ¶ Bathe
But that tale is nought worth a rake stele
ꝑparde we women konne no thinge hele
Wittenesse of Mida wille ye here the tale
Ouyde a monge othir thingis smale
Faith Mida hadde vndir his longe heres
Growyng vp his hede too asses eres
The whiche vice he hid as longe as he myght
Ful sotilly from eủery mannys sight
But saue his wif ther wist of hit no moo
He louyd hir moste and trustid to hir also
He preied hir moste that vnto no creature
She shulde nought telle of his disfugure
She swore hym nay for alle this worlde to wynne
She wolde do that vylanye or synne
To make hir housbonde haue so foule a name
For repuyng of hem and foule shame
But natheles she thought that she deede
That she so longe a counseille shuld hide
Here thought hit satte so sore a boute hir herte
That nedely some worde mote a sterte
And sith she durste telle it no mane
Doune to a maris fast she ranne
Tille she cam ther her herte was afire
And as a betore bomblith in the myre
She laide hir mouthe vnto the watir downe
Be wrey me nought thou watir with thi soune
Qd she to the I telle hit and no mo
Myn housbonde hath too longe assis eris too
Now is myn herte al hole nowe it is owte
I myght no lenger kepe it now oute of doute
Here may ye see though we a tyme abide
Yit oute hit mote we mowe no coıı̄unceille hide
The remenaunt of the tale yif ye wille here ¶ Bathe
Rede Ouyde and ye may hit here
This knyght of whiche my tale is specially
Whanne that he sawe he myght nought com therby
This is to say whatte women m louyn moste
With inne his herte sorefull was the goste
But home he goth he myght nought soiorne
The day was come that homwarde he moste turne
And in his wey it happid hym to ride
In alle his kare vndir a Foreste side
Wher he sawe ou oon daunce goo
Of ladies foure and twenty and yit moo
To warde the daunce he drowe hym yerne
In hope that some wisdome to lerne
But certeinly or he come fully there
Va nysshid I was the daunce he wist nought where
No creature sawe he that bare liffe
Saue in the grene he saw sitting a wif
A fouler wight ther may no man deuyse
A geyn the knyght the olde wif ganne arise
And saide sir knyght here forthe lieth no way
Telle me what ye sekyn by your feye
ꝑparauenture it may the bettir bee
This olde folke coneth moche thinge qd sche
My leue modir qd this knyght serteyne
I am but dede but that I kanne sayne
What thinge hit is that women most desire
Coude ye me wisse I wolde welle quite youre hire
Plight me thi trouth here in myn hande qd she
The nexte thinge that I require the
Thou shalt hit doo yif hit lie in thi myght
And I shal telle hit you or hit be nyght
Haue here my trouth qd the knyght I graunte
That qd sche I may me welle avaunte
Thi lif is saf I wille stande ther by
Vpou my lif the quene will say as I ¶ Bathe
Lete se whiche is proudeste of hem alle
That werith on a kerech or a calle
That dar say nay of that I shall you teche
Late vs go forth with any more speche
Tho roundid she a pistill in his ere
And bad hym to be glad and haue no fere
Whanne they be comyn to the Courte this knyght
Saide he hadde holde his day as he hadde hight
And redy was his answe as he saide
Full many a nobill wif and many a maide
And many a wedewe for that they be wise
The quene hir silf sittyng as Iustice
Assemblid ben is answere for to here
And aftir ward this knyght was bedyn to apere
And that the knyght shulde telle in audience
To eủery wight was commaundid silence
What thinge that worldly women loue moste
This knyght stode nought stille as dothe a beste
But to his question anon answerid
With manly vois that alle the Curte hitte herde
My lege lady genally qd hee
Women desiryn to haue soeủereinte
As welle oeủere housbondes and hir loue
And for to be in maistrie hem aboue
This is youre moste desire though ye me kille
Doth as you liste I am here att youre wille
In alle the Courte was ther wif ner maide
Ne wedewe that koude contrarie that he say
But saide he worthi was to haue his lif
And with that worde vp stirte that olde wif
Which that the knyght saw sittyng on the grene
Mercy qd she my soeủerayn lady quene
Or that your Courte deꝑparte do me right ¶ Bathe
I taught this answere vnto this knyght
For whiche he plight me his trouthe there
The first thinge I wolde of hym requere
He wolde hit doo yif hit lay in his myght
Be fore the Courte thanne pray I the sire knyght
Qd she that thou me take vnto thi wife
For welle thou woteste that I haue kepte thi life
Yif I say fals say nay vpon thi fay
This knyght answerid allas wele away
I wotte right welle that swiche was myn heste
For goddis loue chese a newe requeste
Take alle my gode and late my body goo
Nay thanne qd sche I shrewe us both too
For that I be foule olde and pore
I nolde nott for all the metall and the ore
That vndir erthe is graue or lithe aboue
But that I the wif were and thi loue
My loue qd he nay my dampnaciou
Allas that any ohofohf of my naciou
Shulde eủere so foule disꝑparagid be
But al for nought the ende is this that he
Constreyned was he nedis moste hir wede
And take this olde wif and go to bedde
Nowe wolde some men seyn ꝑparauenture
That for my neccligenece I do no cure
To telle you the ioie and the arraye
That atte the feste was that ilke a day
To whiche thinge shortly answere I shalle
I sey ther was no Ioie ne feste atte alle
Ther nas but heuyneeheuynesseheuyness and mochil sorwe
For preuyly he weddid hir on the morwe
And all day aft̉er hidde hym as an owle
So wo was hym his wif lokyd so foule ¶ Bathe
Grete was the sorwe the knyght had in his thought
Whanne he was with his wif a bedde I brought
He walwith and turnyth to and fro
His olde wif lay smylyng eủere mo
And saide a dere housbonde o benedicite
Farith eủery knyght with his wyf as yee
Is this the lawe of kynge Arthuris hous
Ys eủery knyght of his so daungerouse
I am youre ovne loue and eke youre wif
I am she the swyche hathe sauyd thi lif
And certꝭes yit dede you neủere vn right
Whi fare ye thus with me the firste nyght
Ye faren like a man that hadde loste his witte
Fy what is my gilte for goddes loue telle hitte
And hit shall be amendid yif I may
A mendid qd this kny nay nay
Thatt wille nought bee amendid neủere moo
Thou arte so lothly and so olde also
And ther to come of so lowe a kynde
That litill wondir is though I walwe and wynde
So i wolde god myn hert wolde breste
Is this qd she the cause of youre vnreste
Ye certenly qd he no wondir is .
Nowe sir I koude amende al this .
Yif that me liste or hit were daies thre
So welle ye myght bere you to me
FoButFoBut for ye spekyn of sweche gentilesse
As is discendid oute of al richesse
That ther for shulde ye be gentilmen
Swech erregaunce nys nott worth an hen
Loue that moste is vertuous al way
Preuy and aperte and most intendith ay
To do the gentill dedis that he canne
And take hym for the gretteste gentilmanne ¶ Bathe
Criste wille we clayme of hym oure gentilesse
Nought of oure eldres for hir ol olde Ricesse
For though thei yif vs all hir heritage
For whiche we clayme to be of hie parage
Yet may they nought be quethe for no thinge
To noon of vs her vertuous leuyng
That made hem gentil men I callid be
And bad vs folwyn in sweche degre
Welle canne the wise poete of florence
That hight Daunt spak in this sentence
Lo in swiche man ryme is Dantes tale
Ful seelde vp risith by his braunchis smale
Prowesse of man for god of his prouesse
Wille that of hym we klayme oure lentilesse
For of oure eldres a may we no thing claime
But temꝑperel thinges that may hurte and mayme
Eke eủery wight wott this as welle as I
Yif gentillesse were plantid naturelly
Vnto certeyn lynage doune the lyne
Pryue and a perte than wolde they neủere fyne
To do of gentilesse the faire office
They myght do no veleny or vise
Take fire and bere hit in the dirkest house
Be twix this and the mounte of Cānkasous
And latte men shitte the dores and the genne
Yit will the fire alle so faire lye and brenne
As though a thousand men myght hit beholde
His office naturell ay will hit holde
Vp perell of lif till that thou die
Here may ye see welle that genterie
Is nought annexid to possessiou
Sith folke do nought hir o oꝑperacōu
For god hit wote men may ful often fynde
A lordes sonne do shame and vilanye
And that wille haue pⁱris of his genterie ¶ Bathe
For he was borne of gentill hous
And had his elderis nobil and vertuous
And will hym selfe do no gentil dedis
Ne folwe his gentil auncestres that ded is
He nys nought gentill be he duke or Erle
For vileynes synful dedis makith a Cherle
For gentilesse is but reủerent reneune
Of thyn auncestres for hir beute bovne
Which is a stronge thinge for thi ꝑpersone
The gentilesse cometh fro god aboue
Thanne comyth oure verry gentilesse of gᵃce
It was no thing be quethe vs with oure purchaceplacepurchace place
Thingith how noble as saith valerius
Was thilke Tullius hostilius
That oute of pouerte rose to hie noblesse
Redith Senek and redith eke Boesse
Ther shulle ye sen expsse that hit no drede is
That he is gentill that doth gentil dedis
And ther for dere housbonde I thus conclude
All were that myn auncetres were rude
Yit may the hie god and so hope I
Graunte me gᵃce to leue vertuously
Thanne am I gentil whan that I begynne
To leven vertuously and weuyn synne
And ther as ye of poeủerte me repreue
The hie god on whom we beleue
In wilful poeủerte chese to leue his lif
And sertis eủery man and maide and wife
May vndirstande Ihu heuen kynge
Ne wolde nought chese a visious leuyng
Glade poeủerte is a honest thing certayne
This wille Senek and othir Clerkis sayne
Who so that holte hym paied of his poeủerte
I holde hym riche al had nought serte
He that coueitith is a pore wight ¶ Bathe
For he wolde han that is nought in his myght
But he that nought hath ne coueitith to haue
He is riche and though men holde hym but a knaue
Verry pouerte is signesinnesignne propirly
Iuvenall sathsaythsayth of pouerte myrely
The pore man he goth be the waye
Beforne theues he may singe and play
Poeủerte is hatel goode and as I gesse
A full grete bringer oute of besinesse
A grete amender eke of Sapience
Poeủerte is this al though hit seme elenge
Possessiou that no wight wille chalenge
Poeủerte ful ofte whan a man is lowe
Makith his god and eke hym selfe to knowe
Poeủerte is spectacle as thinkith me
Thorow whiche thinkith methinkith me whiche he may hes v̉erry fend see
And ther for syn that I you nought greue
Of my poeủerte no more me repue
Nowe sir of elde ye reproue me
And sertꝭes sire thourgh non auctorite
Were in were in a boke ye gentils of honoure
Seyn that men scholde an olde wight do fauour
And clepe hir modir for hir gentilesse
And auctours schal I fynde as I gesse
Nowe ther ye seyn that I am foule and olde
Thanne drede ye nought to be no kokkolde
For felth and elde also mote I the
Be grete wardeyns vpon chastite
But natheles syn I knowe youre delite
I shal fulfill your worldly apitite
Chese now qd she on of thingis twey
To haue me foule and olde til that I dey
And be to you a goode trew humble wif
And neủere you displesyn in al my lif
Or els ye wille haue me yonge and faire ¶ Bathe
And take the auenture of the repeire
That shal com to your hous be cause of me
Or in some othir place welle may be
Nowe chesith youre selfe whethir that you likith
This knyght avisith hym andsore sikith
But atte the laste he saide in this mane
Mi lady and my loue and wif so dere
I put me in your wise goeủernaunce
Gessith your self whiche may be moste plesaunce
And most honoure to you and me also
I do no fors the wethir of us too
For as hithit you likith hit suffisith me
Thanne haue I gote of you maistrie qd sche
Sen I may chese and goeủerne as my liste
Ye sertis wif I holde hit for the beste
Kisse me qd she we be no lenger wrothe
For be my trouth I wille be to you bothe
This is to sayn to be faire and gode
I pray to god that I mote stirtyn wode
But I to you be al so sadde and treue
As eủere was wif sithyn the worlde was newe
And but I be to morwe as faire to sene
As any lady Emprese or Quene
That ys be twene the Este and eke the Weste
Do with my lif right as you liste
Caste vp the Curtyns loke hou hit is .
And whan the knyght say alle this .
That sche so faire was yonge also
For ioie he hente hir in hir armys too
His herte bathid in a bathe of blisse
A thousande tyme on rowe he gan hir kis
And she obeied hym in eu eủery thinge
That myght do hym plesaunce or or likynge
And thus they leuyd to hir lyues ende ¶ Bathe
In ꝑparfite Ioie and Ihu Crist vs sende
Housbondes meke yonge and fressh a bedde
And to eủere lede hem that we wedde
And eke I pray to Ihu shorte hir lyuys
That wille nought be goeủernyd be hir wivis
And olde and angry nygardes in dispence
God sende hem sone a verry pestelence

l.hi: ¶ Here begynnyth the prologe of the Frers

div.l: This worthi lymytour this noble frere
He made alway lourynge chere
Vpon the Sompnour but for honeste
No veleyns word as yit spak he
But that atte laste he saide vnto the frerewiffrere wif
Dame goode god yif you right gode life
Ye han touchid here as so mote I the
In skole mat̉er grete difficulte
Ye han saide meche thing righte welle I sey
But dame as we riden here be the way
Vs nedith nought spekyn but of game
And late auctorites go on goddis name
To pcheng and to scole eke of clergie
But yif hit like vnto this companie
I wille of a Sompnour telle a game
ꝑparde I may well knowe be the name
That of no Sompnour may no goode be saide
I pray that non of you be euyil a paide
