That we to you with pitous hert compleyne
And late nat youre Eris my vois disdeyne
Alle haue I nought to done in this matere
More than a nothir hath in this place
Yett for als moche as ye my lorde so dere
Haue alwey shewid fauour and grace
I dar the better of you aske a space
Yit for also moche of you my lorde to shewyn oure requeste
And ye my lorde to done right as ye leste
For certis lorde so welle vs likith you
And of your werkis and eủere a dou that we
Ne koude nought oure ovne selue dyuysen howe
We myght more leuyid in felicite
Saue oon thing lorde yif hit your will be
That for to be a weddid man if it your willeyou listeit yourwille liste
Thanne were youre peple in soeủereyne hertꝭes reste
Bowith your nekke vndir that blisful yokke
Of soueynte nought of seruise ¶ Gresilde
Whiche men spekeclepespekeclepe spousaile or wedloke
And thinkith lord a monge your thoughtꝭes wise
For of wedloke komyth grete emprise
For though we spekeslepespeke slepe or wake rome or ride
Ay fleth the tyme it wille no man abide
And though youre grene youthe growe as yitt
In crepith age all way as stille as stone
And deth manasith eủery age and smytte
In eche astate for ther escapith noon
And also certeyn as we knowith eủery chon
That we shulle die and vncertein that we alle
Ben of that day that dethe shal on vs falle
Acceptith than of vs the trewe entente
That neủer yitt we refusith your heste
And we wille al lorde yif ye wil assente
Chese you a wife a wife in shorte tyme atte the leste
Borne of the gentileste and of the moste
Of al this lande so that it ought seme
Honour to god and you so as we kan deme
¶ Delieủere vs of al this besy drede
And take a wif for high goddis sake
For yif hit be felle so as god for bede
That thurgh deth your lenage shulde slake
And a straunge leneage shulde take
Your heritage o woo wer vs a lyue
Wher for we pray you hastily to wiffe
Her meke preier and hir pitous chere
Made the Marquis haue suche pite
Wille ye quoth he myne owne peple deb dere
To that I neủer erste thought constrayne me
I me reioise nought of my liberte
That seldyn tyme is founde in mariage
Ther I was fre I mote ben in Seruage
And truste vp on you and
¶ But natheles I se your treue entente
And truste vpon you and haue don ay ¶ Grisilde
Wherfor of my fre wille I assent
To wedde me as sone as eủere I may
Wherfor of my fre wille I as sente
To w But ther as ye haue proferid me to day
To chese me a wif I you relese
That choise and pray you of that profir sese
For god hit wotte that cheldren oftyn ben
Vnlike hir worthi elderis hym be forne
Bounte comyth alle of god nought of the strene
Of whiche they ben engendrid and I borneboreborne bore
I truste in goddis bounte and ther fore
My mariage and myn estate and reste
I hym be take he may do as hym liste
Lete me in chesinge of my wife
That charge ou my bakke I wille endure
But I you pray and charge vpon youre lif
That wif that I take ye me ensure
To worshipe her wel my lif endure
In worde and werke bothe here and els where
As she an EmꝐPerour Doughtir were
And firthir more this ye shole swren
That a yenst my chose shole nothir groche ne striue
For sith I shalle for go my liberte
At your requeste as eủere mote I thrive
Ther as my herte is sette ther wille I wife
And but ye wille assente in seche manere
I pray you speketh no more of this matere
With hertly wille they sworyn and assentyn
To alle this thing they saide no wight nay
Be sechyn hym of gᵃce or they wentyn
That he wolde graunte hem a certeyn day
Of this spousaile as so sone as eủere he may
For yit alwey the peple somwhat dradde
Leste this Marquis wolde no wif wedidweddewedid wedde
He grauntid hem a day such as hym liste
On whiche he wolde be weddid sikirly
And saide he dede al this at here requeste ¶ Grisilde
And they with hvmble entente ful buxhumlye
Knelyng on hir knees ful reủerently
Hym thankyng all and thus they haue an ende
And here vpon he toke his officers
Of her entente and home ageyne they wende
And here vpon he toke his officers
Comaundyng for the feste to puruey
And to hise ꝑperduy knyghtꝭes and squiers
Wit swiche charge yaf hem is lust on hem to leye
And they his cōmmaundement to obeye
And eche of hem doth his diligence
To done vnto the feste reủerence
¶ NOught fer from thilke place honourable
Wher as this Marquis shope his mariage
Ther stode a thrope of sight delitable
In whiche poore folke of that village
Hadde hir bestis and hir herbrigage
And of hir laboure toke hir sustinaunce
Aftir the erthe hem yaf habundaunce
A monge thise pore folke ther dwellid a man
Whiche that was holde porest of hem alle
But high god somtyme sende canne
His grace vn till . a litil . oxe stalle
Ianicula men of that thrope hym calle
A doughtir had he faire and yonge of sighte
And Grisilde this younge maide hight
But for to speke of vertuous beute
Than was she on fairest vndir the sonne
Welle poorly I fosterid was she
No licourusnesse was in hir lust I ronne
Welle oftir of the welle thanne of the tonne
She dranke and for she wolde vertu plese
She knewe wel labour but noon idill ese
But though this maide were tendre of age
Yitt in the breste of hir virginite
Ther was inclosid ripe and sad corage
And in grete reủerence and grete charite
Here olde poore Fadir fostrid she ¶ Grisilde
A few shepe spynnyng in the felde she kepte
She wolde nought ben Idill til she slepte
And whanne she homwarde come she wolde bringe
Wortis or herbis tymes ful ofte
Whech she shrad and sethe for hir leuyng
And made hir bedde ful harde and no thinge softe
And eủere she kepte hire faderis lif on a lofte
With eủery obeisaunce and diligence
That childe childe may . doo . to fadir reủerence
Vpon Grisilde the pore creature
Wel ofte hath Marquis sette his eie
As he a hontyng rode ꝑparauenture
And whan hit felle that he myght hir aspie
With wantanne lokynge of folie
As his eyne caste vpon hir but in sad wise
Vpon hir chere he wolde hym ofte avise
Comending in his herte here womanhode
And eke hir bente passing any wight
Of so younge age as wele in chere and in dede
For though the peple haue no grete insight
In vertue he considerid afulaful right
Here bente and disposid that he wolde
Here wedde and eủere he wedde sholde
The day of wedding kome but no wight kan
Telle what woman it shulde be
For whiche muaile wondrid many a man
And saiden when they were in priuite
Wille nought oure lorde leue his vanyte
Wille nought wedde alas alas the while
Whi wille he hym selfe and vs begile
But natheles this Marquis hath do make
Of gemmys sette in golde and of asure
Brochis and ringis for Grisild sake
And of hir clothing toke he the mesure
Of a maydyn like to hir stature
And eke of othir ornamentꝭes alle
That to swiche a wedding shulde falle ¶ Grisilde
The tyme of vndirne in the same day
A prochith that this wedding shulde be
And al the paleis put was in araye
Bothe halle and Chambres eche in his degre
Houses of office with grete plente
Ther maiste the see of deyntevous vitaile
That may be founde as as ferre as lestith Itaile
This reall Marquis rially araijd
Lordis and ladies in his companie
The whiche to the fest were praijd
And of his retenewe the bachelrie
With many a sonne of sondry melodie
Vnto the village whiche I tolde
In this aray the right wey they holde
Grisilde god wotte of this was ful Innocente
That for hir was al this araye
To fettyn watir atte welle is wente
And comyth hom as sone as eủere she may
For welle she herde say that ilke day .
The Marquis sholde wife and yif she myght
Sche wolde fayne se somme of that sight
She thought I wille with othir maidenes stonde
That be my felawes in oure dore and see
The Marquis and ther for wille I stondefondestonde fonde
To done atte home as sone as may be
The labour wheche that longith vnto me
And than may I at leisir hit be holde
Yf she this wey to this castelle holde
And she wolde oeủere the thressh folde gone
The Marquis come and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doune hir wat̉er potte anone
Be side the threshfolde of the oxe stalle
And doune vpon hir knees she ganne falle
And with sad contenaunce knelid stille
Tille she had herde what was the lordis wille
This thoughtfull Marquis spake vnto this maide ¶ Grisilde
Wel sobirly and saide in this manere
Wher is your fadir Grisilde he saide
And she with reủerence and meke chere
Answherid lorde he is al redy here
And in she goth with any lenger lette
And to the Marquis she hir fadir fette
He be the honde he toke this olde man
And saide thus whanne he hym thus a side
Ianicula I neither may ne canne
Lenger the plesaunce of myn herte hide
If that thou fouchesafe what so betide
I Thi Doughtir wolde I take er that I wende
As for my wif vnto my lyuys ende
Thou louyst me I wotte serteyne
And arte my feithful lege man I bore
And al that likith me I dar wel sayne
Hit likith the and specially therfore
Telle me that pointe that I haue saide before
Yif that thou wilte vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thyn son in lawe
The sodeyn cas the man a stonyd soo
That rede he wax al bashid and al quakynge
He stode vnneth and saide a worde moo
But only thus lorde quoth he my willynge
Is as ye wille no right a geynst your likynge
I wille no thinge ye be my lorde so dere
Right as ye luste goeủernyth this matere
Thanne wol I do thus quoth Marquis sothelie
That in to the chambre I and thou and she
Haue a colaciou and wost thou whi
For I wille aske her yif hir wille bee
To be my wif and reule hir aftir me
And al this she shal do in thi presence
I wille nought oute of her audience
And in the Chambre while they were a boute
Her tretis whiche ye shulle here aftirwarde ¶ Grisild
The peple kame in to the hous withoute
And wondrid hem in howe honeste manere
And tentifly she kepte here fadir dere
But vttirly Grisilde wondir myght
For neuer efte sawe she swiche a sight
¶ No wondir is thowe she beisbe is a stonyed
To se so grete ageste come in to that place
She was neủere to suche gestis wonyd
For whiche she lokid with full pale face
But shortly for this mater for to pace
Thise were the wordis that this Marquis saide
To this benygne ferey feithful maide
Grisilde he saide ye welle vndirstande
As I suppose that ye wele that it may so be
But this demaunde I aske firste quoth he
That sithin I shall be done on hasty wise
¶ Grisilde he saide ye wille welle vndir stande
It likith vnto youre fadir and me
That I you wedde and eke may so stande
As I suppose that ye wille that hit so be
But this demaunde I aske firste quoth hie
That sethen it shalle be done on hasti wise
Wille ye assente or els you avise
¶ I sey this be ye redy with gode herte
To all my luste and that frely maye
As me best thinkith do yow laugh or smerte
And ye neủere grouche nyght ne day
And eke whan say ye sey ye nought nay
Nethir be worde ne be frowarde countenaunce
Swere this and here I swere oure a liaunce
Wondring vpon this worde quakyng for drede
She saide Indigne and vnworthie
And I to thatt that ye be me bede
Butt right as ye wille youre selfe so will I
And I swere that neủere wilfullye
In worde ne in thought I neủere disobeye
For to be dede though me were lothe to die ¶ Grisilde
This is I nowe Grisilde myn quoth he
And forthe he gothe with a sobir chere
Oute atte the dore aftir hy cam she
And to the peple he saide in this manere
This is my wordewifeworde wife quoth he that stondith here
Honourith hire and louyth hir I you pray
Who so louyth me ther is no more to say
And for no thinge of hir olde gere
She shulde bringe to his house he bade
That women shulde dispoile hir right there
Of whiche the ladies were nought right glad
To handill hir clothis in whiche she was clade
But natheles this maide bright of hewe
Fro fote to hede I clothid was al newe
Hr heris haue thaye kembid that lay vntressed
Welle rowdely with hir fengres smale
And a krowne on hir hede they haue dressid
And sette hit ful of ouches grete and smale
Of hir aray what shulde I make a tale
Vnethe the peple knewe hir for hir fairnesse
Whanne she transfourmyd was in suche richesse
This Marquis hathe hir Spousid with a ringe
But for the same cause and thanne hir sette
Vppon an hors snowe white and welle ambelynge
And to his paleis or he lenger lette
With Ioifull peple that he hadde and mette
Conveied here and thus the day they spende
In reuel tille the sonne ganne discende
And shortly forth this tale for to chase
I say that to this newe Marquysesse
God hathe sente swiche fauour of his gᵃce
That semyd nought asas be likenesse
That she was borne and fedde in rudenesse
As in a Cote or in an oxe stalle
But norishid in a EmꝐPerours halle ¶ Grisilde
To eủery wight she wexen is so dedederedede dere
And worshipful that folke there as she was bore
And fro hir birthe knewe hir yere be yere
Vnnethe trowid they but durste haue swore
That to IaniculaIanicleIanicula Ianicle of whiche I spake before
She his Doughtir ne were for as be coniecture
He thought she was a nothir creature
For that eủere vertuous was she
She was encresid in swiche excellence
Of thewis sette in hie bounte
And so discrete and faire of eloquence
So benygne and digne of reủerence
And koude the peple hertes so wewe enbrace
That eche hir louyd that lokid in hir face
Nought only of saluce in the towne
Publesshid was the bounte of hir name
And eke beside in many a regiou
Yif on saide welle a nothir saide the same
So spred of hir bounte the fame
Than men and women bothe yonge as olde
Gone to Saluce here to be holde
This water lowly nay butte Rially
Weddid with fortune honeste
In godis peese leuyth wel esily
And home and oute warte grace I now had he
And for he sawe vndir lowe degre
Was ofte vertue hide the pepil hym hilde
A preudent man and that is sene wel selde
Nought only g Grisilde thus thourgh his witt
Coude al the fete of wifly humblenesse
But eke whan the cas requirid hitte
The cōmmvne profite koude she redresse
Thar nas discorde rancoure ne heuynesse
In all that lande the she ne coudet cese
And bringe hem alle wisely in reste and ese ¶ Grisilde
ThoughtThoughThought that hir housbonde psent wer or noone
Yif gentil men or othir of hir contre
Were wrothe she koude bringe at one
So wise and pdpe wordis had she
And Iugement of so grete equite
That she fro heuen was as men wende
Peple to saue and eủery wronge to amende
Nought longe tyme aftir this Grisilde
Was weddid she a Doughtir hathe bore
Had she leủere a borne a knaue childe
Glad was the Marquis and his folke ther fore
For though a maide childe come al before

div.l: Be likely hede sithenes she nys nought bareynet
She may to a knauechilde ateyne
Be likly hede sithenes she nys nought bareyne
Therfor as it fallith tymes moo
Whan this Childe hathe sowkid but a throwe
This Marquis in his herte longith soo
To tempte his wif her sadnesse to knowe
That he ne myght fro his herte throwe
This meruelous desire his wif to assaie
Netheles gode wote he thought hir for to afraye
He he had assaied e nowe to fore
And founde hir eủeregoode what nedith hit
Hir for to two turment and alwey more and more
Thowe some preyse hit for a sotil witte
But as for men I say that euyl hit sitte
To a say a wif whanne hit is no nede
And putte hir in anguysshe and in drede
For whiche this Marquis wrought in this manere
He cam a nyght a boue where as she lay
With sterne face and trewlid chere
And saide to Grisilde quoth he that day
That I you toke of youre poore arraie
And putte you in astate of high nobelesse
Ye haue nought forgetyn as I gesse ¶ Gresilde
I say Grisilde this psente dignite
In whiche I haue putte you as I trowe
Makith you nought for yeteful for to bee
That I you toke in pore estate ful lowe
For any thinge ye mote your selfe knowe
Take of eủery worde hede what I you sey
Ther is no wight that herith this but we twey
Ye wote youre selfe welle howe that ye come here
In to this hous it is nought longe agoo
And though ye beth to me lefe and dere
Vnto my gentilis ye be nought soo .
They sey to hem it grete shame and wo .
For to be sogette and in seruage
To the that arte borne of so lowe lynage
And namly sithe thi doughtir was bore
Thise wordes haue they spoke doughtles
But I desire as I haue do to fore
To leve my lif with hem in rest and pees
I may nought in this cas be recheles
I moste do with my Doughtir for the beste
Nought as I wolde but as my gentils liste
And yitt god wote this is wel lothe to me
Butt natheles with oute youre wetyng
I wele nought do but this I wil quoth hee
That ye to me assente as in this thinge
Shewith nowe youre pacience in youre wirchinge
That ye me be hight and swore in your village
That day that makid was oure mariage
Whan she had herde al this she was nought ameuyd
Nothir in worde ne chere ne countenaunce
For as hit semyd she was nought agreuyd
She saide lorde al lithe in youre plesaunce
My childe and I with hertely obeisaunce
Be yours all and ye may saue and spille
Youre owne thinge whethir that ye wille ¶ Gresilde
Ther may no thinge so god my soule saue
Likyng to you that may displese me
Ne I desire no thinge to haue
Ne drede to lese saue only ye
This wille is in my herte and ay shal bee
Ne length of tyme or deth it may deface
Neithir chaunge my corage in to othir place
Gladde was this Marquis for her answhering
But yitt he faynyd as he were nought soo
Al drery was his chere and lokyng
Whanne sheheshe shulde oute of the chambre goo .
Sone aftir this a forlonge wey or too
He pleynly hathe tolde al his entente
Vnto a man wiche he vnto his wif sente
A maner seriaunte was this preuy man
The whiche that faithfull founde he hadde
In thinges grete and eke suche folkꝭes wel canne
Done execusiou of thingis badd
The lorde knewe welle that he hym louyd a dred
And whan this seriaunte wiste his lordis wille
In to the Chambre he staltkid ful stille
Madame he saide ye mote for yeuet mee
Though I do thing whiche I am constreynyd
Ye ben so wise that wel knowyn yee
That lordis hestis may nought be faynyd
They mowe welle be wailid or complaynyd
But men mote nede to hir lustes obeie
And so wille I ther no more to sey
That Childe I cōmmaundid to take
And spak no more but oute the childe he hente
Dispitously and gan a chere to make
As he wolde haue slayne it her he wente
Grisilde mote al suffre and al consente
And as a lambe she sittith meke and stille
And lete this crewell Sergeaunte haue his wille ¶ Gresilde
Suspecte was the fame of this man
Suspecte is face suspecte is worde also
Suspecte the tyme that he this be ganne
For hir Doughtir that she louyd soo
He wente he wolde haue slayn it right thoo
SheShe But natheles she neithir wepte ne saide
Confourmyd here to that the Marquis likide
And att the laste speke she be ganne
And mekely to this Serieaunt praide
So as he was a worthi gentilman
That she moste kisse here childe or that it deyde
And in hir arme this litil childechilde she leide
With full full sadde face and gan the childe to blisse
And lullid hit and aftir gan hit kisse
And thus she saide in hir benygn vois
Fare wel my childe I shal the neủer see
But sithyn I haue market the with the Crois
Of thilke fadir blissid mote thou bee
That for vs dide vppon the Rode tree
Thisoule litill childe I hym be take
For this nyght shal thou dien for my sake
I trowe that to a norice in this cas
Hit had be harde this reuthe for to seen
Wel myght a modir than krie allas
But natheles she sade and stedfaste was she
That she endurid al hir adeủersite mekely
And to the seiaunte meke she saide
Haue here ageyne my litill yonge maide
And goth nowe quothe she and doth my lordis heste
And o thing wolde I pray you of youre grace
That but if my lorde for bode you atte the leste
Burith the body in some place
That no bestes ne birdis it to race
But he no worde to the purpos wolde sey
This Seriaunte wente to his lorde a geyne
And of Grisildes wordis and of hir chere
He tolde hym pointe fro pointe in shorte and playne
And hym psentid with his Doughtir dere
Somwhat this lorde had re thought in his manere ¶ Gresilde
But natheles his purpos hilde he stille
As lordis done whan they wille haue hir wille
And bad this Seriaunte ful pduyly
He shulde wel softe this childe wynde and wrappe
With all the sircumstaunce tendirly
And cary hit in a coffre or in thi lappe
But vp peyne his hede of to swappe
That no man shulde knowe of his entente
Ne whens he comēn ne whethir he wente
But to Boleyne to his Sustre dere
That tho of Pavy was Countesse
He shulde hir take and shawe hir this matere
Beseching hir to done hir besinesse
This Childe to fostre in all gladnesse
And whos childe that it was he badde hide
From eủery wight for ought that myght be tide
This Seriaunte gothe and hath fulfillid this thinge
But to this Marquis nowe retorne we
For nowe gothe he ful ofte ymaginyng
If by his wif he myght see
And be hir wordis ꝑperceiue that she
Were chaungid but he coude neủere fynde
But eủere in oon I like sadde and kynde
¶ As glad as humble as besy in seruyce
And eke in loue as she was wonte to bee
Was she to hym oon in eủery w maner wise
Ne of hir Doughtir a worde spak shee
None accident for non adeủersite
Was sene in hir ne neủere hir Doughtir name
Nempnyd she for ernest ne for game
In this estate passid been foure yere
Er she with childe were but as god wolde
A knaue childe she bare be this Waltere
Wel gracious and faire to be holde ¶ Gresilde
And whenne folke it to here fadir tolde
Nought only he but al the Contre merie
Was for the Childe and god they thankid and herie
When hit was too yere olde and from the breste
deꝑpartid from from the norice on a day
This Markes kaughte a nothir leste
To tempte his wif ofter yif he may
O nedeles was she tempted in a say
But weddid men knowe no mesure
When thei fyndyn a pacient creature
Wife quothe this Markes ye han herde or this
Mi peple sekirly berith oure mariage
And namely sith my son borne is
Now it is worse that eủere in oure age
The mormour sleth myn herte and my corage
For to my eris cometh the vois so smerte
That hit wille nye distroiyth al myne herte
Now men sey thus whan walter is agone
Thanne shalle the blode of Ianycle succede
And ben oure lorde for othir haue we none
Siche wordis seyne my peple it is no drede
Wel ought I of suche murmour take hede
For serteinly I drede suche sentence
Though they nought speke plainly in myn audience
I wolde leue in pees yif that I myght
Wher for I am disposid vttirlye
As I his sustir seruyd be nyght
Right so I thinke serue hym so pduylie

His fresshe may his paradis his make

Nowe we haue leue to pleyen vs be the lawe

This sike Damyan in Venus fire

Vnto this . faire fresshe lady may

And so by felle . how that this gode man

And saide seinte marie howe may this be

This Damyan whan that he his tyme say

And she obeieth be he lefe or lothe

To the whiche . they do to the deuyl . sacrifise .
With in the deuils temple in sondri wise
Be suꝑperfluite abhomynable .
Her othis . be so grete and dampnable .
That is grisly for to here hem swere
Oure blissid lordis body . they al to tere
Hem thought Iewes rente hym nought I nowe
And ilke at othir synne lowe .
And right anone . come Inne tombsteres
Fetis and smal . and yonge frutereres
Singers with harpis . baudes and wafereres
Suche ben verray . the deuelis officers .
To kyndel kyndilyn and bloue the fire . of lecherie
That is annexte to glotenye
The hely writte take I to wittenesse
That lecherie . is in wyne and dronknesse
Lo how that dronkyn lote . vnkyndely ¶Pardoner .
Lay by his doughtris too vn wetingly
So dronkyn he was . he neste what he wrought
Erodes who that hathe the stories soughte
Whanne of wyne was replete . at his feste .
Right at his owne table . yaf his heste
To slene the Baptiste Iohn ful gilteles .
Senek seithe a goode worde douteles .
He saith he kane no difference fynde
Be twix a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man that is dronkelewe
But that wodenesse is fallyn in a shrewe .
ꝑperseủerith lenger . than doth dronkenesse
O gotonye ful of cursidnesse
O cause first of oure confusion
Original . of oure dampnacioun
Til Crist had bought vs with his blode ageyn
Lo howe dere shortly for to sayne
A bought was the cursid vilanye .
Corupt was . al this worlde thorwe glotenie
Adam oure fadir and his wif also
Fro Paradise . and whan that hee
Ete of the frute defendid on the tree .
A none he was oute caste to wo and payne
O glotenye on the wel ought vs pleyne
O wiste a man howe many maladies
Folwith of excesse and of glotenyes .
He wolde ben the more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng att his table
Alas the shorte throte the tendre mouthe
Makith that Este and west north and southe
In erthe in eire in watir men to synke
To gete a gloton mete and drinke
Of this matir o poule welle . canne thou trete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe eke to mete
Shal god distroie . both as poule saithe
Alas a foule thing it is be my feith
To say this word and fouler is the dede
When men so dronkyn bee . of the white and rede ¶Pardoner .
That of his throte he makith his preue
Thourgh / that cursid suꝑperfluyte
The apostil weping seith ful . pitously .
Ther walkith many of whiche tolde haue I
I say it nowe weping with pitous vois
They ben Enemys of Cristis Crois
Of the whiche ende is deth wombe is hir god .
O wombe o baly . o stinkynge Codde
Fulfillid of donge and of corrupciou
And to eủery ende of this foule is the sesoun
How grete coste and labour is to fynde
Thise Cokis hou they stampe streine and grinde
And turne substaunce in to accidente
To fulfille al thi licorous talent
Oute of the harde bones knokke they .
The mary for they caste notte a way .
That may go thourgh the golete softe and sote
Of spicery and leues barke and rote
Shal be his sause I made be delite
To makyn hym a newe appetite
But certꝭes he that hauntith swiche delites .
Is dide whils that he e leuyth in tho vicis .
A lecherous thinge is wyne and dronknesse
It is ful of striuynge and of wrechidnesse
O dronkyn man . disfugurid in thi face
Foule is thi brethe foule arte thou to enbrace
And thourgh thi dronkyn nose souneth the soune
As thou saidiste ay Sampsoun sampson
And yit god wote Sampsou dranke neủer no wyne
Thou fallist as it were a dronkyn swyne
Thi tonge is loste and thyne honeste cure
For dronkkynnesse is verry sepulture
Of mannys witte and his discresciou
In whom that drinke hath dominacoun .
Ye kan no counceil . kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you fro the white and fro the rede
Namly from the white wyne of lepe ¶Pardoner
That is to selle in fishstrete and in chepe
This wyne of spayne crepith subtilly
In othir wynes growynge faste by
Of whiche . risithe . swiche fumosite
That whan a man hathe dronke a draught or thre
And wenyth that he be at home in chepe
Than is his he at spayne right at the toune of lepe
Nought att Rochil . ne att Burdeux tovne
And than wil he say sampsou sampson
But herkenyth lordyngis . o worde I you prey
That all the soeủereyne actis . dare I saye
Of victories . in olde testamente
That thourgh verry god that is omnipotent
Were done in abstinence . and in praiere
Lokith the bibil . and ther ye may lere
Loke Attyla . the grete conquerour .
Died in his slepe . with shame and dishonour
Bledyng at his nose . in dronkennesse
A Capetayne shulde leue in sobirnesse
And oeủere al thise a vise you right welle
That was cōmmaundid vnto lamwel .
Notte Samuel but lamwel . say I .
Redith the bible . and fyndith expssly .
Of wyne yevinge of hem that aren Iustice
No more of this for hit may suffise
And nowe that I s haue spokyn of glotonye
Now wille I defende you hasardrie
Hasard is ferry modir of lesynges .
And of disseite cursid for swerynges .
Blaspheme of Cristis name slaughtir and waste also
Of bataile ⁊and . ofte tyme . and of forthir moo
His repue . and contrari to honoure
For to be holde a comvne hasardoure
And eủere the hier of a state
The more he is holdyn desolate
Yif that a pⁱrince . vse . hasardrie
In al goeủernaunce policie ¶Pardoner
He is as be cōmmune opynyou
Hold the lasse in reputacou
Stylbone that was . holde awise enbassiatour
Was sente in to Corinth with ful grete honoure
Fro Calidoyne . to make hem alyaunce
And whanne he cam happid this chaunce
That al the grettest that were of that lande
Pleying atte the hasard he hem fande
For whiche as sone as that myght bee
He stale hym home a yen in to his contre
And saide ther I wolde nott lese my name
I wolde notte take on me so grete diffame
For to allie you to no hasardoures .
Sendith othir wiser Embassiatoures .
For by my trouthe me were leuer die
Than I shulde to you hasardowres alie
For ye that ben so gloriouse in honoures
Shal nought allie you . with hasardoures .
As be my wille ne as by my trete
This wise Philosophir thus said he
Loke eke that kynge Demetreus .
The kynke of Partes . as the boke seith thus .
Sente hym a paire of dees in skorne
For he had vsid hasardry ther be forne
For whiche he held his glorie and his renoun
For no value of o reputaciou
Lordis myght fynde othir mane of pley .
Honeste I nowe to driue the day a wey
Nowe wille I speke of othis smale and grete
A worde or too as othir bokis . trete
Grete swering is a thinge abhominable
As fals swering is more repuable
The hie god . for bad swering att alle
Wittenesse of Mathewe but in speciall .
Of sweringe the holy Ieromie
Thou shalt swere soth in othis and nought lie
And swere in dome and eke in rightwisnesse
But Idil swering is a cursidnesse ¶Pardoner
Be holde and se that in the firste table
Of hie godis hestis . honurable
Howe that too hestis . of hym is this .
Take nought my name in Idilnesse a mys
Lo rathir he forbedith swering
Than homycide or any othir thinge
I say as thus . be ordre it stondith
How that the secounde heste of god is that
That firthir oeủere I . wele telle al plate
That veniaunce . shal nought ꝑparte fro his hous
That of his othis is so contagious
By goddis pcious herte . and his nailis .
And be his blode . that is in hailis
Seven is my chaunce and his fyue a thre
By godis armys if thou falsly play me
This dagger shall thourgh thyn herte goo
This frute comyth of thise bones too
For sweryng Ire falsnesse and homycide
Now for the loue of Criste that for vs dide
Leuyth youre othis . bothe grete and smale
For I shal telle . you a merueillous tale
Thise reatoures of whiche I telle .
Longe erste or pⁱrime ronge any belle
Were sette in tauerne . to drinke
And as they satte thei herde a belle clynke
Be forne a Corps is that / that passith forth by
A forne a Corps . was carijd to his graue
One of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bet quod he and aske redily .
What Corps is that / that passith forth by
And loke that thou reporte his name welle
Sir quoth this it nedith neủere adele
It was me tolde . or ye come here too houris .
He was ꝑparde an olde felawe of youris .
And sodenly was he slayne to nyght
For dronkyn as he satte b vpon his bench vp right
Ther com a puy thef men clepen dethe ¶Pardoner
That in this contre al the peple sleth
And with spere he smote his herte atte too .
And wente his wey . withoute wordes moo .
He hath a thousande slayne this pestelence
And maistir ere ye come in his psence
Me thinkith that hit were necessarie
For to be ware of swiche aduersarie
Bethe redy for to mete hym eủere more
Thus taught me my modir I sey no more
Be seinte marie . sayth this Taeủernere
The childe saithe sothe . for he hath slayne to yere
Hennes oeủere a myle with in agrete village
Bothe manne and woman . childe and page
I trow his habitacioun be there
To ben avisid grete wisdom it were
Or that he did a man a dishonoure
Ye goddis armes . quod this reatoure .
Is it swiche ꝑperill . with hym for to mete
I shal hym sechen . by stie and be strete
I make a vowe . by godes . dyne bones .
Herkeneth felaws . we thre ben al ones .
Lete vche of vs halde vp his hande to othir
And eche of vs be come othir brothir
And we wil sle this fals traitour dethe
He shal be slayn he that so many slethe
Be goddis dignite er it be nyght
To gedir han thise thre her hertꝭes pliȝght
To leue and die . ilke of hem with othir
As thoughe he were his owne borne brothir
And vp they stirtyn and dronkyn in this Rage
And forthe they gon towarde that village
Of whiche the Taeủerner . hathe spokyn be forne
And many a grisly othe than haue they sworne
And Cristis blissid body han they to rente
That dethe shal be dede yif that we may hym hente
Whanne they haue gone nought fully a myle
Right as they wolde . gon oeủer a stile
An olde poore man with hem mette
This olde man ful mekely hem grette ¶Pardoner .
And saide thus . lordis . god you se
The prodeste of thise riatoures thre
Answerid a gayne what cherle with olde gᵃce
Whi arte thouı so longe in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And saide thus . for I canne nought finde
A man though I walkid in to Inde
Nothir in Cite nothir in village
That wille chaungen his youth for myne age
And therfor . mote . I haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as it is . godis wille
Ne dethe alas wille nott haue my lif
Thus walke I thourgh a resteles kaitif
And on the grounde . whiche is modir gate
I knok with my staf erly and late
And sey leue modir late me Inne
Lo how I wanysh fleshe blode and skynne
Alas whan shulle my bonys ben att reste
Modir with you wolde I chaunge my cheste
That in my chaumbre longe tyme hath bee
Ye for an haire cloute to wrape in me
But yit to me she nyl . nought do that grace
For whiche fulwelkid is my face .
But siris to you hit is no curtesie
To speke to an olde man vilanye .
But he trespacid in worde or els in dede
In holy writ ye may youre selue wel rede
A yenste an olde man hore . vpon his hede
Ye shulde a rise ther for I yeue you rede
Ne doth nott to an olde man harme as nowe
Ne more than ye wolde a man dide to you
In age if that ye so longe abide
And god be with you whethir ye go or ride
I mote go the dir as . I haue to goo
Nay olde cherle . be god thou shalt not soo .
Saide thise othir hasardoures . anone . ¶Pordoner
Thou partest nought so lyghtly by seinte Iohn
Thou spak right nowe of thilke traitour dethe
That in this contre alle oure frendis slethe
Haue my trouth as thou arte a spie
Telle where he is or els thou shalte abie die
Be god . and be the holy sacrament
For sothly thou arte of his assente
To slen vs yonge folke thou fals thef
Nowe certis yif hit be you lef
To fynde deth turne vp this crokid weye
For in that greue I lefte hym by my faye
Vndir a tree . and ther he wille abide .
Ne for youre bost he wille hym nothinge hide
Se ye that oke right there he wil a bide ye shul h hym fynde
God saue you that bought al man kynde
And you amende . saide this olde man .
And eủery of thise reatoures ranne .
Til they conne . to the tre . and there founde
Florens of of golde fyne . I kovnyd rovnde
Wel nye a seuen busshelles . as hem thought
No lenger aftir deth thei ne sought
But eche of hem so glad was of that sight
For that the floreyns . so faire be and bright
That doune thei sette . hem be the precious horde .
The worste of hem he spake the first worde .
Brethrene take hede what I seye
My witte is grete though I bourde and pley
This tresour fortune hathe vs yeuen .
In myrth and Iolite . oure lif to leuen .
And lightly so as it komyth so wylle we spende
Ey precious godis herte who wende
To day that we . shulde haue so faire agrace
But mytht this golde . be karied fro this place .
Home vnto my hous . or els to youres .
For wel I wote al this golde is ouris .
Than were we in hie felicite .
But trewly be day hit may nott bee ¶Pardoner .
Men wolde seyn that we were theuys stronge
And for oure tresour don vs honge
As wisely and also sleyghly as hit myght
This tresour moste I karied be be nyght
Wherefor I rede . late loke a monge vs alle
To drawe and late se where cutte shalle falle
He that hath the cutte with herte blithe
Shal renne to the toune and that ful swith
To bringe vs brede and drinke of the beste ful preuyly .
And to of vs shul kepe full . subtilly .
This tresoure a wel and yif he wil not tarie
Whenne hit is nyght we wil this tresour carie
Be on assente where as we likith beste .
The tou of hem brought gras in his fiste
And bad hym drawe . and loke on whom hit wolde falle
And hit fille on the yongest of hem alle .
And forth toward the toune . he wente anone
And also sone as he was agone .
The tone of hem spak to that tothir
Thou woteswel thou arte my sworyn brothir
Thy profite I wille telle the anone
And also sone as he was agone

l.hi: The tone of hem spake to that other

div.l: And here is golde and that right grete plente
That hit . shal b depardid be a monge vs thre .
But natheles yif I kanne shape hit soo .
That hit departid were a monge vs too .
Had I nought don a frendis turne to the
The tothir answerid . I notte howe hit myght be
I wolde welle that the golde were oure too .
What shulle we do that hit myght . be soo .
Shal hit be counseil . saide the firste shrewe
I shal telle the in wordis fewe .
What we shulle doo . and bringe hit aboute
I graunte quod that othir oute of doude
That be my trouthe I wille the nought be wrey
Nowe quod the firste thou woteswel we be twey .
And to of vs shulle strenger be than oon ¶Pardoner .
Loke whanne he is sette and that a noon
A rise as though thou woldiste with hym pley
And I shal renne thourgh his sidis twey .
While thou stroglist with hym as in game
And with thi dagger loke thou dothe same
And than shal this golde de ꝑpartid bee
My dere frende be twixte the and me .
Than may we bothe oure lustes fulfille .
And play at the dees right atte oure owne wille
And thus acordid be thise shrewis twey
To sle the thirde as ye herde me sey .
This yongest whiche that . wente to the toune
Ful ofte in his herte hit rollid vp and doune
The beute of thise florence faire and bright
O lorde quod he yif hit so were I myght
Haue al this tresour to my self a lone
Ther is no manne that leuyth vndir trone
Of golde . that shulde loue as mery as I .
And at the last the fende oure . enemye
b Putt in his herte . that he shulde . pusyn biee
Wyth whiche he myght slene his felowes tweyne
For whi the fende fonde hem in sweche leuynge
That he had leue hym to sorwe bringe
For this oughtirly is his intente
To slene hem bothe and neủere to repente
And forth he gothe no lenger . wolde he tarie
Vnto the toune vnto a poticarye
And preid hym . that he wolde selle
Somme puson that . he myght his rattis kille
And eke ther was a polkatte in his hawe .
That as he saide hese capownes had he slawe
And saide he wolde wreke . yif he myght
Of vermyn that distroied hym be nyght
The poticarie answerid thou shalt haue
A thinge that als so saue god mote my soule saue
In al this worlde ther nys creaturis .
That ete or drinke of this confecturis .
Nought butt the mountenaunce of a corne of whete ¶Pardoner .
That ne shal his lif a none for lete
Ye st̉erue he shal and that in lasse . while .
Than thou wilt gon a pace but a myle
This poisou that is so harde . and violente
The cursid man hath hit in his hond hit hente
This pusou in a box and sithins he ranne
Vnto the nexte strete . vnto a manne
And borwid hym large boteles three
To his felawes . ayeine repairith hee .
The thirde he kepte clene for his drinke
For al the nyght he shope hym to swynke
In cariyng of that golde oute of that place
And whan this reatour with sory gᵃce
Had fillid with hym his grete botelles three
To his felaues . ageyne repairith hee
What nedith it to ʆsermone of hit more
For right as they . caste so dide they yore
Right so they hym haue hym slayne and that a noon
And whan that this was don than spake that oon .
Nowe late vs sitte and drinke and make vs merie
And aftir warde . we willith . his body bury
And aftir hit happid hem ꝑpar cas .
To takyn a botel . where in pusou was .
And dranke and yaf his felawe also
Thourgh whiche a none thei steruyn bothe too .
But certis I suppose . that avicen
Wrote neủere in no kanoune in no fen
Mo wondre sorowes . of enpoisennynge
Thise had thise wrechis . to fore hir ending
Thus endid be thise homisides too .
And eke the fals pusoner also
O cursid synne ful of al cursidnesse
O traitours homycides o wikkidnesse
O glotonye luxurie and hasardrie
Thou blasfemour of Criste with vilonye
And othis grete of vsage and of pⁱride
Allas man kynde hou may hit be tide . ¶Pardoner .
That to thi creatour whiche that the wrought
And with his precious blode the bought
Thou arte so fals . and so vnd vnkynde allas
Now gode men god for yeue youre trespace
And kepe you fro synne of auarice
My holy pardoune may you al warish
So that ye offre noblis or starlyngis .
Othir siluer spones brochis or rīnges
Boueth youre hede . vndir this bulles .
Comyth vp you wivis . offerith your willes .
Youre name I entre here in my rolle a none
In to the blisse of heuen than shulle ye gone
I you assoile be my high pouere
Ye that willen offren as klene and eke as clere
As ye were borne and siris thus I preche
And ihu Criste that is oure soulis leche
So graunte you his pardou to resceive
For that is best I wille Iewel I wille nought you deseiue
But siris o worde for gate I in my tale
I haue relikes and pardoune in my male
As faire as any man in Engelond
Whiche were yife be the popes honde
If any of you wil of deuociou
Offren and hauen myn absoluciou
Comyth forth anon and knelith here a dovne
That ye may haue parte of my pardou
Or els takith ꝑpardoun as ye wende
Al new and fressh . at eủery tounes ende
So that ye offren . al wey newe and newe
Noblis or pens . whiche that ben gode and trewe
Hit is an honoure to you that ben here
That ye may haue a suffisaunte pardoner .
To assoile you in contre wher as ye ride
For auentures . whiche that may be tide
For ꝑparauenture ther may fal one or too .
Doune of his hors and breke his nekke attoo
Loke suche suerte hit is a monges you alle
That I am in youre felawship I falle ¶Pardoner .
That may asoile you bothe more and lesse
Whan your soule shal fro you body passe
I rede that oure hoste shal begynne
For he is moste envolupte in synne
Comyth forth sir hoste . and offre firste anon
Thou shalte kisse my relikes eủerychon
Ye for a grote vnboke a none thi purs .
Nay nay quod he thanne haue I cristis curs .
Lete be quod he thou shalt nough me so teche
Thou woldist me make kisse thine olde breche
And swere hit were . the relike of a sainte
Though hit were with thi foundement depeinte
But be the Crosse that seint Eleyne fonde
I wolde I had thi coliovns in my honde
In stede of relikes . ore seintewarie
Lete cutte hem of I wil hem kepe and carie
They shul be shrynyd . in an hors torde
This Pardoner answerid . nought a worde
So wroth he was . he wolde no worde sey
Now quod oure oste I wil no lenger pley
With the ne with none othir angry man
But right a non the worthi knyght be gan
Whan he say al pepil . lowe
No more of this . for hit is right I nowe
Sire pardoner . be mery and glad of chere
And ye sir oste that ben to me so dere
I pray you that ye kisse the pardoner .
And pardoner I pray you drawe you nere
And as we dedyn late vs . laugh and play
And now thei kissid and rede forth hir wey .
¶ Explicit fabula pardoner
T oure hoste sawe welle that the bright sonne
The cooke of his artificial day hath ronne
The ferthe parte and halfe an houre more
And though he were nought depe stirte in lore ¶ Man of lawe
He wist he wist hit was the xviij day
Of aprile that is messanger to may
And sawe wel that the shadewe of eủery mantreman tre
Was as in lengthe the same quantite
That was the body erecte that causid hit
And ther for be shadewe he toke his witte
That Phebus whiche that shone so clere and bright
Degees xlv was clomben in height
And for that day is in latitude
It was x a clokke he gan conclude
And sodenly he plight his hors a boute
Lordis quod he I warne you al aboutethe routeaboute the route
The ferthe ꝑparte of this day is gon
Now for the loue of god and seint Iohn
Lese no tyme a ferforth as ye may
Sires the tyme wastith nyght and day
And stelith fro vs what puely sleping
And what thourgh negligence in oure wakynge
As do the streme that turnyth neủereageyn
Discendyng fro the mounte in to the playne
Wel kan Senek and many a philosophir
Be waile tyme more than gold in coffre
For losse of Catel may recurid be
But losse of tyme shendith vs quod he
Hit wil nott come ageyne with oute drede
No more than wil Malkyn maiden hede
Whan she hath loste hit in hir wantounes
Late vs nought momble thus in Idilnes
Sir man of lawe quod he so haue I blisse
Telle vs a tale anon as forward is
Ye be submittid be youre fore assente
A quite you nowe of youre beheste
Than haue ye done youre deủere at the leste
Hoste quod he depardieus I assente
To breke forwarde is nought myn entente
Behest is dette and I wil holde fayne ¶ Man of lawe
Al my behest I kan no bettir sayne
For suche lawe as a man yeuyth a nothir wight
He shulde hym selfe vse it be right
Thus wil oure tixte but nertheles serteine

In E Ermygildis chaumbre while she slepte
¶ Wery for wakyng in hir orisonis
Slepith Cunstaunce and Ermigild in twoalsoin two also
This knyght thourgh sathan temptacions
Al sotilly to the bed is gongoogon goo
And kutt the throte of ermygilde in two
And leide the blody knyf be dame Custaunce
And wente his wey ther god yif hym mischaunce
¶ Sone aft̉er cometh the Cunstable hom a geyn
And eke Alla that kynge was of that londe
And in the bedde sawe his wif dispitously I slayne
For whiche he wepte and wronge his honde
And in the bed the blody kif he fonde
Be dame Custaunce allas what myght she sey
Fo verry wo hir wit was all awey
¶ To kynge alla was tolde this myschaunce ¶ Man of lawe
And eke the tyme where and in what wise
That in a ship founde was this custaunce
As here be forne that ye haue herde deuyse
The kyngis herte of pite gan a grise
Whan he sawe so benygne a creature
Falle in dissese and mysauenture
¶ For as the lambe toward his deth is brought
So stante this Innocente be fore the kynge
The fals knyght that this treson wrought
Berith hir an honde that she did this thing
But nertheles ther was grete mornyng
A monge the people that seyn the canne nott gesse
That she hathe don so grete a wikkidnesse
¶ For they haue seyne hir so vertuous
And louyng Ermygilde right as hir lif
Of this bare wittenesse euiche in the hous
Saue he that Ermygilde slow with his knyf
This gentil kynge alla hathe take a grete motife
Of this wittenesse eủeriche in thateủeriche in that thought he wolde inquere
Depper in this cas a trouthe to lere
¶ Allas Custaunce thou has no champiou
Ne fight kanste thou nought so wel a wey
But he that for aloure aal oure al redempcioun
Bonde sathan and yit liggith ther he lay
So be thi stronge champiou this day
For but if criste open miracle kithe
With oute gilte thou shalt be slayne as swithe
¶ She sette hir doune on knees and she saide
Imnortal god that sauid susanne
Fro fals blame and thou mercifull maide
Mari I mene doughtir to seinte anne
Be fore hose childe aungelis singe osanne
If I be gilteles of this felonie
My socour be or els I shal die
¶ Haue ye nought se sum tyme a pale face
A monge a pres of hym that hath be ladd
Towardis deth ther as hym getith no grace
And suche a colour in his face hathe hadd
Men myght k know his face that was bestadde ¶ Man of lawe
A monge al the faces in the route
So stante Custaunce and lokith hir aboute
¶ O quenis bebe leuīnge in prosꝑperite
Duchessis and ye ladies eủerychou
Haue sum ruthe on hir adeủersite
An EmꝐPerouris doughtir stante alone
She hath no wight home to make hir mone
O blode Roial that stondist in this drede
Fer ben thi frendis in thi grete nede
¶ This kinge alla hathe suche compassiou
As gentill herte is fulfillid of pite
That fro his eien ran the watir doune
Now hastily go fecche a boke quod hee
And if this knyght wil swere howe that she
This woman slowe yit wil we vs auise
Hom that we wille shal ben oure iustice
¶ A Britou boke writen with Euangelis
Was fette and hee on this boke swore heehee a noon
She giltif was and in the mene whilis
An hand hym smote on the nekke bon
That doune he fille at onis as a ston
And both his eien b breste oute of his face
In sight of eủery body in that place
¶ A vois was herde in general audience
And saide thou haste disclaundrid gilteles
The doughtir of hōny chirche in hie psence
Thus thou has don and yit I holde my pees
Of this miracle agaste was alle the pres
As masid folke they stode eui chon
For drede of wreche saue Custaunce a lone
¶ Grete was the drede and eke and repentaunce
Of hem that had wronge suspeciou
Vpon this seli Innocente Custaunce
And for this miracle in conclusiou
And be custaunces mediacion
The kynge and many othir in that place
Conuertid were thankid be goddis grace
¶ This fals knyght was slayn for his vntruthe ¶ Man of lawe
Be Iugement of Alla hastily
And yit Custaunce had of his dethe reuth
And aftir this ihus of his mercy
Made alla wedde h ful solempnely
This ioly maiden that bright was and shene
And thus hath Criste made Custaunce a quene
¶ But ho was woful if I shal nott liee
Of this wedding but Donegilde and no moo
The kyngis modir ful of tiranny
Hir thought hir cursid herte brast in too
She wolde nought hir sonne had do soo
Hir thought a dispite that he shulde take
So straunge a creature vnto his make
¶ Me luste nought of the chaffe ne of the strawe
Make so longe a tale as of the corne
What shulde I telle of the realte
Of mariage or whiche course bebe gothe be forne
Ho blowith hiest in trumpe or horne
The frute of eủery tale is for to sey
They ete and drinke daunce and singe and pley
¶ They gon to bedde as hit was skille and right
For though that wivis ben ful of holy thinges
Thei muste take in pacience at nyght
Suche man necessaries as be plesinges
To folke thatt haue hem weddid wit ringes
And leien a litil hir holynesse aa be side
As for the tyme it may non othir tide
¶ On hir he gate a knaue childe anon
And to a bisshop and to his Constable eke
He toke his wif to kepe when he is gon
To scotteland warde his fomen for to seke
Nowe faire Custaunce that is so humble and meke
So longe is gon with childe til that stille
She halte hir chaumbre abiding cristis wille
¶ The tyme is come a knaue childe she bere
Mauricius at the fonstou they hym calle
This Constable does forth come a messanger
And wrote to his kyng clepid alle Man of lawe
How this blisful tithingꝭes is be falle
And othir tithingis spedeful for to sey
My lady He takis the lettir and forth he goth his wey
¶ This messanger to don his avauntage
To the kyngis modir he ridith swithe
And salutith hir fair in his language
Madame quod he ye may be glad and blithe
And thanke god an C Mˢ sithe
My lady quene hathe childe withoutyn doute
To ioie and blisse of al the regne aboute
¶ Loo here the letteris selid of this thinge
That I muste bere with al the haste I may
Yf ye wille ought to youre sonne the kynge
I am youre owne ʆseruᵃnt nyght and day
Donegilde as nowe att this tyme nay
But here al nyght I wil thou take thi reste
To morwe wille I sey the what me leste
¶ This messanger dranke sadly ale and wyne
And stole were his lettres puely
Oute of his boxe while he slepe as a swyne
And countirfetid was ful subtilly
An nothir lettre wrought ful sinfully
Vnto the kynge directe of this matere
Fro his Constable as ye shul here
¶ The lettre spak the quene delyuerid was
Of so horrible a fendely creature
That in the Castel non so hardy was
That ony while durst ther in a bideendurea bide endure
The modir was an Elf be auenture
I comen be charmes or be sorceri
And eủery wight hatith hir compani
¶ Wo was this kynge whan he this lettre hathe sayn
But to no wight he tolde his wordis sore
But of his owne hande he wrote ageyne
Welcome the sonde of criste for eủere more
To me that am nowe lerid in thi lore
Lorde welcome be thi luste and thi plesaunce
Mi luste I put al in thine ordinaunce
¶ Kepe this childe al be hit foule or faire
And eke my wif vnto my home cōmynge ¶ Man of lawe
Crist whan hym liste may send me an heire
More greabletretablegreable tretable than is to my likynge
This lettre he selith puely weping
Whiche to the Messanger was take sone
And forthe he gothe ther is no more to done
¶ O messanger fulfillid of drunkenesse
Stronge is thi brethe thyn lymmes faltyn ay
And thou be wreieste al thi sikirnesse
Thi mynd is lore thou Iangeliste as a iaie
Thi face is turnyd in a newe aray
Ther droıı̄unknesse regnyth in ony route
Ther is no counseil hid withoutyn doute
¶ O Denegild I haue noon Englissh digne
But thi malici and thi tiranny
And therfore to fende I the resigne
Late hym endite of thine traitorie
Fy manysh fy nay be god I lie
Fy fendly spirit I der wel telle
Though thou here walke thi spirite is in helle
¶ The messanger comyth fro the kynge ageyn
And atte the kynges modirs Court he light
And she was of this messanger ful fayne
And plesid hym in al that she myght
He dranke and wel his girdil vndir pight
He slepith and he fnertith in his gise
Al nyght til the sonne ganne rise
¶ Efte were his letteres stole eủery chon
And countirfetid letteris in this wise

l.seg: That he ne shulde suffre in no wise
Custaunce with in his regne to abide

div.l: The kynge comaundith his constable anone
Vp peine of hanging on an hie wise
That he ne shulde suffre in no wise
Custaunce with in his reigne to abide
Thre daies and a quarter of a tide
¶ But in the same ship as he hir fonde
Hir and hir yonge sonne and al hir gere
He shulde putte and croude fro londe
And charge hir that she neủere efte come there
O my Custaunce wel may thi gost haue fere
And sleping in thi dreme ben in penaunce
Whan Donegild caste alle this ordinaunce Man of lawe
¶ The messanger on morwe whan he woke
Vnto the Castel holdith the nexte wey
And to the Cunstable he the lettir toke
And whenne that he this pitous lettir sey
Ful ofte he seide allas and wellawey
Lorde Criste quod he how may this worlde endure
So ful of synne is many a creature
¶ O myghty god if that it be thi wille
Sothe thou arte rightfull iuge how may hit be
That thou wilte suffre Innocentꝭes to spille
And wikkid folke regne in s prosꝑperite
O goode Custaunce allas so wo is me
That I muste be thi tourmentoure or die
On shames dethe ther is noon othir wey
¶ Wepyn bothe yonge and olde in that place
Whan that the kinge this cursid lettre sente
And Custaunce with a dedly paleface
The ferth day toward hir ship she wente
But neủerthe les she takith in goode intente
The wil of Criste and knelyng on the stronde
She saide lorde ay welcome be thy sonde
¶ He that me kepte fro the false blame
While I was on londe amonges you
He can me kepe fro harme and shame
In the salte see al thowgh I se nott howe
As stornge as eủere he was he is right nowe
In hym truste I and in his modir dere
That is to me my saile and eke my stere
¶ Hir lytil Childe lay weping in hir arme
And knelyng petously to hym she saide
Pees litil sone I wille do the none harme
With that hir kerchef oeủere hir hede she leide

l.seg: And in hir arme she lullith hit ful faste

div.l: And oeủere hir childes eien she hit leide
And in hir arme she lullith hit ful faste
And to heuen hir eien vp she caste
¶ Modir quod she and bright maide marie
Sothe hit is that thourgh womannes eggement ¶ Man of lawe
Mankynde kynde was loste and dampnid to die
For whiche thi childe was on Croisse rente
Thi blidsid eien sawe al this turmente
Thanne is no comparisoun be twene
Thi wo and my wo man may sustene
¶ Thou saw thi sonne slayne be fore thyne eiene
¶ And right nowe lyueth my litil childe ꝑparfay
Now lady bright to hom alle woful crien
Thou glorie of womanhede thou faire may
Thou hauen of refute bright sterre of day
Rewe on my childe that of thi gentilnes
Rewist on eủery reuful in distresse
¶ O litil childe alas what is thi gilte
That neủere wroughtest synne as yit ꝑpardee
Whi wil thi harde fadir haue the spilte
O mercy dere Constable quod she
As late my childe dwelle here with the
And if thou dar nought saue hym frforfror blame
So kisse hym ones in his faders name
¶ With that she lokith bakwarde to the londe
And saide farewelle housbonde reuthelese
And vp she risithe and wakith to the stronde
Toward the ship hir folwith al the pres
And eủere she praieth hir childe to holde hir pees
And takith hir leue and with an holy entente
She blissid hir and to the ship she wente
¶ Vitailid was the ship it is no drede
Habundantly for hir ful longe space
And othir necessaries that shulde nede
She had I nowe heried be godis grace
For wynde and wedir al myghty god purchace
And bringe hir home I canne no bett̉er sey
But in the see she driuyth forth hir wey
¶ Alla the kynge cometh home sone aftir this
Vnto the Castelle of the whiche I tolde
And askid where his wif and his childe is
The Counstable ganne a boute his herte colde
And playnly al the matir he hym tolde ¶ Man of lawe
As ye han herde I kan telle no bettir
And shewid the kynge his owne sele and his lettir
¶ And saide lorde as ye comaundid me
Vp peine of dethe so haue I don certeine
This messanger turmentid was til hee
Muste be knowe and telle platte and playne
Fro nyght to nyght in what place he had layne
And thus be witte and subtil inqueringꝭes
Imagined was be whom that this gan springe
¶ The hande was knowe that this lettre wrote
Al the venum of this cursid dede
But in what wise certeinly I ne wotte
The effecte is this that alla oute of drede
His modir slowe that men may pleynly rede
For that she traitour was to hir ligegaunce
Thus endith olde Denegilde with mischaunce
¶ The sorwe of this alla nyght and day
Makith for his wif and his childe also
Ther is no tonge that hit telle may
But now wille I to Custaunce goo
That fletith in the see in peine and wo
v yere and more as likid Cristis sonde
Er that hir ship approchid vnto the londe
¶ Vndir an hethin Castelle at the laste
Of whiche th the name in my text I fynde
Custaunce and eke hir childe the seethe see vp caste
Al myghty god that sauyd al mankynde
Haue on Custaunce and hir childe sum mynde
That fallyn is in hethyn londe efte sone
In pointe to spille as I shal telle you sone
¶ Doune fro the Castelle conne ther many a wight
To gaure on this ship and on Custaunce
But shortly fro the castel on a nyght
The lordis stward god yif hym myschaunce
Athef that had reniʳe houre creaunce
Come into the ship and saide that he wolde
Hir leman be whethir she wold or nolde ¶ Man of lawe
¶ Wo was this wrechid womman be gon
Hir childe cried and she cried pitously
But blisful marie helpe hir right a noon
For with hir stroglynge wel and myghtly
That thefe fel oeủere the borde al sodenly
And in the see he drenchid for vengeaunce
Thus hath Criste vnwemmyd kepte Custaunce
¶ O foule luste of luxury lo thine ende
Nought only thou faintist mannys kynde
But verely thou evil his body shende
The ende of thi werke or of thi lustis blinde
Ys compleynyng how many on may men finde
That naught for werke but sum tyme of entente
To don this synne ben slayn or els shente
¶ How may this weyke woman haue strengthe
Hir to defende ageine this renegate
O Goli as vnmesurable of lengthe
How myght dauyd make the so mate
So yunge and of armur so desolat
How durste he loke vpon thi dredeful face
Wel may men see it is but god is grace
¶ Ho yaf Iudith corage or hardinesse
To sle oliphernes in his entent
And to delieủere oute of wrechidnesse
The peple of god I sey for this intente
That right as god spirite and vigour sente
To hem and sauyd hem oute of mischaunce
So sente he myght and vigoure to Custaunce
¶ Forthe goth the ship thourgh narwe mowthe
Of iubalter and sorth driuyth ay
Sum tyme weste and sum tyme north and southe
And sum tyme Estful many awery way
Til Cristis modir blissid be she ay
Hath shapyn thourgh hir endles goodenesse
To make an ende of h al hir heuynesse
¶ Now late vs stynte of Custaunce but a throwe
And speke we of the Romayn EmꝐPerour
That oute of surry hathe be letteris knowe
The slaughtir of Cristyn folke and dishonoure ¶ Man of lawe
Don to his doughtir be a fals traitour
I mene the cursid wikkid sowdonesse
That at the feste lete goo sle bothe more and lesse
¶ For whiche the EmꝐPerour hath sente anon
His senatoure with a Riall ordinaunce
And othir lordis god wote many one
On surreins to take hir vengeaunce
They brenne and flee and bringe hem to myschaunce
Ful many a day but shortly this is the ende
Homwarde to Rome thei shape hem to wynde
¶ This senatour repeirith with victorie
To Rome warde sailyng ful Rially
And mette the shipe as seithe the storie
In whiche Custaunce sittith ful pitously
No thing knewe what she was ne whi
She was in suche aray ne she wil sey
Of hir Estate though she shulde dey
¶ He bringith hir home to Rome and to his wif
He yaf hir and hir yonge sone also
And with the senatoure she lad hir lif
Thus canne oure lady bringe hir oute of woo
Woful Custaunce and many othir moo
And longe tyme dwellid she in that place
In holy werkis eủere as was hir grace
¶ The senatours wif hir awnte was
Fo But for all that she knewe hir neủere the more
I wil no lengir tarie in this cas
But to ky kynge alla whiche I spak of yore
That for his woo wepith and sikith sore
I wille retourne and lete I wil custaunce
Vndir the senatours goeủernaunce
¶ Kynge alla whiche that had his modir slayne
Vpon a day fel in suche repentaunce
That if I schortly telle shal and playne
To Rome he comys to receiue his penaunce
And put hym in the popis ordinaunce
In hie and lowe and ihu crist besought
For yife his wikkid werkis that he wrought
¶ The fame a none thourgh rome is borne
How alla kynge shal com on pilgrimage
Be herbegeouris that wente hym beforne
For whiche the senatour as was the vsage
Rede hym ageyn and many of his lynage ¶ Man of lawe
As welle to shewe his hie magnificence
As to don any kynge Reủerence
¶ Grete chere dothe this noble senatour
To kynge alla and he to hym also
Euerich of hem doth othir grete reủerencehonourreủerence honour
And so be felle that in day or too
This senatour is to kynge alla goo
To feste and shortly if I shal nott liee
Custaunce soune was in the cumpani
¶ Sum men wolde sey at request of Custaunce
This senatour hath lad this childe to feste
I may nought telle eủery circumstaunce
Be as be may there he was at the leste
But soth is this that at his modirs heste
Be forne Alla during the mete space
The childe stode lokyng in the kyngis face
¶ The kynge alla hath of the childe grete wondir
And to the senatour he saide anon
Hoes is that faire childe that stondith yondir
I nott quod he be god and by seint Iohn
A modir he hath but fadir hath he noon
That I of wote and shortly in astounde
He tolde alla howe this childe was I founde
¶ But god wote quod this senatour also
So vertuous a lyuer in my lif
Ne saw I neủere as is she ne herde of moo
Of worldly women maidyn ne wif
I dar wel sein that hir had leủere a knyf
Thourghoute hir breste thanne be a woman wikke
Ther is no man that couthe bringe hir to the prikke
¶ Now was this childe as like Custaunce
As possible a creature to be
This alla hath the face in remembraunce
Of Dame Custaunce and ther on musid hee
If that the Childis modir were owght shee
That is his wif and pⁱriuyly he sihidsightsihid sight
And sped hym fro the table al that he myght
¶ Parfai thought he fantom is in myne hede
I oughte deme of skilful iugement ¶ Man of lawe
That in the salte se my wif is dede
And aftirwarde he made this argumente
What wott I if that crist hath hir hedir sente
Mi wif be see as wel as he hir sente
To my contre fro thens that she wente
¶ And aftir none home with the senatour
Goth alla for to see this wondir chaunce
This senatour doth alla grete honoure
And hastily he sente aftir Custaunce
But truste welle hir luste nought to daunce
Whenne she wiste wherfor was that sonde
Vnnethe vpon hir fete myght she stonde
¶ Whanne Alla sawe his wif faire he hir grette
And wepte it was reuthe for to see
For at the first loke he on hir sette
He knewe well verrily hit was she
And for sorwe as dombe stant she as a tre
So was hir herte shit in distresse
Whan she remembrid his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twis she swounyd in his owne sight
He wepte and hym excusid pitously
Now god quod he and his halwis bright
So wisly ofonofon my soule as haue mercy
That of your harme as giltles am I
As is maurice my sone so like youre face
Elles the fende me fecche oute of this place
¶ Longe was the sobbyng and the bitt̉er peyne
Er that hir woful hertꝭes myght apt cesse
Grete was the pite for to here hem pleyne
Thourgh whiche pleintes gan hir sorwe encrece
I pray you alle my sorwe to relese
I may nought tell hir wo till to morwe
I am so sory to speke of sorwe
¶ But finally whanne the soth is wiste
That alla gilteles was of hir wo
I trow an hundrith tymys haue thei kiste
And suche ioie is ther be twix hem too
That saue the ioie that lastith eủer moo
Ther is nought like that ony creature
Hath sen or shal while the worlde may dure ¶ Man of lawe
¶ Tho praid she hir housbonde mekely
I relies of hir longe petous peyne
That he wolde pray hir fadir specialli
That of his hie magestete wolde incline
Vouche sauf sum day with hym to dyne
She preieth hym eke he wolde no worde sey
Vnto hir fadir be no wey
¶ Sum men wolde sey howe the childe Maurice
Dothe this message vnto the EmꝐPeroure
But as I gesse alla was nought so nice
To hym that was so souereyne of honoure
As he that is of Cristyn folke the floure
Sente ony childe but hit is best to deme
He wente hym selfe and so hit may wel seme
¶ This EmꝐPerour hathe grauntid gentilly
To com to diner as he hym be sought
And wel rede I be lokid besily
Vpon this childe and ou his doughtir thought
Alla goth to his Inne and as hym ought
Araied for this fest in eủery wise
As ferforth as connyng may suffice
¶ The morwe came and alla ganne hym dresse
And eke his wif the EmꝐPeroure for to mete
And forth they ridyn in ioie and gladnesse
And whanne she sawe hir fadir in the strete
She light adoune and fallith to his fete
Fadir quod she youre yonge childe Custaunce
Is now ful clene oute of youre remembraunce
¶ I am youre owne doughtir Custaunce quod she
That whilom ye hane sente vnto Surri
It am I fadir that in the salte see
Was put a lone and dampnid for to die
Now gode fadir mercy I you crie
Sende me no more in to hethynnesse
But thanke my lorde of his kyndenesse ¶ Man of lawe
¶ Ho canne the pitous ioi tellyn alle
Betwix hem thre sethe they ben thus I mette
But of my tale make an ende I shalle
The day goth faste I wille no lenger lette
This glad folke to diner they hem sette
In ioie and blisse I lete hem at mete dwelle
A thousandefolde more than I canne telle
¶ The childe Maurice was sethe EmꝐPeroure
Made by the Pope and lyuyd Cristynly
To Cristis Chirche he did grete honoure
But I letyn al this stori passyn by
Of Custaunce is my tale specialli
In olde Romaine gestis men may fynde
Maurice lif I bere it nought in mynde
¶ This kynge alla whan he his tyme say
With Custaunce his holy wif so swete
To Engelond be they com the right way
Where as they leue in ioie and quiete
But litil while it lastith I you hete
Ioie of this worlde for time wil nott abide
Fro day to nyght hit chaungith as the tide
¶ Who lyuyth eủere in such delite a day
That hym meuyd eithir conscience
Or ire or talent or sum kynnys fray
Enuy or pride or passiou or offence
I sey but for this ende this sentence

div.l: Whan endid was the tale of Mellebe
And of Prudence and of hir benignite
Oure s hoste seide as I am a feithful man
And be the pcious corpus Madrian
I had leuer than a barell ale
That goode lef my wif had herde this tale
For she nys no thing of suche pacience
As was this Mellebeis wif Prudence
Be Cokkis bonys whanne I bete my knaues
She bringith me thanne clubbid staues .
And krieth sle the doggis eủery chon .
And breke of hem both bakke and bon
And if any neigboure of myne
Wil nought in chirche to my wif incline
Or be so hardy . onis to hir trespace
Whanne she comyth home she rampith in my face
And crieth fals coward wreke thi wife
Be corpus bonys I wil haue thi kn knyf
And thou shalt haue my distaffe and go spinne
Fro day to nyght thus she wille beginne
Allas she seith that eủere I was I shape
To weddyn a mylke sop a coward ape
That wil ben oeủer ladde of eủery witht
Thou dar nought stonde be thi wiuys right
And at the dore I mote me dight
This is my lif I sholde fight
Or ellis I am lost but if that I .
Be like a wode lyou fole hardy .
I wel wote wel she wille do me sle sum day .
Sum neighboure and thanne renne away
For I am ꝑperilous with knyf in honde
Al be hit I dar nought with hir stonde
For she is bigge in armys be my feith .
That shal he fynde that hir mysdoth or seith
But late vs passe a wey fro this matere
My lorde Munke quod he so mery of chere
For ye shulle a tale talle treuly .
Lo Rouchestre stante here faste by .
Ride forth breke nought youre owne game
But be my trouth I knowe nought youre name
Whethir shal I calle you my lorde daun Iohn
Or els Daun Thomas or Daun albon
Of what hous be ye be youre fadir kynne
I vow to god thou has a full faire skynne
It is a gentil pasture ther thou goste
Thou arte nought like a penaunt or a goste
Vpon my feith thou arte an officer .
Sum worthi secresten or som celerer .
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Thou arte a maistir whanne thou art at home
No pore cloisterer . whanne thouwhanne thou ne no nouice
But a goeủernour willy and wise
And ther with all . ful of braune and of bones
A wel faring ꝑpersoune for the nones
I pray to god yeue hym confusiou
F That the firste brought in to religiou
Haddist thou as grete leue as thou hast myght
To ꝑperfourme all thi loue in engendure
Thou haddist be gotyn many a creature
Allas whi weris thou so wide a cope
God if me sorwe if I were a Pope
Nought oonly thou but eủery myghty man
Thowghe he were shorne brode vpon his panne
Shulde haue a wife for al this worlde is lorne
Religiou hath takyn al vp the corne
Of treding and we borel men beth shrimpis
Of feble trees com feble ympis
This makith thou oure heiris ben so sklendir
And feble that they may nought ingendre
This makith that oure wivis wille asay
Religious folke for they may bettir pay .
Be nought wroth my lorde you I prayyou I pray though I play
For ofte in game a sothe I haue herde seye
This worthi Monke toke al in pacience
And seide I wil don al my diligence
As ferforthe as sounyth in to honestee
To telle you a tale or to or thre
And yif you luste to herkyn hedirward
I will sey the lif of seint Edwarde
Or els first tregedies I wille telle
Of which I haue an hondrith in my selle
Tragedie is to sein a certeine storie
As olde bokis makith vs memorie
Of hem that stodyn in grete prosꝑperite
And ben fallyn oute of that degre
In to miserie and endyn wrecchidly
And they ben versified . cōmmunely
Of sixe fete whiche men clepe exametrou
In prose ben eke enditid many on
And in metre eke and in sundri wise
Lo this declaring ought I now suffise
Now herkenyth if you luste to here
But first I you beseche in this matere
Though I be ordir telle nought thise thingis
Be hit of Popes EmꝐPerouris or kynk kyngis
Aftir hir age as men writen fynde
But telle sum before and sum behynde
As comyth nowe in to my remembraunce
Haue me excusid of myn ingnoraunce
¶ Incipit Fabula Monachi
I wille bewaile in maner of Tregedie
The harme of hem that stondith in hie degre
And fel so that nere nas no remedie
To bringe hem oute of hir adeủersite
For certeine whanne fortune liste to flee
Ther may no man the cours of hir with holde
But no man truste of blinde prosꝑperite
Be ware of thise insaumples bothe yonge and olde
Lucifer though he an Angill were
And nought a man att hym I wille beginne
For thou fortune may non angel dere
From hie degre yet fel he for synne
Doune in to helle wher as he yit is inne
O lucifer . brightest of aungels alle
Nowe arte thou Sathanas thou maiste nott twynne

div.l: Oute of myresy whiche that he is Inne
¶ O adam in the felde of Damashene
Whiche of god is owne finger . wrought was he
And nought begotyn of no mannes vnclene sꝑperme
And welte al paradice of that tre
And neủere man so highe degre
As adam . till his mys goeủernaunce
Was dreuen oute of hie ꝓprosꝑperite
To labour and to helle and to myschaunce
¶ Sampsou this myghty and noble sampsou
Sampson whiche that was anuciate
To the aungil or his natiuite
And was to god al myghty consecrate
And stode in noblesse whiles that he myght see
Was neủere suche an othir as was he
To speke of strenghth and therto hardinesse
But to his wif . tolde he his secre
For whiche he slowe hym self for wrechidnesse ¶
Sampsou this myghty and noble sampsou
Withoutyn wepyn saue his handis twey
He slowe al to rente the lyou
To warde his dethe walkyng by the wey
His fals wif couth hym so welle plese and prey
Til she his counseil knewe and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counseill gan be wrey
And hym forsoke and toke a nothir newe
¶ An hundrid foxis toke Sampsom Sampsou for Ire
And al hir tailis he to gedir bonde
And sette the Foxis tailis al on fire
For he in eủery taile had putte a bronde
And they brente all the cornys in that londe
And al hir oliuys and hir vines eke
A thousande men he slowe eke with his honde
And had no wepyn but an asses cheke
¶ Whan they weren slayn so threstid hym that he
Was welny lorne for whiche ganne to prey
That god wolde of his peyne haue sum pite
And sende hym drinke or elles muste he die
And of an asses cheke that was so drie
Oute of a wangetoth sprange anon a welle
Of whiche he dranke I nowe shortly to sey .
Thus hath hym god as Iudicum can telle
¶ Be veray fors atte Gason one an nyght
Maugre the philestines of that Cite
The gate of the toune he hath vp plight
And on his bakke I karied hem hath hee
High on an hille where as men myght see
O noble and myghty Sampson lefe and dere
That stronge and noble hath bee
In all this worlde ne had ther ben thi pere
¶ This Sampsou neuer sidir dranke ne wyne
Ne on his hede came rasour non ne shere
Be pcepte of the messanger dyuine
For all his strenghthe was in his here
And fully twenty . yere be yere
He had of Israel the goeủernaunce
But aftir sone shal he wepe many a tere
For wōmmen shulle bringe hym to myschaunce ¶ Monke
¶ Vnto his lemman Dalida he tolde
That in his here al his strength lay .
And folsly to his fomyn she hym solde
Sleping in hir barme vpon a day .
She made to clip or shere his here a way .
And made his fomen al his crafte espien
