div.l: They bande hym faste and putte oute his eien
¶ But er his here were clippid or shaue
Ther was no bonde that myght hym bynde
But nowe is he put in prisoun in a kaue
There as they made hym at the querne grinde
O noble Sampson strengest of man kynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse
Thou maiste thou wepe with thine eien blid blinde
Sithens thou arte fro wele fallyn into wrechidnesse
¶ The ende of this Caitif was as I shalle say .
His fomen man made a feste vpon a day .
And made hym as hir fole to forne hem pley .
And this was at the temple of grete araie
But at the laste he made a foule afray .
For he to postes shake and made hem falle
And doune felle Temple ther hit laye
And slowe hym self and eke his fomen alle
¶ This is to seyn the pⁱrincesse eủerychon
And eke a Mᵗ bodies were there slayne
With the fallyng of the grete Temple of ston
Of sampsou wil I no more seyne
Bith ware of this ensaumple olde and plaine
That no man telle hir counseil . to hir wivis
Of swiche thingis they wolde haue secre fayne
Yif that hit touche hir lymys or hir̉e lyues
¶ Of Ercule the soeủereine conquerorour
Seynge his werkꝭes worthi and hie renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare the floure
He slow and rafte the skynne fro the lyoun
He of seintaurus leide the boste a doune
He arpies slowe the cruelle briddis felle
He goldyn apples rafte the dragoun
He drewe oute Serberois the hounde of helle ¶Monke
¶ He slowe the Cruell tyraunt buserus
He made his hors to frete hym skynne and bone
He slowe the verrey Sepente venemous
Of achilles to hornes brake he oon
And he slow kacus Inne a Caue of stone
He slowe the geaunte antevs the stronge
He slowe the gresely bore and that anon
And hathe the hede vpon the spere longe
¶ Was neủere wight sithen the worlde be ganne
That slowe so many monsteris as did he
Thourgh oute this wide worlde his name ranne
What for his strength and for his bounte
And eủery Reme wente he for to see
He was so stronge that no man myght hym lette
Atte bothe the worldis endes seide troue
In stede of boundis he a piller sette
¶ A lemman had this noble champiou
That hight Dianiere as fresshe as may
And as Clerkis make mensiou
She hath hym sente a sherte fressh and gay
Allas this sherte and weleawey
Enevemed Eneuemyd was sutilly with alle
Or that he hadd werid . hit halfe a day
Hit made is bones fro his flesh falle
¶ Thus starf this worthi myghty Ercules
Lo who may truste one fortune any throwe
For hym folwyd al the worlde of pees
Or he be ware is boste leide ful lowe
Ful wise is he that can hym self knowe
Bith ware for whanne that fortune luste to glose
Thanne wat waitith she hir man doune to throwe
Be suche a wey as he wolde leste supose
¶ But natheles sum Clerkis here excusyn
Be on nessus that hit makid .
Be hit as be may I will hir nought acousyn
But on his bakke this sherte he werid al nakid
Till that his flessh was of the venym blakid .
And whanne he sawe non othir remedie .
In hote Coles he hath hym self rakid
For with no venym deynyd he to die ¶ Monke
The myghty trone the pcious tresour
The glorious ceptre and reall mageste
That had the kynge nabugodonosor .
With tonge vnneth discriuyd bee
He twis name Ierusalem the Cite
The vessel of the Temple with hym lade
At babelyn was his soeủereyne see
In whiche his glorie and his delite he hadde
¶ The fairest Children of the blode riall
Of Iel Ierlm dede he gilde anon
And makid eche of hem to ben his thralle cherle
A monge al othir daniel was on
That was the wiseste childe of eủery chon
For he the dremes of the kinge expoundid
Wher as in Caldey . clerke was ther noon .
That wiste to fine his dremys sounyd
¶ This proude kynge made a stature of golde
Sixti cubites longe and vij of brede
To whiche ymage both yonge and olde
Comaundid he to ho loue and haue in drede
Or in a furneis ful of flames rede
He shalle be brente that wille nought obeie
But neủere wolde assent to that dede
Daniell ne his yonge felawes twey
¶ This of kynge of kynkis proude and elate
He wende that god . that sittith in mageste
Ne myght nought bereue hes estate
But sodenly he loste his dignite
And like a beste hym semyd for to bee
And ete heie as an oxe and lay ther oute
In reine with wilde bestis walkid hee
Til certeyn tyme were comyn a boute
¶ And like an Eglis federis was his eris heris
His nailis like briddis clawes were
God lernyd hym wit in certeine yeris
And yaf hym witte thanne with many a teres
He thankid god . and er euer is in fere
Was in goodenesse and did no more trespace
And or that tyme that leide was on the bere
He knewe welle that god was ful of myght and grace ¶ Monke
His sone whiche that hight baltesare
That helde his regne aftir his faderis day
He be his fadir . coude nought be ware
For proude he was of herte and of araye
And eke an hidolater . was he ay .
His high estate assurid hym in pⁱride
But fortune caste hym doune and ther he lay .
And sodenly his regne be gan dyuyde
¶ A feste he made vnto his lordis alle
Vpon atyme he made hym blithe be
And his officers gan he calle
Goo bringith forth the vessels quod he
Whiche that my fadir in his prosꝑperite
Oute of the Temple of Ierlm brought bi rafte
And to hiegh goddis thanke wee
Of honouris that oure elderst with vs lafte
¶ His wif his lordes and his counceillouris
Ay dronkyn whil hir apetite laste
And sawe oute of thise noble vessels sondry wynys
And on a walle this kynge his eyen caste
And sawe an arme handeles that wrote ful faste
For fere of whiche he quoke and . sighid sore
This hande that made so baltesar so gaste
Wrote mane techel . fares and no more
¶ In al that lande Magicien was ther noon
That koude expounde whit this lettyr mente
But Danyel . expoundid hit anon
And seide kynge god this fadir f sente
Glorie and honoure reigne tresour and rente
And was puyd and . god no thinge dradde
And for grete wrethe god vpon hym sente
¶ And hym berafte the regne that he hadde
He was oute caste of mannys companie
With assis was his habitacou
And ete haye as a beste in wete and drie
Till that he knewe be grace and be resoun
That god of heuyn hath domynaciou
Of eủery regne and eủery creature
And thanne had god . of hym compassiou . ¶ Monke
And hym restorid his reigne and his figure
¶ Eke thou arte his sone arte proude also .
And knowiste all thise thingis pⁱriuyli
And arte rebelle to god and arte his foo .
Thou dranke of his vessels boldely
Thi wif eke and thi wens wenshis synfully .
Dranke of the same vessels sondry wynys
And heried fals godis cursidly .
¶ Therfor shapyn to the grete peyne is
This honde was sente fro god that on the walle
Wrote mane techil fares truste me
Thi regne is don thou weiesse nough alle
Dividid is thi Regne and hit shal be
To Medes and to perces yeuen quod hee
And thilke same nyght the kinge was slawe
And darius occupied . it his degre
Thei he ther to . had neithir right ne lawe
¶ Lordingis here by may ye ensaumples take
Howe that in lordeship is no sekirnesse
For whanne fortune wille a man forsake
H She berith a wey his regne and his richesse
And eke his frendis bothe more and lesse
And what man hath frendis thourgh fortune
Misse hap wille make hym ennemyes I gesse
This ꝓproeủerbe is sothe and ful comine
¶ Senobia . of Palamire the quene
As writyn ꝑperciens of hir nobl nobillesse
So worthi was in armes and so kene
That no wight passid hire in hardinesse
Ne in lenage ne in gentillesse
Of kinges blode of perce is she discendid .
I sey sey she had nought most fairenesse
But of hir shap she myght nought ben a mendid .
¶ Fro hir childehode I fynde that she fledde
Office of woman and to wode she wente
And many a wilde hertꝭes blode she shedde
With arwis brode that she to hem sente
She was so swifte s that she anon hem hente
And whanne that she was eldir she wolde kille
She wolde kille liounis leopardes and beris al to rente
And in hir armys wilde hem at hir wille ¶ Monke
¶ She durst wilde beste dennes seke
And renne in the mounteynis al the nyght
And slepe vndir a bush and she couthe eke
Wrestelyn be verry forse and verry myght
With any yonge man were he neuer so wight

l.seg: To no man deynyd she to be bonde
Ther myght no thing in hir armes stonde

div.l: She kepte hir maidynhode fro eủery wight
To man deynyd hir to be bonde
¶ But at the laste hir frendis her maried
To Odenak a prince of that cuntre
Al were that she hym longe tarijd
And ye shulle vndirstonde how that he
Had suche fantasies as had she
But neủertheles they were knytte in fere
The leuyd in ioie and felicite
For eche of hem hadde othir leffe and dere
¶ Saf onthing she wolde neủere assente
Be no wey that he shulde be hir lie
But ones for hit was hir playne entente
To haue a childe the worlde to multiplie
And also sone as she myght aspie
That she nas nought with childe with that dede
Than wolde she suffre hym don his fantasie
Efte sones and nought but ones oute of drede
¶ And yif she were nought with ilke caste
No more shulde he pley thilke game
Till fully fourty wekis were paste
Than wolde she ones suffre hym to don the same
Al were this Odinak wilde or tame
He gatte no more of hir for thus she saide
Hit was to wivis lecherie and shame
In othir cas yif men with hem pleide
¶ Too sonnes by this Odinake had she
That she kepte in vertue and in lettrure
But nowe to oure tale turne we
I say that worshipful creature
And wise ther with and large with mesure
To penible in the werre and curteis eke
Ne more myght laboure myght in werre indure
¶ Was non in all this worlde men shulde seche
Hire riche array myght nought be tolde
As welle in vessell as in clothinge ¶ Monke
She was alle cladde in perry and in golde
And eke she lafte nought for no hontyng
To haue of sundry . tonges folke knowyng
Whan that she leisre had and nought for to entende
To lerne bokis was hir likynge
¶ How she myght in vertue hir lif dispende
And shortly . of this story . for to entrete
So doughty was hir housbonde as she
That they conquerid . many regnys grete
In the orient with many afaire Cite
Apertenaunte to the mageste of Rome
Of Rome and with . stronge hand helde hem faste
Ne neủere myght hir fomen don hir fle
¶ While that Odinak daies laste
Hir batailis hose luste hem to rede
A say Sapor . the kynge and othir moo .
And how that all . this processe felle in dede
Whi she conquerid . and what title had therto .
And aft̉er is mischef and wo .
Howe that she was besegid and I take
Whan Odinak was dede she myghtly
The Regne helde and with propir hande
A geyne hir foes she faught truly
That ther nas kyng ne prince in al that londe
That he nas glad if he that fande
That she ne wolde vpon his londe werry .
With hir they made a lyaunce be bande
¶ To levyn in pees and lete hir ride and pley
The EmꝐPerour of Rome Claudius
Ne hym beforne the Romayne galiene
Ne durste neủer be so coragious
Ne non of Ermyn ne noon Egipciane
Ne Surreyne ne none arabiene
With in the felde that durst with hir fight
Leste that she wolde hem with hir handis slene
¶ Or with hir meine put hem to flight
In kynges habite were hir sones too .
As heiris of hir Regnes alle
And her manno and Timaldo ¶ Monke
Hire names were as ꝑperciens kalle
But ay fortune hath ay in hony galle
This myghty quene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hir regne mader falle
¶ To wrechidnesse and to mysauenture
Aule Aureleon whan that the goeủernaunce
Of Rome kame in to his armys twey
He shope vp on this quene do veniaunce
And with his legiounes he toke his wey
Towarde Cenobie and shortly for to sey
He made hir fle and at last hir hente
And feterid hir and eke hir children twey
¶ And wanne the lande and home to Rome they wente
A monge thise othir thinges that he wanne
Hir chare that wrought was with golde and perre
This grete Romayne this aurilian
Hath with hym lad . for that men shuld see
With gilte cheines on hir nekke hangynge
Crownyd she was aftir hir degre
And full of Perre chargid hir clothing
¶ Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredeful . to kynges and to EmꝐPerouris
Nowe gaurith al the peple on hir allas
And she that helmyd was in starke shouris
And wanne be force tounes stronge and touris
Shalle on hir hede nowe were vetremyte
And shat bare the ceptre full of flouris
Shal bere a distaf hir Coste for to quite
O noble o worthi petir glorie of spaine
Whom fortune helde so high in mageste
Welle oughte men thi pitewous deth compleyne
Thi bastarde brothir . made the to fle
And aftir that asege be subtillite
W Thou were betraied and lad to his tente
Ther as is owne handis slene the
Succeeding in thi Regne and in thi rente
¶ The fed felde of snowe with egle blak ther inne
Kaught with lymeroddis coloures as the glede
He brewe the cursidnes and al synne
The wikkidnesse was wirke of al this nede
Nought Chareles Oliuer . that nought toke gode hede ¶ Monke
Of strengthe honour but armorikke
Genylou Oliuer corupte for mede
Brought this worthi kynge in swiche a brekke
¶ Worthi petre kinge of Cipre also .
That Alisaundre wanne be highe maistrie
Ful many an hethyn wroughtest thou ful woo .
Of whiche thine owne liges had envie .
And for no thinge but for chiualrie
They Inne thi bedde haue slayne the be the morwe
Thus canne fortune goeủerne and gie
And oute of þᵉ ioie bringe men to sorwe
O of Melayne grete Barnabo . viscounte
God of delite and scourge of lumbardie
Whi shulde I thi fortune a counte
Sithin in estate thou Clombyn were ful hie
Thi brothir sonne that was thine awne alie
For he thine owne nevew was and son in lawe
With in his pⁱrisoun made the to die
But whi ne howe wote I howe thou were slawe
O of the Erle hugelyn of pise the langour
Ther may no tonge telle for pite
But litill oute of pise I putte was hee
And with hym ben his litill childeryn thre
The Eldest skarsly fyue yere was of age
Allas fortune hit was grete cruelte
Suche briddis for to put in suche a cage
Dampnyd . he was to dien in that pⁱrisoun
For Roger whiche that was Bisshop was of pise
Had on hym made a false sugestiou
Thorugh whiche the puple ganne on hym a rise
And put hym in pⁱrisoun in suche wise
As ye haue herde and mete and drinke he had
And ther with all hit was ful pore and badde
And on a day it felle that in that oure
¶ Whanne that his mete was wonte to be brought
The gailer . shette the dore and the toure
He herde hit welle but he say it nought
And in his herte anone there felle a thought
That they for hungir . wolde don dien
Allas quod he allas that I was wrought ¶ Monacus
Ther with the teres . felle from his eyen
His yonge sonne that thre yere was of age
¶ Saide vnto his fadir whi do ye wepe
Whan wille the Gailerd bringe vs potage
Is ther no morcelle brede that ye do kepe
I am so honngri that I may not slepe
Nowe wolde god that I myght slepe eủere
Than shulde no hungir in my wombre crepe
Ther is no thing saue brede me were leuer
Thus day . be day . this childe ganne to crie
¶ Tille in his fadirs barme a doune hit lay
And saide fare welle fadir I mote dey
And kissid his fadir . and deide the same day .
And whan the wofull . Fadir . dede hym say .
For wo his armys towe he ganne to bite
And saide allas fortune and welaway
Thi fals whele t̉er my wo I may well wite
His Children wende that hit for hungir was
¶ That he his armes gnowe and nought for wo .
And saide fadir do nought so allas
But rathir ete the flesshe vpon vs too .
Oure flessh thou gaue vs take oure flessh vs froo .
And ete I nowe right thus to hym they seide
And aftir that with in a day or too .
They leide hem downe in his lap and died
¶ Hym self dispeirid eke for hungir starfe
Thus all endid is this myghty Erle of pise
Fro hie Estate fortune fro hym Carf
Thus endid is . Of this tregidie it ought I now suffice
Who so will . here hit in a lengir wise
Redith the grete Poete of ytaile
That hight dant for he hit can deuise
Fro pointe to pointe nought o worde wille he faile
¶ Alle be hit that nero were as vicious
As any fende that lith ful lowe a doune
Yit tellith vs sewthenevs
This wide worlde had he in subieccon . ¶ Monke
Bothe Este and weste of Septentriou
Of Rubies Saferis and Perlis white
Were alle his clothis broudid vp and doune
For he in gemmes grete gaf delite
¶ More delica more pompous in aray .
More proude was neủere EmꝐPeroure than was hee
That ilke cloth that he had werid a day
Aftir that tyme he nolde hit neủere see
Nettis of golde had he grete plente
To fissh in Tibre whan hym liste to pley .
His lustis were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wolde hym obeye
¶ He Rome brente for his delekasie
The senatoures he slowe vpon a day
To here how that men wolde wepe and crie
And slow his brothir and by his sustir lay
His modir made in pituous aray .
For he hire wombe slitte to be holde
Wher he conceyuyd was wellawey .
That he so litill of his modir tolde
¶ No tere oute of his eien for that sight
Ne kam but seide a faire woman was she
Grete wondir is howe he coude or myght
Be domysman . of hir dede beute
The wyn to drinke comaundid he
And dranke a non othir wo ne made
When myght is Ioynyd vnto cruelte
Allas to depe wele the venym wade
¶ In youth a maistir had this EmꝐPeroure
To teche hym lettrure and curtesie
For of moralite he was the floure
And in his tyme but bokis lie
And whilis of hym his maistir had maistrie
And made hym so connyng and so souple
That longe tyme it was ore tirantrie
Or any vice dirste on hym vncouple ¶ Monke
¶ This seneka of whiche I you deuise
Be cause Nero had of such drede
For he for his vicis wolde hym chastise
Discretely . as be worde and nought be dede
Sir wolde he seyn an EmꝐPeroure mote nede
Be vertuous and hate tyrantrie
For whiche he hym in bathe made to die
This Nero had eke of a custumaunce
¶ In youthe a geynste his maistir for to rise
Whiche aftir hym thought a grete greuaunce
Therfor he made hym dien in this wise
Chese in a bath to die in this manere
Rathir thanne to haue a nothir tormentrie
And thus hath Nero slayn his maistir
Nowe felle hit so that fortune liste no lengir
¶ The hie pride of Nero to cherice
For though he were stronge yit was she strenger .
She thought thus be god yit am I nise
To sette a man that is fulfillid in vice
In hie degre an EmꝐPeroure hym calle
Be god . oute of his sete I wille hym trice
Whanne he leste wenyth sonest sonneste shall he falle
¶ The pupel . ros vpon hym one ane nyght
For his defaute and when he hit aspied
Oute of his dores a none he hym dight
Alone and there he wende han ben alied
He kokkid faste and ay the more he kried
The fastir shette thei doris alle
Tho wiste he welle he had hym selfe begilid
¶ And wente his wey no lengir durste he calle
The puple cried an rvmbled vp and doune
That with his eris herd he howe they seide
For sokoure but hit myght nought betide
For drede of this hym thought that he deide
And thanne in to a gardyn
fande he clerkꝭescherlisclerkꝭescherlis tweyne
And satyn be a fire ful grete and rede
And to the Cherlis twey he ganne to sey prey
To sle hym and gerdyn of his hede
That to his body whan that hit were dede ¶ Monke
Were no dispite done for his defame
Hym selfe he slough he couthe no bett̉er rede
Of whiche fortune laugh and had game
¶ Was neủer Capetayne vndir a kynge
That Reignes N mo putte in subieccōn
Ne strengir was in felde of al thinge
As in his tyme ne strenger of renoune
Ne more pompous in high psumpsiou
Than oliferne which fortune ay kiste
So likerous and lede hym vp and doune
Til that he hedeles were er that he wiste
¶ Nought only that this worlde had of hym awe
For lesyng of Richesse and liberte
But he made eủery man reney his lawe
Nabegodonosor . was lorde seide hee
Non othir god . shulde honourid bee
Ayeinste his his heste dar no wight trespace
Sauf in Betolia . a strange Cite
Where Eliachym a prest was of that place
¶ But take kepe of the deth of Olipherne
He myd his oste he dronke lay on a nyght
With in his tente large as a berne
And yit for all his pompe and all his myght
Iudith a woman as he lay vp right
Slepyng his hede of smote and . of fro his tente
Ful priuyly she stale fro eủery wight
And with his hede vn to hir toune she wente
¶ What nedith it of kynge antiochus
To telle his hie and rial mageste
His hie pⁱride his werke venemus
For suche an othir . was neủere non as hee
Redith whiche he was in makabe
And redith the proude wordis that he saide
And whi he felle fro his prosꝑperite
And in an hille howe wrechidly he dide
¶ Fortune hym had enchauntid so in pⁱride
That verely . he wende he myght ateyne
Vnto the steris vpon eủery side ¶ Monachus
And in a balaunce to weyen eche mounteyne
And al the flodes of the see restreyne
And godis pepill had he moste in hate
Hem wolde he slee in turmente and peyne
Wenyng that god myght nought his pride abate
¶ And for that Nikamour and Tymothe
With Ievis were venquissid . myghtily
Vnto the Iewis suyche an hate had hee
That he hath greithid . is chare ful hastili
And swore and saide ful dispitously
Vnto Ierlm he wolde efte sone
To wreche his Ire on hit full cruelly
But of his purpos he was lette ful sone
¶ God for his manace hym so sore smote
With an Invisible wounde and vncurable
That in his guttꝭes carf so and bote
That his peynes were in portable
For many mannys go guttꝭes dede he peyne
But fro his purpos cursid and dampnable
For alle his smerte he nolde hym nought restreyne
¶ But bade a none appayrel his oste
And sodenly . er he were ther of ware
God dauntid al his pⁱride and all his boste
For he so sore felle fro his chare
That hurte his lemes and his skynne to dare tare
So that he ne myght go ne ride
But in a chare men aboute hym bare
Al for brissid . both bakke and side
The wrech of god . hym smote so cruelly
That in his body wikkid wormys crepte
And ther with alle he stanke so horribily
That non of all his men a boute hym barethat hy kepte
Whethir that he woke or slepte
Ne myght nought the stinke of hym indure
In this myschef he weilid and eke wepte
And knewe oure lorde god . and eủery creature
To all his oste and to hym self also
Ful lothsom was the stynke of his karine
No man ne myght hym bere to ne froo .
And in his stynke and in his horrible peyne
He starfe ful wrechid ly in an mu mounteyne ¶ Monke
Thus hath this robbour and this homycide
That many a man made to wepe and pleyne
Suche guerdon . has be longith vnto pride
¶ The storie of Alisaundre is so knowe cōmmvne
That eủery wight that hath discressiou
Hath herde sumwhat or al his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusiou
He wan be strength or force his high renoune
Ther weryn glad for pees vnto hym sende
The pⁱride and boste of man he leide a doune
¶ Comꝑparison ne myght neuer . yit be makid
Be twix hym and non othir conquerrour
For al this worlde for drede hym quakid
He was of knyght hode and of fredom floure
Fortune hym makid the hier of honoure
Saue wyne and women nothing myght he a swage
His hie entente in armes and laboure
So was he ful . of louyng corage
¶ What pite were hit to hym they I you tolde
Of Darivs and an hundrid thousande mo
Of princes kynges Erles bolde
Whiche he conquerid . and brought in woo .
I say as ferre as men may ride or goo
The worlde was his what shulde I more deuise
For though I write and tolde you eủer moo .
Of his knyght hode hit myght nought suffice
¶ Twelfe yere he Regnyd . as seith Makhabe
Philippes sone of Macedōn he was
That first was kynge of grece the countre
O worthi gentill Alisaundre allas
That eủere shulde falle in suche a cas
Enpusened . of thi folke thou were
Thi stronge fortune hath turnyd in to an aas
And yit for the wepte she neủere a tere
¶ Who shall men yeue teres to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse and . of Fraunechise
That al the worlde weldid . in his demyne
And yit hym thought hit myght nought suffice
So full was corage of his emprise
Allas who shalle me helpe to endite ¶ Monachus
Fals fortune and poysou to dispise
The whiche too of all this wo I wite
¶ Bi wisdom manhode and be labour
Fro humblehede and for Riall mageste
Vp ros . hercules . he . Iulius the conquerour
That al the ox occident by lande and see
Be strenghthe of hande or elles be tretee
And vnto Rome made he tributarie
And sethens of Rome than EmꝐPerour was he
Til that fortune wex his adeủersarie
¶ O myghty Cesar . that in tessalie
A yens Pampevs fadir thine in lawe
That of all the orient had alle the chiualrie
As fer as that day be ganne to dawe
That thourgh thi knyghthode haste hem take and slawe
Safe fewe folke that with pompeus fled
Thourgh whiche thou puttist al the oriente in awe
Thanke fortune that wel the spedde
¶ But now a litill wille I bewaile
This pompeus this nobil goeủernoure
